PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon. Sir Billy Snedden) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Community Youth Support Scheme
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That a need exists within the community for the Community Youth Support Scheme.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government not remove any funds for the Community Youth Support Scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we express our concern at the recent decision of the Commonwealth Government to disband the Community Youth Support Scheme, that we ask the Commonwealth Government to look more closely at the continuing high incidence of youth unemployment in this country, and the need to provide further opportunities of employment for such people and continuing support for those who suffer from such unemployment.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will reconsider its decision and will provide effective means of implementing additional programmes to provide further employment and support.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth their anger and condemnation at the Fraser government's decision to abolish all Community Youth Support Schemes on the 31st October 1981.
Further they denounce the decision for the disastrous effects it will have on growing numbers of unemployed young people around Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government immediately and fully reverse its decision and restore complete funding to the Community Youth Support Scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully demand:
That the decision of the Government to end funding for the Community Youth Support Schemes on October 31st, 1981 as announced by the Treasurer in the Budget speech of 18th August, 1981 be reversed.

Community Youth Support Schemes have operated successfully for five years and provide valuable community support and educational opportunities for unemployed young people which will not be adequately provided by other Government programmes. The full effect of the abolition of Community Youth Support Schemes will be felt by the unemployed people whose opportunities to participate in the Australian Community will be further diminished.
The petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives take all steps necessary to ensure that continued Government funding of Community Youth Support Schemes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the abolition of Community Youth Support Schemes show a callous indifference and lack of sensitivity to the needs of the unemployed youth of Australia.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government continue to fund the Community Youth Support Schemes throughout Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BROWN; CHARLES; CHILD; CUNNINGHAM; DARLING; DUFFY; JENKINS; KENT; MILDREN; PEACOCK; SHIPTON
PETITION.NAMEIDS: OD4; GF4; HF4; 0G4; UD4; 6G4; XF7; PH4; AI4; MI4; CJ4
PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth:
That the serious youth unemployment problem is a direct result of the community's failure to create sufficient jobs.

In these circumstances the decision to abolish Community Youth Support Schemes (CYSS) is a socially retrogressive step. The CYSS Projects provide valuable support services and work training for many young unemployed.

We the undersigned are concerned that the closure of CYSS Projects may lead young unemployed to become involved in anti-social behaviour such as crime, vandalism, prostitution, rebellious behaviour and mob action. There is the even more frightening prospect that many more young people will give up hope of obtaining a job, become idle and even contemplate suicide.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government reverse its decision to abolish CYSS Projects and provide sufficient funds to enable the various CYSS Centres to continue their valuable work with the young unemployed in the future.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr N. A. Brown,Mr Charles,Mrs Child,Mr Cunningham,Mrs Darling,Mr Duffy,Dr Jenkins,Mr Kent,Mr Mildren,Mr Peacock and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Division of Ballarat respectfully showeth:

(i) that the action of the Government in terminating the Community Youth Support Scheme will have serious effects upon the life possibilities of a significant number of young people who, through circumstances totally outside their control, are not able to find any form of paid employment,

(ii) that the action of the Government fails to understand that many unemployed youth do not fit into the retraining initiatives proposed and that part of the need within the total context of school-to-work transition is to have support structures based around the Community Youth Support Scheme model,

(iii) that the failure to provide such supports will place many young people in a position of high vulnerability to crime, violence, vandalism, drug abuse, and even suicide, and that the incidence of homelessness and family breakdown will be further aggravated.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government give immediate attention to the re-instatement of the Community Youth Support Scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cunningham,Mrs Darling,Mr Jacobi and Mr Mildren.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned members of the Warragul and district community, are concerned about the Budget decision to abolish CYSS.
In doing so, we believe that the Government has, in effect, turned a blind eye to the social and economic problem of increasing youth unemployment.

Without CYSS or a similar alternative, the government has taken away the only form of support being offered to the unemployed youth of Australia. The Government has taken away the place where young unemployed people come for various reasons, from general support, counselling, skills training etc., to help with employment issues, the only place where they can even chat and drink coffee with those in similar circumstances.

The Government has allocated more money into Training Programs. They can be no solution standing alone as they are not jobs, nor apprenticeships, which are sorely needed, and they do not necessarily offer any guarantees of being better equipped for employment.
A Community Youth Support Scheme is still greatly needed and in abolishing the program, the Government is not fulfilling its obligation to the youth and future leaders of this country.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
We, the people of the Geelong Community, request that the Community Youth Support Schemes (CYSS) throughout Australia, be restored.

We particularly ask that the Geelong and Corio CYSS Schemes be ongoing after the proposed closure date, 31st October, as they have contributed much to our community. CYSS has provided interests, support, opportunities for service, a voice in the community and job training for its thousands of participants over the past four years in Geelong.
CYSS is an important part of our community and we, as a community, support it especially in times of high youth unemployment that seriously affects our region.
We urge that the decision to close CYSS be reversed and that sufficient time and attention be given to a review of CYSS with a view to improvements or development of alternative support programmes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: CHARLES; CUNNINGHAM; DUFFY; HOLDING; KENT; MILDREN; MILTON; THEOPHANOUS; WILLIS
PETITION.NAMEIDS: GF4; 0G4; 6G4; CH4; PH4; AI4; DI4; QJ4; ZJ4
PETITION.TITLE: Diabetics: Insulin
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in view of the recent standardisation of insulin and insulin syringes, having the effect of increasing the cost of both items to the Diabetic in general, and as every insulin-dependent Diabetic must use the same, daily or twice daily according to medication.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that syringes be made available on the N.H.S. and that insulin prescriptions revert to 10 bottles as previously supplied.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Charles,Mr Cunningham,Mr Duffy,Mr Holding,Mr Kent,Mr Mildren,Mr Milton,Dr Theophanous and Mr Willis.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Service Homes Loans
PETITION.PARA: To The Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the members of the Women's Services of the 1939-45 War not at present considered eligible for Defence Service Home Loans should qualify as 'Australian Soldiers' under the Defence Service Homes Act. They volunteered for service with the Naval, Military and Air Forces, serving wherever they were sent in whatever capacity they were required and yet they are refused Defence Service Home Loans.

They took the oath to resist His Majesty's enemies which meant to fight His Majesty's enemies, and although not used in actual combat in war zones, they were available for that use and had a sufficiently grave need arisen would have been used, to serve with distinction as have women in other lands.

In accordance with the Acts and Regulations of the period, the women of the Military Forces had enlisted for service anywhere, some of the Naval women to sail in any waters, others with service on warships optional, while the women of the Air Force could have been sent to Papua New Guinea or other territories under the control or care of Australia.

Ex-servicemen of the Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Imperial Force and the Royal Australian Air Force who volunteered in the 1939-45 War but were not sent to War Zones are granted home loans. Not to grant eligibility to all Ex-servicewomen of 1939-45 War is unjust and unfair.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you favourably consider amending the Defence Service Homes Act by repealing Sub-section 4 (2A) (b) (c) (d) of the Principal Act as amended by No. 137 of 1978, and grant eligibility to all members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service, the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Australian Army Medical Women's Service, and the Voluntary Aid Detachment of 1939-45 War
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Child,Mr Duffy and Mr Peacock.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Service Home Loans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That all members of the Women's Services 1939-45 War qualify as 'Australian Soldier' under the Defence Service Homes Act for loans because on voluntarily joining the Australian Forces they took the oath to resist His Majesty's enemies making themselves available for combat duty in War Zones, and according to Acts and Regulations of the period the Military women had enlisted for service anywhere, some Naval women to sail in any waters, with all servicewomen available for service in Papua New Guinea.

As those members of the Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Imperial Force and the Royal Australian Air Force of 1939-45 War who were not sent to War Zones are granted loans, refusal to grant eligibility to all Ex-servicewomen of 1939-45 War is unjust and unfair.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that you amend the Defence Service Homes Act by repealing Sub-section 4 (2A), (b), (c), (d) of the Principal Act as amended by No. 137 of 1978, and grant eligibility to all members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service, the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Australian Army Medical Women's Service, and the Voluntary Aid Detachment of 1939-45 War.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Kent and Mr Willis.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

We, the people who have signed this petition, ask all parties: Labor, Liberal, Democrats, and others, to stop the latest increase in taxes, and the forever increases in taxes which hit all people of the country of Australia in all goods and consumer goods and we call for a referendum on taxes and interest rates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Duffy,Mr Kent and Mr Milton.

PETITION.TITLE: Trans Australia Airlines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Many Australians depend almost exclusively upon Trans Australia Airlines for the provision of essential air services.
The Federal Liberal Party policy objective of selling Trans Australia Airlines within 4 years is contrary to the national interest.
Sale of Trans Australia Airlines would inevitably result in-
(i) the creation of a private monopoly of major airline services of Australia;
(ii) higher domestic air fares.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject outright any proposal to sell Trans Australia Airlines.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Kent,Mr Morris and Mr Willis.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. the proposal to introduce fees for higher and second degrees will mean that access to post-graduate and recurrent education will be limited to the rich; Australian research and ability to cope with technological change will suffer; this proposal must be seen as a step in the direction of the introduction of fees for all tertiary students.

2. the proposed introduction of a loans scheme for students will mean graduating with a heavy debt or being denied a tertiary education if loans are refused because a student is seen as a ''poor risk'' (particularly affecting women and those doing non-vocational courses); only the rich will be able to get a tertiary education without course restrictions and the burden of indebtedness.

3. in regard to the proposal to restrict eligibility for TEAS and the foreshadowing or reviewing TEAS levels only in the light of the availability of loans, it should be noted that any further downgrading of TEAS, which is already inadequate, can only further limit access to education.

4. the proposed restriction of Adult Secondary Assistance to those needing qualifications for employment will severely restrict access to a full high school education and necessary bridging education to tertiary education for those who left school early.

5. the proposal not to fund 30 Colleges of Advanced Education if they are not rationalised is an attack on teacher education. This attack will create teacher shortages in the mid 1980s, restrict access to education now and endanger the future quality of teaching available to Australian children.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
(i) post-secondary tuition fees not be introduced for any courses or for any category of students;
(ii) that the TEAS scheme be extended so as to more fully meet the real financial need of students;
(iii) that a comprehensive loans scheme not be introduced;
(iv) that there be no restriction of Adult Secondary Assistance;
(v) that the proposal not to fund 30 CAEs unless they are rationalized be rescinded.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Child and Mr Dawkins.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

(i) the financial situation of students enrolled at Australian post-secondary institutions is already extremely difficult (as indicated in the Commonwealth Department of Education's 1979 survey of student incomes and expenditures) and any substantial increase in the financial commitments of students would gravely worsen their financial difficulties.

(ii) the imposition of post-secondary tuition fees of comparable levels to those imposed prior to 1971 would force many currently enrolled students to discontinue their studies and deter many persons willing and able at present to undertake post-secondary study from doing so.

(iii) those students and potential students from social groups currently under-represented and disadvantaged in the post-secondary education system would be most severely affected by the reintroduction of fees for post-secondary education.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
1. post-secondary tuition fees not be re-introduced for any courses or for any category of students;
2. the visa charges upon private overseas students be removed immediately;
3. the Minister of Education immediately clarify the government's attitude to the re-introduction of post-secondary tuition fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Dawkins and Mr Kent.

PETITION.TITLE: Motor Vehicle Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the proposed changes to assistance to the passenger motor vehicle and components industries after 1984 shall lead to the collapse of the Vehicle Manufacturing Industry in Australia. Your Petitioners therefore pray that the Industries Assistance Commission Report be not given effect.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hurford and Mr Kent.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to investigate downgrading or closure of Avoca Post Office 3467 places in jeopardy the existing postal and mail services to our community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission taking any action to downgrade the postal and mail services of our community.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Division of Stirling respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to downgrade Postal and Mail services throughout Australia, will place in jeopardy the existing services and the security of the mails by:-
downgrading a large number of official post offices;
reducing the number of post offices open for business during the lunch period;
reducing the number of street posting boxes;
delaying telegrams by reducing the number of delivery offices;
downgrading post office services by employing untrained and unqualified staff; and
using private contractors for mail cartage.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission implementing any plan which will downgrade the Postal and Mail services of the citizens of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Elizabeth North Post Office
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully demands:

That the Elizabeth North Non-official Post Office not be closed on 31 December 1981. It is used by pensioners, unemployed and housewives who don't regularly have transport; the nearest other Post Office being at Elizabeth West, 1 Kilometre away.
The Petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives take all steps to prevent the closure.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aspect House for Handicapped Children
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. All children in Tasmania are not treated equally
2. Persons with intellectual, physical and multiple handicaps in particular will be denied access to ASPECT HOUSE, 6 Warragul Avenue, New Town in Tasmania if the house is closed
3. ASPECT HOUSE is faced with imminent closure because of lack of Government policy and on-going funding

4. ASPECT HOUSE is the only community-based facility in an ordinary house in an ordinary surburban setting which provides relief to parents and families engaged in the onerous and demanding task of rearing their handicapped children in the community
5. That the rights of all children to live with their families should be respected
6. That we seek Government to take immediate action to prevent the closure of this unique facility.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal Land Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the projected repeal by the Queensland State Government of the Aborigines Act 1971-1979 and the Torres Strait Islander Act 1971-79 will almost certainly lead to the degazettal of all Aboriginal reserves in Queensland, as has already been the case with Aurukun and Mornington Island.

That if, as is likely, the Aboriginal communities from these reserves are placed under similar shire council legislation of fifty year leases, they will be exposed to serious encroachment on their land by mining and tourist interests.

That it is also quite clear, on past evidence, that these interests will have the full backing of the Queensland Government and the rights of Aboriginal people to land rights and self-management will not be granted by that Government.

That the Commonwealth Government has the power to legislate and acquire land for Aboriginal people under its constitutional powers since the amendments to the Constitution in 1967, but it is your Petitioners' sincere belief that it failed to act in 1978 and thus, failed in its duty before the people of Aurukun and Mornington Island.
That the Aboriginal people of Queensland have stated that they want land rights and self management.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government make use of its constitutional and legislative powers to grant full land rights and self management to the Aboriginal people in Queensland.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. The Government proposes to impose a Sales Tax of 17 1/2 per cent on manufactured pet foods which were previously exempt.
2. That this new tax will impose an unreasonable burden on pet owners, many of whom are pensioners and citizens in receipt of a small income.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will withdraw or repeal its Sales Tax Legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Government's Sales Tax legislation imposes an unreasonable burden on the community generally, especially pensioners, families, those in receipt of smaller incomes and small businesses.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will withdraw or repeal its Sales Tax Legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights in Chile
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That many people have left Chile because of political, religious and economy persecution, and that these people would face imprisonment, and political and economic harassment if forced to return.
That statements by Amnesty International and the London-based Chilean Committee for Human Rights reveal there has been no abatement of political, religious and economic persecution in Chile.

That Australia, as a signatory to the 1951 United Nations' Convention and the 1967 United Nations' Protocol on refugees, adopt and endorse the principles for refugee status espoused by the legal adviser to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Dr Guy Goodwin-Gill.

That many Chileans presently in Australia, including two refugee status applicants, Fernando Del Carmen Cerda Labarca and Pedro Jose Belmar Aguilera, clearly fall within the parameters of Dr Goodwin-Gill's definition.
We urge the government to grant refugee status to these two refugees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Government Publishing Service Bookshops
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Government Publishing Service bookshops provide the main source of access by citizens to Government information and publications.
That this information distribution is an essential pre-requisite for a democratic system, and that all Government publications should be readily available to the community.

That control of the distribution of government publications is an essential service and should not be in the private sector where only high demand, and hence profitable publications will be carried, leading to a restriction on publications available to the community.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject outright any proposal to transfer the functions of the AGPS bookshops to the private sector.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Metric System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth objection to the metric system and request the Government to restore the imperial system.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. Our grievance that taxation on interest earned in bank and building society savings accounts is thus a law and-
2. Our grievance that interest charged on home mortgage loans is not at this time, an allowable taxation deduction.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should:-
1. Allow interest earned in bank and building society savings accounts-to the approximate amount of $500.00 (five hundred dollars)-to be not counted as Taxable Income.

2. Deem that interest-to the approximate amount of $1000.00 (one thousand dollars)-charged on home mortgage loans be an allowable taxation deduction. This only applicable on the private home of the taxpayer, and not on any investment properties.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That many Australians will be financially disadvantaged by the health changes proposed by the Federal Government, especially the withdrawal of Commonwealth medical benefits for the uninsured, and the introduction of a means test for free public hospital care;
That the health insurance changes promote inequity, inefficiency and lack of universal coverage;
That the public hospital system and community health programmes will be financially disadvantaged by the abdication of Commonwealth responsibility and funding.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will take all steps necessary to reintroduce a system of health care based on ability to pay, and access to health care based on medical need.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the proposed sales tax of 2.5 per cent on books, magazines and newspapers represents a tax on knowledge which should not be contemplated in a civilised country. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that this proposed sales tax be withdrawn from the budget proposals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned residents of Salisbury and Elizabeth in the State of South Australia petition that:

Competition between banks and finance companies by giving ever increasing interest rates to obtain the investors' capital, is against the nation's best interest. It penetrates every form of activity by constant demands for higher wages to meet these explosive conditions.

It is an intolerable burden to the younger generation of family life, that by necessity are the recipients of these excessive interest rates that are catastrophic to house purchase and natural living.

We therefore respectfully petition for an urgent annual realistic controlled reduction right ''across the board'' on all existing and future interest rate agreements. With a maximum interest percentage ceiling on investors' capital, and a scale of interest charges for loans as appropriate.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will give effect to our submissions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned residents of Hindmarsh Division, State of South Australia petition that:

Competition between banks and finance companies by giving ever increasing interest rates to obtain the investors' capital, is against the nation's best interest. It penetrates every form of activity by constant demands for higher wages to meet these explosive conditions.

It is an intolerable burden to the younger generation of family life, that by necessity are the recipients of these excessive interest rates that are catastrophic to house purchase and natural living.

We therefore respectfully petition for an urgent annual realistic controlled reduction right ''across the board'' on all existing and future interest rate agreements. With a maximum interest percentage ceiling on investors' capital, and a scale of interest charges for loans as appropriate.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will give effect to our submissions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Motor Vehicle Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled. This Petition of the undersigned electors of the Division of Henty, P.B.R. division of Repco, respectfully showeth that:
1. the automotive products industry is vital to the livelihood and well being of many thousands of Australian workers and their families.
2. if imported automotive products are allowed to flow freely into the Australian market it will deprive over 100,000 workers in the industry of their work opportunities.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament recognise the rights of Australian workers in this industry and that proposals to reduce the level of protection in the future be rejected.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned residents of Northern Tasmania respectfully showeth our opposition to the Sales Tax Bills. We call on you to support the Senate's requested amendments to the Sales Tax Bills concerning such items as clothing, footwear, building materials, wrappings, books, magazines and newspapers.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate's requested amendments to the Sales Tax Bills be supported.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Motor Vehicle Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled.

This humble petition of citizens of the Geelong region in the State of Victoria respectfully request the Federal Parliament not to accept the IAC recommendations on the motor vehicle industry as they would, if accepted, have a disastrous economic effect on the region and would create massive unemployment.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House condemns the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats for interfering in the decision making of the Tasmanian people by initiating a Senate inquiry into the South West of Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Did the Prime Minister have any discussions with the Minister for Industrial Relations about answers he might give or about questions that might be asked in the House in respect of the Estimates Committee E meeting on 8 September?

—I have many conversations with Ministers and quite obviously I am not going to relate those conversations in this House. Obviously, if a Minister has been under criticism the Minister is entitled to defend himself.

—Mr Speaker, I ask a question of you. In view of the secrecy that appears to surround the current deliberations of the Privileges Committee and the effect that secrecy could have on the decisions this House may have to make on any recommendations of the Committee, I ask: Have any persons appearing before the Committee been instructed that they cannot consult with their own counsel about matters which transpire before the Committee? If this is so, will it create the impression that the Committee is conducted in the context of a secret court? Lastly, will the evidence of the proceedings of the Privileges Committee be made public prior to the House being called upon to make a decision upon any recommendations that may be placed before it?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the honourable gentleman is under a misapprehension about the role of the Speaker in relation to privilege matters. The Speaker has an obligation under the Standing Orders to ascertain the material raised by the person who brings up the matter of privilege, and out of that material the Speaker is obliged to decide whether or not there is a prima facie case. In the instant matter I did look at the material-I had had the opportunity of seeing it before, it having been brought to my attention-and I found there was a prima facie case. Then, under the Standing Orders, I gave the honourable member for Dundas an opportunity to consider the motion he would bring up. In the event, the motion was brought up and voted on by the House.

INTERJECT.PARA: I want the honourable member and all other members of the House to know that the Speaker is the servant of the House, and the Standing Orders make provision for the Privileges Committee to examine a matter. The conduct of this matter is in the hands of the Privileges Committee. The Committee is entitled to make preliminary reports and a final report. It has the exclusive right to the conduct of the matter before the Privileges Committee. Certainly, there is no means whereby the Speaker is authorised to attempt to influence in any fashion the findings of the Privileges Committee. When the findings come before this chamber the members of parliament in the chamber will be able to make up their minds on the basis of the report. At this stage, I can go no further than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Prime Minister's attention been drawn to reports that the Builders Labourers Federation has a full list of all companies involved in the Government's deregistration moves against the union? Has he noted claims that the list was obtained after the Minister for Industrial Relations invited journalists into his Melbourne office and then left them with relevant files of the deregistration application? Has the Prime Minister discussed this matter with the Minister for Industrial Relations? Has he asked the Minister for his resignation; if not, why not? Alternatively, has the Minister offered to resign. If so, why has the Prime Minister not accepted his resignation?
—I have not discussed that matter with the Minister. Therefore, I have nothing to add to the honourable gentleman's question.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH HEADS OF GOVERNMENT MEETING: DISCUSSION OF PROTECTIONIST POLICIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Prime Minister recall telling the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Lusaka that protectionist policies are inimical to general economic recovery and put the future growth of developing countries in jeopardy? Will he adopt the same approach at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be adopting the same approach at this meeting. If anyone shows an interest in Australia's position, I will point out how, over the last 10 or 12 years, general tariff levels have been reduced very significantly in Australia, how we use quantitative restrictions or non-tariff devices to a much lesser extent than most other countries and how we do not have voluntary restraint arrangements, which most of the other advanced industrial countries have, which they practice very greatly and which impinge upon our exports as they impinge upon the exports of many other countries. I think one point does need to be emphasised. I can well understand those who argue for lower levels of protection and freer trade. I believe that all of us would understand and know that that will assist in promoting healthier and stronger industry in Australia and in increasing productivity around the world. It will assist in enabling those who can do things well to do more of them and to do so more competitively.

ANSWER.PARA: At the same time, obviously, a movement in that direction, as we had with the textiles, apparel and footwear industries, needs to be gradual and within the capacity of domestic industries to absorb the structural changes which are necessary if that kind of movement is to take place. I think the changes in the textiles, apparel and footwear industries are classic examples and the decisions we took a year ago are a very good example of how it is possible to free trade, to provide preference for developing countries, and to provide greater access to our market for imports and, at the same time, to do so in a way which has encouraged continuing investment. But the industries know that substantial restructuring is still required and inevitable as a consequence of our decisions.

The other point that ought to be made is that the arguments for a lower level of protection stand in their own right philosophically and on their own logic. People sometimes say that this is a highly protectionist country, more protectionist than any other, and in trying to reinforce that argument do Australia a grave disservice because that wrongly describes the Australian position relative to what is done in many countries of Europe, in Japan and in many cases even in North America. The Australian markets are open and therefore, in the process of arguing for lower levels of protection, there is no need to criticise the access that is already available to the Australian market. I have had prepared recently a lengthy document on this subject. If the honourable member would like a copy of it, I would be very happy to make it available to him. I know that he would understand that I am not casting him in the role of the kind of person I was mentioning in the last part of my answer, one who criticises his own country unjustly in order to make a point that stands on its own logic in any case.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Industrial Relations firstly, whether, at the meeting of the National Labour Consultative Council on Monday, 27 April 1981, he gave an unequivocal undertaking that the review of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act which he had commissioned by Messrs Searby and Taylor would be concerned with technical matters only? Secondly, why did the Minister break that undertaking on Friday of the same week in his discussions with Searby and Taylor, as evidenced by his letter of 8 May, which states:

QUESTION.PARA: I write following the talk I had with you and Mr Taylor on Friday afternoon . . . . . (1 May).
Amongst other things, we discussed three additional particular matters the Government would like you to examine in conjunction with your consultancy to the Department.
The three matters concerned the possible need for legislation as to:
qualifications and accountability of officials of organisations registered under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act;
accelerating the process of securing stand-down orders . . . and complementary legislation between the Commonwealth and a State in cases of de-registration.

Thirdly, what were the relevant events which transpired between then and 29 May causing the Minister to write another letter to Searby withdrawing his formal request initiated on 1 May? Fourthly, when the Minister's action first became known to the parties by public exposure in the media on 23 June, did the Minister receive a telex from the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Dolan, which said in part:
It would indicate that the Government has been deceitful in its relations with the union movement over this matter.
Finally, what assurance can the Minister give this House that any future undertakings given to the NLCC will be honoured by him?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Richard Searby, Q.C., and Mr E. J. Taylor were briefed to undertake a study of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act by my predecessor. The matters to which the honourable member has referred have been discussed within the NLCC. I might also remind the honourable member that the matter was discussed at the Estimates Committee hearing on 8 September. I would refer the honourable gentleman to the transcript of the Estimates Committee hearing of that day. I will have a look at his question. If there is any more that I need to add, I will do so.

—I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to Press and other reports relating to the existence of a substantial cash economy in the home building and home renovation industry and its effect on government tax revenue. Will the proposed sales tax on building materials in any way redress such a loss to the Government? Further, considering the structure of the new tax sharing agreement with the States, what effect would any reduction in sales tax have on future Federal grants to the governments of the States, in particular, Queensland.

—I am aware of the substantial size of the cash economy in Australia. I do not think it applies only to Queensland, but most noticeably throughout Australia and, I think, particularly in the building area. All honourable members would be aware that on some occasions building projects, even small domestic projects, can be much more readily achieved and more speedily accomplished if a cash payment is made rather than a cheque. The extension of the sales tax to this area certainly will bring money to the Government's coffers. On the other hand, I am bound to say that the amount of money that will come in by way of increase in this particular area will not be significant and, therefore, this will not be an important area in relation to the Budget. In relation to tax sharing with the States, that is a matter which the Premiers Conference will rightly take up.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr Howe proceeding to address a question to the Prime Minister-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's question is out of order.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and relates to the Air Safety Investigation Branch report on the Advance Airlines of Australia crash at Mascot. Has the Minister read conclusion 14 of that report which indicates that officers of the Department of Transport were aware of unapproved practices and had not taken action to regularise the company's operations? Will the Minister immediately institute a board of accident inquiry into this episode to remove any lingering doubts about the way in which air safety surveillance reports are conducted in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I do not agree that the Air Safety Investigation Branch report on the Advance Airlines of Australia crash suggests that there was gross incompetence or any dereliction of responsibilities by the Department of Transport for the safe operation of the aircraft which was involved in the crash, I have reconsidered my decision not to institute a board of accident inquiry into this tragic accident. I have given further consideration to the conclusions of the report, particularly conclusion 14 which states:

ANSWER.PARA: Officers of the Department of Transport were aware of the unapproved practices in respect of standard passenger weights and reduced power take-offs, but action had not been taken to regularise the company's operations.

I feel that there is a public interest in this matter that should be resolved by a board of inquiry. The circumstances of the accident were of such tragic consequence to the relatives and friends of those who were lost in the accident that I believe there should be no lingering doubts about the way in which air safety surveillance is conducted in this country. Although the Department of Transport has a record second to none in civil aviation air safety, I believe that if there are doubts in people's minds they should be tested before a board of accident inquiry. As soon as the Government has decided who should conduct this inquiry, I will see that those details are provided to the House.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Communications to the question of the breach of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade arrangements by the Australian Dairy Corporation. If the Minister knew of the breach no later than September 1976, why did it take him until November 1976 to require specific action to be taken? At the meeting of 9 November 1976 with Mr Webster, did he canvass the possibility of continuing the rebate for a period until the ADC credit was exhausted, and did he request or direct Mr Webster to negotiate with Mr Uytengsu accordingly?

—The answer to the last part of the honourable gentleman's question is no. The answer to the first part of the question is that as soon as I was advised that there was a breach of arrangements entered into under GATT, instructions were given to the Chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation that they be terminated forthwith.
—Can the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment advise the House what progress has been made in the certification of films in terms of the recently introduced tax concessions for film makers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The new tax concession legislation came into operation on 24 June this year. Since that date 225 applications have been received for certification as qualifying Australian films. Of this number of applications, 130 certificates have been issued and six applications have been rejected. In the light of the success of the Australian film industry, it may be of interest to honourable members to know that of the 225 films, 107 have been applications in respect of feature films or animated feature films. So far 80 applications have been processed and have received provisional certificates. Applications have been received in respect of 91 documentaries. Forty-one have been processed and have received provisional certificates. Two of seven applications for mini-series of television dramas have received provisional certificates and seven of 14 applications in respect of telemovies have also received certificates. The total budget of the films in respect of which provisional certificates have been granted would, if those films are produced in accordance with their budgets, have amounted to the order of $114m.

ANSWER.PARA: Of the outstanding applications, 59 are currently being processed and 30 are still to be processed. Thirty-three of those are applications that were received in July, 33 were received in August and 23 in September. Honourable members would be aware also that after my predecessor made a statement late last year a large number of applications were received. Of the 91 that were notified prior to 24 June, nine have withdrawn their applications. There are 82 proposals in respect of which we have not had formal applications under the legislation. Since 24 June there have also been a number of other proposals which have been informally notified to my Department, but as yet no formal notification has been received.

These figures show the great strength of the Australian film industry, the initiatives that are being taken and the encouragement that is being given to people to develop worthwhile film proposals. The applications are being processed as quickly as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —The film industry is in a sound position.

—As my colleague behind me has just said, the present position is an illustration of the strength of the film industry. The encouragement that is being given by this Government to the film industry is well demonstrated by the world success of the film Gallipoli.

—I refer to an article in this week's Bulletin. Have the Prime Minister and his Cabinet colleagues deliberately sought to use the Parliament to lessen the standing of the honourable member for Kooyong? That is, was their action, in the words of Mr Alan Reid, 'a political ploy designed to lessen Peacock's standing'?
—The article and its conclusions are absurd.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EFFECTS OF MARITIME STRIKE ON TASMANIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is he aware of the disastrous effects of the maritime strike on the life and economy of Tasmania? If it continues, or if another should occur, will the Government consider, firstly, an attempt to obtain permanent exemption for Tasmania or, secondly, should that fail, will the Government consider the use of the Navy to ensure the flow of essential services to Tasmania?

—Tasmania has always been particularly susceptible to industrial disputes because it is cut off from the rest of Australia. As the honourable gentleman knows, when there has been a suggestion that air links might be broken we have made it quite plain that there is a standing commitment that the Royal Australian Air Force will stand in to prevent an air link from being broken in the case of industrial disputes. The people of Tasmania can know that that is standing policy. Whether it is a sea or air link, we obviously hope that trade unions will provide exemptions for Tasmania, as has often been the case but not always been the case. If sea transport is cut off from Tasmania in a very significant way, we would also have to look at the options that might be open to us, as we already have for air transport.
—It has got very serious now.

—I know but at the same time I understand that there are prospects of that dispute being over within a matter of hours or by tomorrow. If that is not so I know that we will need to look at the circumstances of Tasmania and at what can be done to protect the island.

—I refer the Minister for Administrative Services to the speech of the Minister for Primary Industry recorded in Hansard on 22 September 1981 in which he said that he had requested the Federal Police to investigate the appropriateness of certain expenditure of the former chairman of Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd, Mr Webster, under section 63P of the Audit Act. The Minister said that this request to the Federal Police was made on 13 August 1980 and a report produced two months later on 24 October. The Crown Solicitor was then advised that further police investigations were required and the investigation was again referred to the police on 21 November 1980. Will the Minister tell the Parliament why the first report was able to be produced in two months but was never released; why the second report is not yet available; when Mr Webster or his legal advisers were last interviewed; and whether he expects that the police will lay charges with regard to the first report?

—The police investigation which the honourable member for McMillan asked about was, in fact, completed and referred to the Crown law authorities, I think, on 14 September. The Crown law authorities have now examined the report and have sent it back to the Police Commissioner with their comments. The Police Commissioner is now examining that report and he will be making up his mind what to do about it.

—I ask the Minister representing the Attorney-General a question in relation to the Joint Select Committee on the Family law Act which reported last October. Can he advise the House of any progress that has been made in preparing a response to that report and also when we might anticipate legislation being introduced to give effect to the recommendations?

—I am in a position to provide the honourable gentleman with some information which has been made available to me by my colleague, the Attorney-General. On 11 December last year the Attorney announced that drafting instructions were being prepared for significant amendments to the Family Law Act, the major purpose of which was the implementation of 24 of the Joint Select Committee's recommendations. These are recommendations that can and should be implemented immediately by legislation. They include a number of the more important of them. The instructions have now been given and drafting of a Bill is now proceeding. When the Bill is ready it will be introduced as soon as the Government's program allows. The remaining recommendations require further detailed consideration including, in many instances, consultation between Commonwealth departments and agencies and with State governments. I am advised by my colleague that he hopes to be able to report to the Parliament on progress in the matter next month.

—I refer the Minister for Primary Industry to paragraph 8.17 of the report of the Senate Committee which inquired into the Australian Dairy Corporation and its Asian subsidiaries. Is the Minister aware that in that section of the report the Committee referred to several million dollars paid by the ADC into a bank in Singapore 'significantly over and above the rebate payments'? Is it a fact that neither the Committee nor the Auditor-General has been able to ascertain the eventual whereabouts of that money? Can the Minister say whether he or his Department has made any further investigations in order to locate the money? If there has been no follow-up to find this money, why not? Further, what action has the Minister taken to tighten internal management practices of the ADC to prevent any further malpractices?

—In respect of the last part of the honourable member's question, if he had listened to my speech in the House the other day he would have heard about 12 points I put down in terms of the tightening of procedures on the control of the ADC and Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd and their relationship with the Minister. I refer the honourable member to that speech. The honourable member referred to the payment of money. This is a matter for investigation. It will be part of the statement I will put down consequent upon receiving the police report.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industry. As the Minister will be aware, certain allegations were made by Senator Gerry Jones that meat could have been contaminated by allegedly contaminated water in the Charters Towers area. Is there any truth in these allegations? Would our meat industry have suffered further by this additional example of beef bashing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the statements that were made by the new Australian Labor Party Senator Jones in his maiden speech in the Senate last week. I am advised that the allegations are completely incorrect. The facts are that during the normal summer wet season a small quantity of uranium ore, which was being stockpiled at the Ben Lomond uranium prospecting operation near Charters Towers, developed minor seepage. I am advised that the Queensland Water Quality Council took water samples at the time from the nearby Keelbohorn Creek and the Burdekin River beyond Ben Lomond. Tests have shown that levels of radio activity were much below the safety levels quoted by the National Health and Medical Research Council for drinkable water. In fact, I am advised that the creek water is under continuous monitoring with samples being taken every three weeks in the wet season and every six weeks in the dry season. At no time have any levels of gross alpha or gross beta radio activity been found in the creek water. It is perfectly drinkable.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of the honourable senator's statement a story appeared in a Singapore newspaper following which the Singapore Department of Primary Production sought clarification from the Australian High Commission. Singapore authorities have been advised of the facts and have been reassured. I suppose the only other point to make is that this was a shoddy and completely irresponsible statement for this honourable senator to make. He is either dimwitted or dumb-I am not sure which-and he has certainly done irreparable damage to the reputation of the beef industry. I have to reassure the beef industry of the facts in relation to the matter. It was totally irresponsible of this honourable senator and scandalmongering of the worst type. The best thing he could do would be to go and get another drink at Breakfast Creek.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Prime Minister aware that the French Government has acknowledged, as a result of recent underground nuclear tests at Mururoa Atoll, that it is not safe for people to swim in the surrounding waters? Is he further aware that because of a huge gap one to two feet wide and half a mile long that has been opened in the Atoll below sea level there are serious leaks of radio activity? Does the Prime Minister realise that this gives Australia strong grounds to institute action against France in the International Court of Justice? Accordingly, will the Government institute such action not only to protect Australia's interests but also to protect those of our Pacific Islands neighbours?

—I have not been advised of the matters contained in the honourable gentleman's question. I will ask for a report on the matter and I hope before the end of this day to get advice on the position. I will be in touch with the honourable gentleman as soon as I can be.

—I refer the Minister for Administrative Services to media reports today about the disputes that are said to be arising between the Australian Federal Police and the Transport Workers Union of Australia regarding the transportation of visiting heads of government to the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne next week. Can the Minister assure this House that equal consideration has been given for the security of the civilian population in Melbourne as well as for the visiting heads of states during the CHOGM conference?

—I thank the honourable member for Cook for that question. I am aware of that newspaper report. As a result I am now aware that a letter, quoted in that newspaper report, was sent by a departmental official of the Department of Administrative Services to Mr Hodgson, Secretary of the Transport Workers Union. It would be totally unacceptable to me and to this Government if any driver, whether from the Department of Administrative Services or from the police force, deliberately injured civilians. To ensure that there is absolutely no doubt, either in my Department or the Australian Federal Police, I have issued instructions to the head of the Department of Administrative Services and to the Police Commissioner that, in performing their duties at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting or, in fact, anywhere else, they will give equal protection to the occupants of vehicles and to civilians outside those vehicles. Because of that letter and that report, I have spoken also this morning to the Police Commissioner in Victoria, Mr Miller. Mr Miller agrees entirely with what I have just said and in fact has assured me that that is the position in the Victoria Police. The police and the Administrative Services drivers will protect both the occupants of the vehicles and the people outside them.

—Is the Minister for Defence aware that the Belconnen Naval Radio Station occupies a site which is regarded as prime residential land? Is he aware that it has been the subject of complaints from local residents that it interferes with radio and television reception? Is the relocation of the station under consideration? When might such a decision be taken? How long will it take to put such a decision into effect? Will the Minister give this matter some urgent consideration because his colleague the Minister for the Capital Territory is running short of good quality residential land to sell to private developers as recommended by the Lynch committee report?

—Yes, proposals are under consideration to move the Belconnen station from its present place to another site. For reasons which I am sure my honourable friend will understand, I excuse myself from saying where that site is.
—Why?

—It would increase the respective price of the land. It will take about four years or five years, I am informed before the move will be made, and that fortuitously ties in with prospective improvements in the technology which will be used. Beyond that, there is no further information I can give the honourable gentleman.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is it correct that current industrial disputes have led to a crucial shortage of essential food and medical supplies at the Aboriginal settlement of Angurugu on Groote Eylandt in the Northern Territory? What is the Government doing to help?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a request from the Northern Territory Government. In that request I was advised that there was a threat to the health and the well being of the community at Groote Eylandt which has been cut off completely as a result of the marine engineers' dispute. As a result of that, yesterday the Minister for Defence authorised the use of defence aircraft to carry essential supplies. If other areas in the Northern Territory or close to the Northern Territory are isolated for the same reason, the same facilities will be provided. Again one can say only that this is an example of the way in which some unions pursue industrial disputation without any regard whatsoever for the consequences on Australians wherever they may live.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is worth noting in this instance that the marine engineers' dispute does not, as I understand it, have the general support of the other maritime unions or the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The marine engineers have been causing the difficulty and hardships that the honourable gentleman referred to. They are causing great difficulty, involving great cost right around Australia. In this instance the Government is pleased to act very speedily as the result of the Chief Minister's request.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister for Communications. He will recall that in answer to a question earlier today from the honourable member for Werriwa he declared that, as soon as he learnt on 9 November 1976 of rebate arrangements in relation to skim milk powder breaching our General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade responsibilities, he terminated that practice-or he directed that it be terminated. Is he aware that on sworn testimony before the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, Mr Wallace, a public servant, declared that the Minister was notified during September, some two months earlier? Does he refute the sworn evidence of the public servant? If so does he expect he does so with the same persuasive authority with which he sought to refute the sworn evidence of Mr Webster--
—Order! The honourable gentleman is now arguing a matter. He will direct his question for information.
—The question stands. Why did he not act much earlier?

—I cannot recall the exact dates but, as soon as the information was made available to me, I asked Mr Webster, as chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation, to initiate the necessary steps so that the breach of the arrangement within GATT could be terminated as soon as possible and forthwith.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Communications, concerns the Government's domestic satellite which will be launched in 1985. Is there any truth in the suggestion that those interested groups which will have access to the transponders on the satellite will have sole access to the earth transmitting stations?

—At this stage the Government has not taken any final decision with respect to the ownership and operation of earth stations. Obviously, quite a number of facilities will be available through the use of the transponders in the satellite. In calling tenders, options have been retained so that the satellite company can operate earth stations or, on the other hand, be excluded from them. Obviously there is a requirement for public use of earth stations, including the Homestead and Community Broadcasting Satellite Service, the Australian Broadcasting Commission and so on. In order to facilitate consideration, tenders have been called providing the options. During the processing of the tenders the costs and advantages will be appraised. When recommendations are made to the Government the alternatives will be considered so that the maximum possible advantage to the Australian community ultimately is decided on.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: REPORT OF THE NATIONAL ENERGY ADVISORY COMMITTEE

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy to the recently released report-No. 14-of the National Energy Advisory Committee on Australia's energy resources. Does this report express serious concern that inadequate physical data and economic assessments exist on Australia's energy resources? Does the report also express concern that information collected by companies and States is frequently not available on a nationally co-ordinated and consistent basis? Were similar criticisms made by the National Energy Advisory Committee over three years ago in its initial report on energy resources? In view of these criticisms, what action does the Government intend to take to establish a national information base for the assessment of Australia's energy resources? Given the concerns of the National Energy Advisory Comittee, can the Minister explain why the Government has run down staffing of the Bureau of Mineral Resources?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a question which obviously needs a detailed answer. I will have it referred to the Minister for National Development and Energy.

—Is the Minister for Trade and Resources aware of reports today that the CSR company is engaged in negotiations with Delhi International Oil Corporation to acquire that company's interests in the South Australian gas fields? Can the Minister say whether these reports are correct? Can he also say what the attitude of the Government would be to such a transaction?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the reports and I am aware that the CSR company has been having negotiations with Delhi International Oil Corporation to purchase its holdings in the Cooper Basin and Pedirka Basin areas of central and southern Australia. I certainly hope that these reports are correct and that these negotiations are successful. I believe it would be a wonderful step forward in purchasing back a piece of the Australian farm. The Cooper and Pedirka Basin areas are very important parts of Australia's resources.
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. I just wanted to let the Minister know that CSR wrapped up the deal this morning.
—There is no point of order.

—I thank the honourable member for the information. I think all of us will welcome such action by an Australian company of such high standing and good reputation as far as the development of resources is concerned. I think it overcomes a lot of problems if an Australian company can buy out an overseas company rather than sell out to some other foreign company. This is a great step forward. It shows the capacity and the competence of Australian firms to get in and buy out foreign interests when it is possible.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SALES TAX INCREASES: PRIVATE BUS OPERATORS

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Transport whether it is correct that, as a result of Government Budget policy of increasing existing sales tax and imposing sales taxes on commodities that were previously tax free, private bus operators will now be required to pay 17 1/2 per cent sales tax on motor oil and grease and on the purchase of new buses and parts? Will this impose an additional expense of more than half a million dollars per year on the cost of providing these services? Do these bus operators provide services in country areas and in out of town, newly developing suburbs of the major cities? If so, what will the Government do to give some relief to these operators so that they can continue to provide a service for the people who so badly need it? Is it also a fact that government buses and transport systems do not have to pay these taxes?

—The answer to the first question is yes. The answer to the second question is yes. The answer to the third question is yes. I assume that, as with any form of tax, the private bus operators would absorb that tax within their normal operating costs just as they have to pay rates, rents, company tax or whatever. This adds to the broadening of the base of the tax system of this country. This has been sought by many sensible people in this country for some time. I am certain that it will not result in the curtailment of bus services in the country areas.

—Mr Speaker, I add to the answer that I gave to the honourable member for Fraser. The four or five years that I referred to in my answer would run from the time when work commenced on the new site. It is not possible to give the honourable gentleman a date as to when the new transmitting equipment can be delivered but I will make further inquiry and see whether a date is in prospect.
—When can we expect a decision?
—I am unable to give the honourable gentleman a definite answer on that simply because no delivery date for the transmitting equipment is available to me.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I present, pursuant to statute, the report of the Auditor-General accompanied by the financial statements prepared by the Minister for Finance for the year 1980-81 and upon other accounts.

INTERJECT.PARA: 1. That this House, in accordance with the provisions of the Parliamentary Papers Act 1908, authorises the publication of the report of the Auditor-General for the year 1980-81.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present the Department of Housing and Construction annual report 1980-81 and, pursuant to section 53 of the Homes Savings Grant Act 1976, I present the Homes Savings Grant annual report 1980-81.

DEBATE.TITLE: GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK AUTHORITY

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to section 60 of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Act 1975, I present the annual report of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority 1980-81.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to inform the House that Mr Harold Gibson Weir has ceased to hold the office of Commonwealth Parliamentary Librarian. Mr Weir has been absent from duty since early July this year and on the recommendation of the Commonwealth Medical Officer is currently on sick leave pending retirement. Mr Weir was first recruited to the Commonwealth Public Service in August 1965 when he joined the Department of Labour and National Service. His first appointment to the parliamentary service was in January 1968 when he joined the staff of the Department of the Parliamentary Library to establish the Education and Welfare Group of the Legislative Research Service. Under his direction that group became a highly effective element in the Research Service.

INTERJECT.PARA: In June 1973 Mr Weir left to take up a position with the Australian Institute of Criminology where he was subsequently promoted to Secretary of the Institute. He returned to the Parliamentary Library in August 1976 as Assistant Parliamentary Librarian and was appointed Parliamentary Librarian in 1978. In that capacity he worked strenuously to ensure that all parliamentarians received prompt and impartial service. Under his administration the Department of the Parliamentary Library underwent change and development to a degree probably not known since the inception of the Legislative Research Service in the mid-1960s.

During his time as Parliamentary Librarian the resources of the Library have greatly increased and there are better career opportunities for staff than ever before. Technical advances have been very considerable and at the national and international level the Department is recognised as one of the best of its kind. I greatly regret that ill health has caused his early retirement and I wish to pay tribute to his most valuable contribution to the working of the Parliament. It is true that during his period as Librarian the Library continued its course of transformation from what one might call a library in the strict sense into an intellectual resource centre for members of parliament. I wish Mr Weir and his wife a long and happy retirement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on behalf of the Government I join in the remarks you made and to pay tribute to the service rendered by Mr Harold Weir as Parliamentary Librarian and share with you a regret that ill health has caused his premature retirement. Members of this place have been extraordinarily fortunate over the years to have had men of very considerable distinction filling the office of Commonwealth Parliamentary Librarian. Sir Harold White and Mr Allan Fleming, to name but two, have set standards of administration within the Library which have enabled all members to benefit from the very wide range of resource material that is so essential to the proper functioning of this place. Therefore, Mr Speaker, on behalf of members of the Government parties, I join with you in wishing Mr and Mrs Weir a long and happy retirement and in wishing Mr Weir a recovery from the present medical problems that have led to his premature retirement.

—Mr Speaker, I want to endorse the words uttered by you and by the Leader of the House (Mr Sinclair). It is always a matter of regret when officers are forced to retire through ill health. The Opposition certainly joins in wishing Mr and Mrs Weir a long and happy retirement, and we certainly note the enormous change in the Parliamentary Library in the period of Mr Weir's librarianship.
