We hope, subject to the approval of Treasury, that that will continue in the next few years under your speakership and under the leadership also of the new President of the Senate. We wish Mr Weir well in his retirement.
—This is hardly the time to say it, but I point out to the honourable member for Lalor that the development of the Library will not be subject to the indulgence of Treasury.

—I would like to pay tribute to Mr Weir for the services he has given to the Parliament, particularly the back bench on both sides of the Parliament, and to register my appreciation of the assistance he gave me during my period of service on the Library Committee. It is true that Mr Weir was the principal Parliamentary Librarian during a period of change and development in the role of the Library and of the Library Committee. Like the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), I express the hope that we will see continued reform and developments and that we will come to the stage when the Library Committee itself will be independent and will be responsible to the Parliament. I wish Mr Weir and his wife the very best in their retirement. May it be a long, happy and healthy period.
—I thank the House for the tributes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Child Mrs J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Commonwealth housing grants to the States have had a pretty good airing in this House in recent times. However, I make no apology for raising the question again as there are few matters which so directly affect the welfare and security of so many people. During the last few weeks, we have witnessed the unedifying spectacle of the conservative Minister for Housing in this Government (Mr McVeigh) and the conservative Minister for Housing in the Victorian Government trading vitriolic abuse. Both have been frantically trying to duck-shove responsibility for the tragic decline in public housing in Victoria. Mr Kennett described the Budget allocation to public housing as 'an absolute disgrace' and accused the Federal Minister of deliberately misleading the public. The Federal Minister, for his part, accused Mr Kennett of 'arrogance and ignorance' and questioned his common sense, his compassion and his sincerity. The odd thing is that, despite their positions being poles apart, both of them are right. This Government has applied a continual squeeze on finance for public housing. This Government has callously abandoned thousands of families who find great difficulty in paying the inflated prices charged for private accommodation.

SPEECH.PARA: Taking into account repayments of capital and interest, the States received a total figure of only $17.7m in this Budget-a decline of $45m from 1980-81. The further back one goes, the more dramatic the decline becomes. In the last full year of the Labor Government, 1974-75, the States received almost eight times the amount, in real terms, that they will receive in the current financial year. Home ownership in Victoria has begun to decline rapidly. Mr Kennett is corrrect when he states that the Federal Government seems to have abandoned the Liberal Party's stated philosophy of support for home ownership. In reality, of course, all that this Government is doing is implementing the Liberal Party's unstated philosophy of 'grab what you can and the devil take the hindmost'.

Now let me turn to Mr Kennett, a most unlikely fellow to be posing as the sword-bearer for the under-privileged in our community. Victorian members will know Mr Kennett better as an immature politician with a right-wing philosophy so extreme that it was a severe embarassment to his Liberal Party colleagues. His appointment to the Ministry came as something of a surprise. I think one could have got a shorter price about the Ayatollah Khomeini becoming Pope. His career as a Minister has, to date, been concerned mainly with attempts at self promotion. In that respect, the Federal Minister's description of him as 'a political pup baying at the moon' is fairly near the mark. Certainly, Mr Kennett and his Liberal colleagues in Victoria have little to be proud of in their housing record. Given all the rhetoric we have heard from Mr Kennett, the Minister for Housing in the conservative Government in Victoria, it comes as quite a shock to find that his Government failed to spend $16m of money allocated to it for welfare housing in 1980-81. One wonders what Mr Kennett is on about, if not just playing politics, when at the same time as underspending Victoria's allocation for welfare housing, he attacks his colleagues in his own party in Canberra for cutting this year's money.

As one who is always seeking low cost housing for constituents and who is continually being told by the Victorian Housing Commission that no emergency housing is available, I believe that Mr Kennett stands condemned for failing to spend Victoria's full allocation. These are fine words from Mr Kennett, but no action. He and his Government stand condemned for their failure to meet their obligations in the area of welfare housing and for failing to recognise that a home is vital to a family's security. One wonders what this Government has against the family. In the words of Mrs Rhonda Galbally of the Victorian Council of Social Service, there has been a real increase of only 1.5 per cent in spending on housing in the Victorian Budget at a time when families in Victoria are breaking up because of the pressure from cutbacks in health, housing and education, not to mention the State gas and electricity increases. It is also a savage indictment of both conservative governments that the Victorian Government has had to set up a $1m pool to bail out families in danger of losing their homes through the savage interest rate increases.

A recent study conducted by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's division of building research found that only about half of Australia's families can now afford to buy a house. It now takes, on average, four years' pay for the average family to buy a home. The study said that the equivalent time before World War I, was about 18 months. No progress has been made in the last 50-odd years. Many people in the housing industry are now thoroughly alarmed by the decline in the industry. The Real Estate Institute of Australia said in a statement dated 25 August that the home ownership rate is falling and will continue to fall because too little finance is available for housing. The Institute went on to predict that the recent Federal Budget would have the short term effect of making home ownership even more difficult. Mr Kirkby-Jones, the National Executive Director of the Housing Industry Association, was a good deal more blunt in his Press statement of 19 August 1981. He said:

The Budget contains no relief for potential first time home buyers or for families experiencing financial hardship with greatly increased mortgage repayment burdens. The absence of even a token interest subsidy scheme shows the Government's insensitivity for thousands of Australian families who have been forced out of the market place by the current record level of interest rates.
Further on in his statement Mr Kirkby-Jones said that the Government will not heed industry advice and will not act to restore home ownership opportunities. He added:

The demand for new housing is strengthening as a result of considerable growth in nett immigration to around 120,000 and increasing family formation. In such a wealthy country, access to decent, safe and affordable housing should be the right of all citizens. The failure on the part of Governments to respond to the Housing aspirations of ordinary Australians will no doubt invite a serious political backlash.

Concern was also expressed by the Federation of Terminating Housing Societies of Victoria. The Federation's Executive Director, Mr Cameron Algie, was reported in the Melbourne Sun of 17 August as forecasting a social emergency due to the latest interest rate increases. Mr Algie said that hundreds of home buyers would face eviction because they could not afford to pay the new interest rates. That is already happening in Victoria and in other States. He predicted the creation of a new class of poor, and pointed out that even a modest home loan of $25,000 would need an income of at least $260 a week to service it. The Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies has also expressed alarm at current trends. The Association's Executive Director, Mr Larkey, was reported in the Australian of 16 July as saying that home finance would tighten even more unless the pressure for funds was eased. Mr Larkey went so far as to question the seriousness of this Government's commitment to home ownership.

The list of people involved in the industry who are deeply worried about the Government's priorities seems endless. Many builders in my electorate have also contacted me, including my son. They are worried about both the short and the long term prospects facing them. Once upon a time it was said that full employment and home ownership were the two most basic credos of any Australian Government. It was thought inconceivable that any government would dream of abandoning either. Under this Government history is well and truly being made. The full employment ideal has been thrown out the window and it seems clear that home ownership is now to follow it. Both have fallen victim to ideological obsessions. Both have fallen victim to an alien philosophy which ruthlessly sweeps aside even the most basic aspirations of the Australian family. It will be to the everlasting discredit of both Ministers if they allow their squabbbling and name calling to prevent them from carrying out their duty to work together in the interests of the community. If their responsibilities of office provide insufficient motivation, they would both do well to ponder the words of Mr Kirkby-Jones: 'The failure on the part of governments to respond to the housing aspirations of ordinary Australians will no doubt invite a serious political backlash'.

In the few minutes left to me I make the comment that the Government is now adjusting supplementary rental assistance in a way which discriminates against poorer pensioners and benefits pensioners paying higher rents to private landlords. In a complicated formula, it will refuse help in meeting rent costs to needy pensioners who are renting from State housing authorities. Under the new means test a pensioner paying $26 a week in the private sector will get $8 a week supplementary assistance, while a pensioner paying $26 a week for a housing commission home will get nothing. Previously both would have been paid $5 a week towards the rent. There is no connection, as the Government seems to imply, between capital grants used in building public housing and the present ability of a pensioner to pay rent. It is an unfair practice to give supplementary assistance to one set of housing authority tenants while denying it to others in the same block of units paying the same amount of rent. Supplementary assistance has been available to only 400,000 of the poorest pensioners. If the Government had indexed this payment, which has not been increased since 1974, it would now be worth $10 a week. Instead, the Department of Social Security has taken the cheap way out; it is confining its payments to tenants in private housing. The landlords will raise the rent, and they are the ones who will make higher profits out of the extra money that is being put into supplementary rental. The money being provided by the Government will not build any more housing, it will not help any public housing tenants--

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to express my concern this morning that only 4 per cent of Australians own equity in Australian companies in their own right. Our nation's growth will undoubtedly continue to require a substantial investment of capital. This will come from either overseas or local sources. Those who complain about overseas investment would do well to consider the need to improve the ability and the willingness of Australia's own people to make investments in this nation's future. They must be prepared to take the risks as well as to share the benefits of our nation's prosperity. According to the Reserve Bank of Australia, households, including unincorporated enterprises, divested themselves of some $1,800m in equity in the three years to June 1980. Over the last 10 years the household sector has also been a net divestor in its own right in ordinary and preference shares. I seek leave to incorporate statistical tables demonstrating this point.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fortunately major Australian companies and particularly the insurance industry have been in the forefront of Australia's capital accumulation and investment in recent years. This has been mainly through selling superannuation and life insurance policies. Unfortunately, it is by no means clear that those who make those investments-some 42 per cent of the work force-do so with the clear intention of owning a share in their nation's development. This is, therefore, the essence of the problem which has been faced by my colleague Mr John Moore, the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, and myself. Our solution to this difficulty rests upon the need to develop a concept known as Trust Australia. This concept is basically a new financial philosophy. We believe that the individual must have the right to sell capital-as well as labour-in the capital markets of the nation at the going market price. Unfortunately we regret that at present access to the market for all Australians remains limited and is by no means equal.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of reasons why this is the case. Firstly, there is a fundamental lack of knowledge and information on how the financial markets work. Secondly, there is a lack of shop front facilities, especially in large communities such as Liverpool in the metropolitan area of Sydney; an area, incidentally, which has a population of over a million people and the largest family consumer income in the Commonwealth. Yet these people have little access to the stock market at present. Thirdly, the cost structure related to equity investments adds considerably to the difficulties of the individual. I hope that the Industries Assistance Commission investigation of the stock market will identify and provide some solutions to these problems, not least of which is the difficulty of high commission rates, high stamp duty and high registration and transfer costs, especially on script. If Trust Australia is to be developed it must be accepted by the Australian people that the Government has a role to help create the conditions, climate and opportunities for all our citizens if they wish to play a more direct role in financing Australia's development. However, no Government can act alone. We need the support of the entire finance industry, especially the stock exchanges and finance institutions.

Four specific groups in the community can be identified as representing potential investors. The first group is those who are already involved, the 4 per cent I spoke of before. There is a case for encouraging them to make larger investments in Australia's development. The stock market has suggested that to encourage them the simple solution is to lift double taxation on dividends. On the surface that has a very real attraction. However, one must ask whether the cost to revenue would equate with the advantages to be gained or would we tend to merely assist the large investor at the expense of those who had no equity. The second alternative is the establishment of a national trust to be called Trust Australia or to permit a range of trusts, all financed by the private sector-I emphasise that they should not be controlled or established by the Government-to work within the legislative umbrella of Trust Australia. An Act of the Parliament would establish the guidelines under which organisations could act to attract capital investment and receive a form of taxation deductability for the individual investor. Trusts, operated by the private sector within this context, would have the capacity to draw on the saving power of the vast majority of the Australian people, most of whom at present have no access to the finance market to the extent that we consider necessary.

The French experience in this area is particularly worthy of consideration. In 1976 the Assembly passed legislation called the Monory Act. In the first four years of its activity about 850,000 additional Frenchmen participated in national capital formation, half of whom were new investors. Of these, some 750,000 chose to invest through specialised mutual funds. The capital raised by French companies rose from 1.5 billion francs, or $2.7 billion, in 1977 to 4.56 billion francs, or $A8.7 billion, in 1978. That was a growth of over 300 per cent in such a short period. This demonstrates so clearly that provided we are prepared to give people the encouragement they will come forward and make investments in Australia's future.

The third consideration is the mobilisation of funds from specialised groups. This relates to the difficulties of pensioners. At present means test anomalies and the attitudes of pensioners towards fringe benefit entitlements remain a major disincentive to major investment from that section of the community. Many pensioners have significant capital at their disposal which is not being utilised in the national interest. There are literally boxes under the beds and non-interest bearing deposits. They have been the subject of comment in this House in recent weeks. Surely pensioners, as well as the citizens of all other age groups, have a right to feel that regardless of age or infirmity they too can make a tangible individual contribution to the development of their nation? To achieve this, therefore, serious consideration must be given, within the Trust Australia framework, to enabling them to make investments which will be tax deductible up to $1,500 and the income not necessarily count against access to fringe benefits as they do at present. Another possibility that needs to be considered is whether there is a case for selling to pensioners, if they do not qualify, the right of access to fringe benefits.

The fourth matter that needs to be examined is worker participation. There is undoubtedly an important link between the success and profitability of companies and employees' own livelihoods and prosperity. There are potential gains in employee morale, reduced labour turnover, higher job satisfaction and, possibly, better industrial relations from the development of programs for worker participation based on the provision of shareholdings for individuals within companies. This can be achieved either by large companies offering shares to their employees, or by enabling small businesses, which are the major employers of the Australian population, to encourage their employees to enter into equity investments such as Trust Australia.

Those companies which have in recent years entered into worker participation programs have demonstrated quite conclusively that their profitability, progress, level of industrial relations and so forth have significantly improved as a result. This is an area which deserves the most careful consideration by government. It is worth while noting that a recent survey of major companies shows that 19.4 per cent have some arrangements for employee share participation while another 24.8 per cent are actively considering this matter.

The questions I have raised this morning I believe are of fundamental importance to the development of a young and a vital nation in which every Australian must have the opportunity to share, in a direct way, the risks as well as the benefits of nation building. It is not satisfactory that some 75 per cent of all equity capital in 50 of Australia's leading companies should be provided by a handful of institutions. The existing restraints on market freedoms must be removed to ensure that the individual has the right to invest in Australian equities and be a true shareholder in the prosperity of this nation. It is time for Australians to be prepared and encouraged to invest in their country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance this morning concerns an unfortunate saga which began some 12 years ago when a man of my intimate acquaintance, Sergeant Christopher Jones, who is the secretary-manager of the Parramatta Police Citizens Boys Club was involved in a traffic accident, while driving a police car, with a man whom I do not intend to dignify by naming. That man has carried out a continual vendetta against Sergeant Jones since that date 12 years ago alleging police suppression. The charges, in fact, have been investigated by two coronial inquiries instigated by the New South Wales Government. In both cases, Sergeant Jones was cleared of all charges. In the last case the man making the charges was branded as a very unreliable witness whose obsession with police suppression led to his evidence being of no use whatsoever.

SPEECH.PARA: While that is bad enough in itself-that a man of high repute could be subjected to this sort of charge-my real grievance concerns an irresponsible use of parliamentary privilege in the New South Wales Parliament. I am pleased to see that the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) is at the table because he and I have discussed this matter of parliamentary privilege before. I am sure that we share equal views about the right of all parliamentarians to use parliamentary privilege. It is a privilege, but it is one which should be used with an enormous amount of responsibility, with sensitivity and discretion. I am pleased to say that since I came to this Parliament four years ago, to my knowledge, I do not think anybody has used parliamentary privilege in any way other than that. I cannot ever remember in my experience here any sort of unmitigated attack being made on a person outside this House.

On 5 March 1981, which, to my mind, was a day of infamy in the New South Wales Upper House, a Dr Derek Freeman, a member of the New South Wales Parliament, did his number upon Sergeant Christopher Jones. I would describe what he did as probably the worst attack that I have ever heard made on any person. It was a vicious, unmitigated assault upon a man of the highest integrity and of the most excellent human qualities. It was not a matter of exaggeration or distortion of facts; it was a vicious assault, a farrago of unmitigated, unsubstantiated and unwarranted lies. He accused Sergeant Jones, among other things, of embezzling $200,000 from the Parramatta Police Citizens Boys Club, of residing in a house that was the prize of an art union conducted by the Parramatta Police Citizens Boys Club and many other associated matters.

The damage to the character and the reputation of Sergeant Jones, his wife and young family is incalculable. The second aspect of those charges made by Dr Freeman in the Upper House on that day was the way in which they were picked by the unprincipled Press of Sydney. I have here, sir-and I hold it up for you to observe-the headline on the front page of the Daily Mirror which states:
Policeman named $200,000 missing-MP
The Sunday Telegraph states:
Angry cop denies police boys' swindle.
That was on page 5. It is a very prominent article. Page 2 of the Sun Herald of 8 March 1981 states:
12-year feud-chance of a probe

Those blazing headlines destroy the character of a very decent man who, in his 12 years in Parramatta, has become a legend almost in his own lunch time. He is a man who devoted his life to the good of hundreds of people who go to the Police Boys' Club for all sorts of training including character training and physical training and all the associated benefits that come from the police boys' movement.

A couple of other things that they do at that Police Boys' Club are worth a mention. In the last 12 months Sergeant Jones, through a couple of his associates on the board of the Police Boys' Club, of which I am a director, I might add, have managed to place 300 young people in employment. These were kids who could not get jobs. Sergeant Jones has done a great amount of work in that area in terms of breaking down barriers between delinquent children and their parents, getting kids to go to school by giving them a new sense of responsibiltity and involving himself in the drug problem which occurs in most suburbs of the size of Parramatta. In fact to my knowledge he physically removed a couple of drug dealers from the area. The amount of good that that man has done for the young people of Parramatta is just inestimable.

For the Press to pick up these unwarranted charges and highlight them, as it did with sensational headlines, to me was like jackals baying at the moon, taking up this chorus of vilification that was orchestrated by Dr Freeman in the upper House. A couple of weeks later, after all these charges were investigated by the internal affairs department of the New South Wales Police Department, after Sergeant Jones was the subject of investigation by the Taxation Office and after Mr Wran instituted his own inquiry into all these charges, a complete and utter denial of every charge was made by Mr Wran in the Parliament of New South Wales. Every one of them was found to be unwarranted and unfair. The day Mr Wran made those denials in the Parliament, the gentleman who instituted them-not Dr Freeman but the man involved in the accident 12 years earlier-was ejected from the New South Wales Parliament for his unruly behaviour in the gallery.

The worst part of the whole deal was this: Although the Press made these sensational charges with headlines, smearings and innuendoes all over the front pages of its papers, when the charges were found to be absolutely groundless, the denials were a long time coming. The only denial I saw was on about page 20 of the Sydney Morning Herald where it sought to give a meagre denial of about three or four lines. That was the only item that countered the sensational headlines produced some months before.

The effect of this matter on Sergeant Jones's life has been profound. He was a man of outstanding record in the New South Wales Police. He had been decorated for valour and also for good conduct. He was well on the way to becoming a man of higher station than the sergeant who was the secretary/superintendent of the Parramatta Police Citizens Boys' Club. The effect on his health of this continuing vendetta conducted against him has been so profound that he has been invalided out of the New South Wales Police Force on medical grounds. The damage to his family is also profound. His children have had to suffer the slings and arrows of outrageous fortune, if I may use that term, with all the sorts of cruelties that children can heap on their school friends, perhaps not with any evil intent but just in the manner of school children.

Sergeant Jones now finds himself outside the police force because of these charges which have been made against him in an irresponsible and vicious way. But the big loser is the Police Boys Club in Parramatta and the young people who belong to that organisation because they have lost not only a man who organised their club for them and made it a great success-one of the most successful of such clubs in New South Wales-but also a great friend and a man to whom they turned for counsel, advice and leadership. I think that that is the great measure of the crime that has been committed, not only by the gentleman who has been conducting this vendetta for 12 years, but also by this man in the Upper House of New South Wales who sought to sully the unfettered right that all parliamentarians have to come into parliament and make charges, grounded on fact, against people who do not have the opportunity to answer. I hope that somewhere along the line some parliament in Australia will have a look at the libel laws, the defamation laws, and arrive at some method of penalising or disciplining members of parliament who do not respect the great privilege that they are given in terms of parliamentary privilege and who use it, as this man did, to launch a vicious attack upon a very decent human being.

It is a sad day for Parramatta that we have lost the services of Sergeant Jones. I believe that he is shifting to another State to start a new life. I wish both he and his family luck in that new life. In closing, I reiterate my firm criticism of Dr Derek Freeman. I hope that his own conscience will prick him to get up in the New South Wales Parliament and make some sort of retraction.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In coming weeks, the Government is to announce the much awaited review of Australia's international aviation policy. Already there have been discussions with the States as to what form the new review will take and who will undertake that review. The decisions that will be made by means of this review are certainly vital to the Australian travelling public and, indeed, to the future inflow of visitors to this country. My purpose in rising today is to ask the Government to open this inquiry so that it can be as wide and as far-reaching as possible and to plead that the inquiry not be enclosed within the Department of Transport but will, for the first time, give priority to the industry, tourist concerns and other interested bodies so that they have a real chance to take advantage of it to make sure that Australia is not disadvantaged by an inverted closed shop operation. I am afraid that we have already seen evidence of what can happen by virtue of the International Civil Aviation Policy which was wreaked on Australia a few years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has been prepared to look at the question of deregulation for our domestic operations. I believe that this should be pressed until we can get some sanity prevailing on the international front as well as the domestic front in the coming years. The same attitude must surely be very clearly examined in light of our future international policy, even at a time when it is claimed that international traffic is on the decline. All State Governments have given an indication that they are not happy with the present policies regarding our international traffic, even though there has been a little loosening of the regulations on fare policies in recent months. The travel industry has indicated that it is not happy either and now we really do have a chance to rectify this situation.

Although there has been a decline on some routes in international aviation traffic and some of the big names of international aviation are in serious loss situations, I do not believe that this is a reason to close up the shop to competition for Australia. Rather, we should go out and fight harder in that international market place. It is interesting to note that while some of the traditional international airlines, such as Pan American and British Airways, are reporting record losses, the airlines which are prepared to take the situation head on overseas are doing exceptionally well. The protectionist pundits-we have them in Australia, including in the Department of Transport-would have us believe that deregulation in the United States of America has wreaked havoc in the industry there. There have been massive changes in the nature of the operations in the United States. It is true that some traditional airlines have been forced out of routes they should never have been on in the first place. New airlines have emerged, route structures have changed, airlines have amalgamated, and the only ones, apart from the profitable airlines, to have benefited are the fare paying passengers and the allied tourist industries.

Let me give honourable members an example of that. Los Angeles to New York for $176 with no restrictions is a most reasonable fare. It is a similar flight to the Sydney to Perth sector. On the international front, the United States to Europe fares vary between $400 and $800 return-a seven-hour trip each way or 11 to 12 hours from Los Angeles and San Francisco to Europe. Since these markets have opened up, there have been most substantial increases in traffic-29 per cent per year, for example, on the New York to London route; 60 per cent on the London to Los Angeles route. This, is new traffic; traffic that was generated by the free market forces; traffic that would not have travelled previously without these incentives, even though fares there previously were much more reasonable than many of those operating into and out of Australia at the moment. The efficient airlines operating these services are indeed profitable. We hear about the tremendous opposition our own carrier faces in operating into and out of Australia. Twenty-six airlines, it is said, compete every day. But on the North Atlantic run from New York to Europe there are no fewer than 42 carriers operating into London alone. The figures I am quoting here are not mine but those of the United States Department of Transportation and the British Civil Aviation Authority, along with International Air Transport Association traffic reports.

It could be said, of course, that London, New York and Los Angeles traffic could not be compared with traffic into and out of Australia, and there may be some arguement there. Perhaps we should examine a more comparable market, one more in line with Australian conditions-for example, the United Kingdom to Miami, Florida market. In 1979, 272,508 passengers travelled from the United Kingdom to Miami. In 1980, the market was opened up to competition and in the first full year of operation 594,393 passengers were carried by five airlines rather than two, an increase of 118.1 per cent in that 12-month period. That again was new traffic with all airlines being profitable and the Miami tourist industry booming like it never had before. In 1979, the total British traffic to Australia was 288,278-an increase on the previous year of about 90,000 passengers, but certainly not nearly the spectacular growth on some of those other routes opened up by the free market forces. Two airlines in Britain have already approached the authorities there for rights to Australia with fares of about $900 return. It is interesting to note that the price being quoted by, say, British Airways for operations in the free market on the London to Miami route is about 3c per mile per passenger, but on the restrictive form of airfares operating from London to Australia at the moment the cost per passenger mile is 6c-twice as much. But there again, British Airways, which has just announced a massive $240m loss for the past year, admits that the kangaroo route is the backbone of its operations and that without it British Airways would collapse. The question we should ask is: Are Australian passengers and visitors to this country in fact subsidising this inefficient, bureaucratic British aviation monster? Unfortunately, the rip off would appear to go on. On the other hand, predictions on the growth of United Kingdom to Australia traffic should the free market forces be allowed to operate indicate most conservatively indeed that an increase of 30 per cent per year would be expected compared with the growth of 3 per cent in 1979-80 and 10 per cent in 1980-81 and the expected growth of 10 per cent this year. That sort of market stimulation would increase traffic to Australia from the United Kingdom by 160,000 passengers on the kangaroo route alone. The catch cry of 'Open Our Skies-Tourists Create Jobs' is well known in Australia. While not advocating full open skies, it is obvious, I would think to the meanest intelligence, that a loosening of the system could do marvels to the economy and to the employment situation.

In answer to a question on notice No. 2824 printed in Hansard of Tuesday of this week, we had an indication of the type of thinking which pervades those who control our international civil aviation. I asked in that question whether Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd had applied for rights from Hong Kong to Brisbane and, if so, why that application was rejected earlier this year. The answer was that such an application had been made but that the present level of traffic was not considered sufficient to justify such a service. The only question I would like to ask is: Who said so? The other gem from the Department of Transport is the vexed question of Japan to Australia fares. This has taken years to resolve and now an advance purchase fare is in place. The usual restrictions apply-a minimum stay of 21 days is required. But of course the Japanese get only two weeks holiday a year and usually take a seven to 10 day package tour. Can the Japanese tourist boom really exist for Australia under these conditions?

There are anomalies in Australian international aviation policies. Splits are appearing in some of the more ridiculous structures. Admittedly, there have been some improvements, but we are still a long way from topping up our true potential. There must be a freer regime than presently exists. There must be proration of fares to allow a greater flexibility for our international passengers to travel around Australia. There is a very great argument to allow the domestic airlines to operate regional routes. There can also be the possibility of a common market between Australia, New Zealand and the Pacific Islands so that we can all benefit from tourism. What a wonderful boost for the Pacific island nations that would be in aid terms.

The international market is tougher than it has been for years but we cannot afford to let go the gains that we have made during the past few years because of our protectionist policy. We have the infrastructure ready to be used. This year we have a world market of 400 million international travellers to draw from. People want to come to Australia. They should not be burdened by distance or high air fares. As we always repeat in this House: For every extra 25,000 international visitors coming into Australia another 1,400 jobs are created. If we could have just half of one per cent of that international travel coming into Australia our employment problems would be virtually solved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett Dr N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak in grievance this morning in support of that anti-Cabinet coalition which has been aroused in support of the Community Youth Support Scheme. I recognise that that is now a bipartisan coalition-it includes the Australian Labor Party, the Australian Democrats and many of the back benchers of the Liberal Party. All of those groups are now gathered together against perhaps the increasing minority-even of the Cabinet-in an effort either to retain the Community Youth Support Scheme or at least to have a scheme which plays many of the roles and performs many of the functions of that scheme. In defence of the CYSS project I think it is important that we do not exaggerate the virtues of CYSS. It is, I think, important to recognise its weaknesses as well as its strengths.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, like every other response of the Fraser Government to unemployment, CYSS is a band-aid rather than a cure. In a society as deeply injured by unemployment as this society, particularly by youth unemployment, even band-aids are better than nothing. It is true that CYSS does not provide work. It does not create jobs, unlike some similar community-based schemes that I have seen overseas, particularly in Canada. The guidelines of CYSS have been unnecessarily restrictive and we have complained of this before. They prevent job creating activities. They prevent the production of goods for sale as is done under one of the Canadian schemes of this type. The guidelines are also restrictive on job search and placement. But none of these weaknesses in the scheme are justifications for ending it. All of them are simply arguments for improving the Community Youth Support Scheme.

On the other hand, CYSS has distinct advantages. First of all, it is the only one of the Government's schemes to emphasise the supportive role for the young unemployed, a role in order to sustain morale and confidence and to give young people out of work a sense of personal worth against the undermining effects of unemployment. Indeed, all the evidence suggests that CYSS gets at the most vulnerable and the most disadvantaged, groups amongst the young unemployed. The honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) quoted one young person who said to him: 'Where do you go when you have nowhere to go?' One of the places to which they can go are the Community Youth Support Scheme projects scattered around this country. One great advantage of CYSS, unlike any of the other schemes, is this whole support role for community youth support schemes.

The second, and I think equally great advantage of CYSS, is that it is the only one of the Government's schemes to involve the community generally and directly in the experience of youth unemployment. This community involvement is very valuable for the young but it is as valuable for the community members involved. Unfortunately, the nature and distribution of youth unemployment in this society enables many of the well-off and affluent to avoid the problem altogether, to avoid in fact the greatest social evil at present in this society. The Community Youth Support Scheme tends to break down this distinction by bringing many community members who previously had no serious experience of unemployment to a realisation, through their support work in CYSS, of the nature of the problem that this society is facing. I believe CYSS clearly benefits not only the young unemployed but also, the community in helping to bring home very clearly to many members of that community the problems of youth unemployment in this society.

We can list very obviously and very clearly the achievements of the Community Youth Support Scheme. Something like 130,000 young people have been assisted in the five years in which the scheme has been operating. At the present time some 274 projects are operating around Australia, which are doomed on 31 October. Today in South Australia, my State, there are 26 CYSS projects-18 in the metropolitan areas and eight country projects-with something like 5,000 participants. In my electorate, which is one of the most severely hit by youth unemployment, we have some five projects-all are invaluable in shoring up youth morale. It is true that I share one of those five projects with the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson). I hope that he is actively working to see whether we can maintain the schemes in that area. These five schemes are all invaluable in shoring up youthful morale and compelling the community to face up to the problem of youth unemployment.

These schemes have been evaluated. Evaluations have pointed out the particular role that CYSS contributes to the problem we face. An evaluation was conducted by the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs in August 1977. It found, firstly, that CYSS had provided considerable gains for participants in terms of personal and social development, confidence, morale and motivation. In many cases CYSS played the role of getting these people ready to go into the training schemes that were then provided. Many of the young people who came into CYSS are disenchanted by the whole school process and by the training process, and CYSS acts in many ways as a stepping place into the sorts of job training schemes that have been advocated. If CYSS were not there we would not get many of these young people into further job training opportunities.

Secondly, a majority of CYSS participants came from underprivileged areas and many had severe social problems. We must recognise that unemployment is not just a problem of getting jobs; it is all the social and psychological problems that flow from the lack of a job, particularly for people in underprivileged areas without very many back-up resources. It was discovered in this evaluation that most of the participants in CYSS had been unemployed for longer periods than the average unemployed young person registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service. A more recent survey in 1980 through the University of Melbourne and the Swinburne Institute of Technology showed that participation in CYSS had reduced the incidence of anti-social activity, especially crime, amongst the unemployed youth involved and that CYSS participation had improved the self-reliance, confidence and self-esteem of those involved due largely to the supportive social framework provided at the projects. There is evaluative evidence of the contribution these projects have made to these groups. Yet all of this is to be ended when youth unemployment is as high as ever.

At least 120,000 young people at the moment are unemployed in this country. Something like 15 per cent of all teenagers outside educational institutions are unemployed. In my electorate the figure is 30 per cent for those outside educational institutions in the 15 years to 19 years age category. The average duration of teenage unemployment, that is, the long term unemployed which these schemes have been particularly getting at, has been growing. The average teenage unemployment duration is now 25 weeks in this country. For the somewhat older participants in CYSS, that is, the 20 to 24 year old group, the average duration of unemployment is now 35 weeks. There is no real promise that in the next year those figures can be seriously eroded.

It is argued by the Government that it will direct CYSS resources and money to better schemes providing training for jobs. I am afraid that that is mostly cosmetic poppycock. There is not much point in starting with training people for jobs which are unavailable. In fact, we can build up whole problems of resentment. In South Australia, if all the job training programs in the Budget got under way, they would provide only 1,000 places whereas at the moment 5,000 people are involved in the CYSS projects. Again, CYSS gives invaluable support from the first day of unemployment. From the very moment a young person is unemployed he can go and make full use of CYSS facilities. Yet nearly all the other training schemes usually require a waiting period, sometimes up to several months, before people can move into them. Of course, none of the training schemes talked about provide the supportive role that CYSS provides. It may be that some support is provided, but that is secondary to the whole job training process, whereas the role of CYSS is to put the supportive process at the very forefront of activity. As I said, I am glad that there is a widespread coalition which is quite bipartisan moving against this decision. We all should realise that we are creating in this society a generation of the unemployed and unemployable. Unless we bring all the resources of this society to bear on this problem to relieve its human and social repercussions, that generation will in future wreak great havoc on this society as it moves through it. CYSS is one of the ways in which we can cope with that massive social problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Groom The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say at the outset that I agree with many of the points made by the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) in his comments on the Community Youth Support Scheme. I think there will be some kind of vacuum when CYSS ceases to operate, and I hope that somehow the Government can find a way of filling that vacuum. It is a very important issue for the young people directly involved.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I want to comment on a subject that I think is very important, especially for the functioning of this House and of the Senate. It concerns the fundamental difference between the executive arm of government and the role to be played by ordinary private members of this House and of the Senate and the dangers that I see in any further extension of the power and the influence of the executive arm of government over the role of ordinary members of this House and of the Senate. Parliaments were created to ensure that the interests of the members of the general community and their views are taken into account when governments determine their policies and the actions that they take as governments.

Absolutely essential to our role is the real independence of the private member. If he is controlled by the executive arm, if he is not free to criticise, he cannot fulfil his duty and his responsibility to the people who elect him. Members must always be free to criticise and to question, when necessary, the government of the day and its actions, no matter whether they be members on this side, the government side, or on the Opposition side. Of course, we on the government side live in the hope that it will not be necessary at any stage to criticise the actions of government, but inevitably there will be occasions when a member must be prepared to speak out in a forthright manner on behalf of the constituents he represents and to criticise policies or actions, because governments are only human and they make mistakes. If that occurs, there must be disagreement and there must be criticism. Therefore, members must always be vigilant and watchful to protect that right to an independent view and to independent action.

I see real danger in reports that are now circulating that the Government is considering increasing the number of parliamentary secretaries to Ministers. Under the Parliamentary Secretaries Act, No. 160 of 1980, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has been given, I think wrongly, extraodinarily wide powers to appoint any member of this House or of the Senate as a parliamentary secretary to a Minister. I refer briefly to the relevant part of the legislation. Section 3(1) states:
The Prime Minister may appoint a person who is a member of either House of the Parliament to be a Parliamentary Secretary to a Minister of State.
Section 3(2) states:
The appointment of a person as a Parliamentary Secretary to a Minister of State may be revoked at any time by the Prime Minister.

Then the Act goes on to establish the fact that secretaries are not to be remunerated for their functions. Of course, that is required under the Constitution. But those powers of appointment of parliamentary secretaries by a particular member of this Parliament, the particular member being the Prime Minister, I think is wrong in the sense that they are far too wide. The act says that the Prime Minister makes the appointment, not the Governor-General as is the case with Ministers. It is not an appointment by the Minister concerned; it is an appointment by the Prime Minister. I believe the situation in the United Kingdom is that the Minister directly affected-that is, the person for whom the secretary will act-has the right to appoint an individual. Here the Prime Minister has the sole right to hire and fire; that is, to appoint or to revoke the appointment.

The second criticism I offer is that there is no limit to the number of members of this House or of the Senate who, in theory at least, can be appointed under that legislation as secretaries to Ministers. I think that is a fundamental flaw in legislation and perhaps it is evidence of our sloppy legislative system that we can allow that kind of provision to go through this House and the other place. Under the United Kingdom Ministers of the Crown Act a maximum number of holders of all ministerial positions is set. That includes a range of people-Ministers, secretaries of state and parliamentary secretaries. But in Australia there is no such limit. In addition, the rights and duties of parliamentary secretaries have not been prescribed, at least not under the legislation or under subordinate legislation of this House.

So, we must ask the question: What are the rights, the obligations and the duties of people who have been appointed or who may in the future be appointed as parliamentary secretaries? Can they criticise government policy? Are they free to raise in this place and in the party room important issues which affect their electorates? If the duties, responsibilities and obligations of parliamentary secretaries who have already been appointed or who may be appointed are set out in some written form, are prescribed in some administrative way by the Prime Minister, by Ministers or by the government, I believe this House is entitled to know just what those functions, responsibilities and duties are to ensure that there is no real conflict between the role of the parliamentary secretary and his responsibilities as an ordinary private member. I believe the legislation is deficient in that it should have set out just what the duties of these parliamentary secretaries are.

I raise this issue just to underline to honourable members the dangers of this system, especially the extraordinarily wide powers vested in the Prime Minister of the day-I emphasise 'of the day'-whoever he may be. Of course, I am not directing my remarks to the role of the present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and how he might use that legislation. At present, a limited number of people have been appointed as parliamentary secretaries. The whole subject of the extension of executive influence, control and power over ordinary back bench, private members of the Parliament, whether they be in this House or in the Senate, is an issue that I believe goes to the very reason for our sitting here representing the communities and the electorates that we represent. As private members we must always be free and independent to question and criticise. If we are not free to do that we canot carry out our functions as ordinary members of the Parliament. So, there is this very clear division between the government-that is, the Executive, the Ministers who are appointed by the Prime Minister or by the party system-and the ordinary member of the Parliament. I think these appointments have clouded that clear distinction between the role of a person who happens to be a member of this place and is appointed a member of the Executive and the role of a person who has not been so appointed but who sits here as a private member to carry out his function of representing the people in his electorate.

I realise, of course, that the pressure placed upon the Government and upon Ministers is great. We are living in a very complex world. It is a much more difficult job to be a Minister of the Crown these days, I am sure, than it was, say, at the time of Federation. There are all kinds of pressures placed upon Ministers, upon the Prime Minister, particularly, and upon leaders of parties. That has manifested itself in illnesses in recent times of these people who carry out very important functions in this country. They carry very heavy burdens as a result of the positions that they hold and the duties that they carry out. The important question is how we can reduce those burdens and the weight that these people carry. At the same time, there are also fundamental and important principles-very high principles-which should not be overlooked. I therefore raise this issue and I trust that members of this Parliament will distinguish the role of private members as distinct from that of the Executive.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to deal with the subject of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission's report which was presented to Parliament yesterday. Education, today, is a subject which is much in the spotlight and a subject that needs careful consideration. We know from the Government's budgeting efforts that universities and colleges of advanced education around Australia are getting $54m less than the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission said was necessary to maintain the current levels of quality and activities that were needed in education. We know that directions have been given for amalgamations to take place. This is having a drastic effect around the country.

SPEECH.PARA: One section in the report is of particular concern to me as I represent the electorate of McMillan in which is situated the Gippsland Institute of Advanced Education. The news for that college in this report is not good. This is something that I wish to highlight to the Government and to the Parliament. I will read from the report. It states:

The situation in Victoria is an evolving one, and is complicated by uncertainties as to the consolidation of certain colleges. Although VPSEC did not wish to vary its proposals as a consequence of discussions with the working party, it provided additional information relating to staffing issues which had not been available at the time of the Council's consideration of VPSEC's proposals. As a result, the Commission has concluded that the grants proposed for the Bendigo College of Advanced Education, SCV Rusden/Burwood/Toorak/Prahran College of Advanced Education, and the successor to the SCV Melbourne, could prove insufficient to cover the costs of transition to a lower level of activity.
In other words, there is insufficient money available for the retrenchment proceedings that this Government has initiated. The report continues:

In these circumstances, the Commission believes that it would not be prudent at this stage to recommend increases in the grants for Footscray Institute of Technology, Gippsland Institute of Advanced Education and Swinburne Institute of Technology at the levels originally proposed.
What procedures have been carried out needs to be considered.

Prior to this report being presented, the Government gave its guidelines for funding and what was required. Because of that, in the short time available, the Victorian Post-Secondary Education Commission and the Advanced Eduction Council were required to put in a lot of work and make a lot of assessments about what the funding and the procedure would be. This required colleges to put forward proposals to VPSEC. These proposals had to be considered. Colleges had to take part in the considerations and put their planning forward for the future. No doubt, the college of advanced education in Churchill in my electorate was very much involved in this. Many, many hours of work were spent to come up with the proposals that were eventually put forward by VPSEC.

However, it appears, from what has happened, that much lobying has taken place since July-August when many of the recommendations were put forward. It has been discovered that the Government's actions and amalgamations will lead to some rather drastic redundancies in many colleges around Victoria. Therefore VPSEC said that it would require somewhere between $5m and $10m extra to cover the costs of these extra stipulations that had been imposed by Government policy. The Government took a rather head-in-the-sand approach to education in solving this problem. Rather than making more funds available to rectify a problem that it had created, it is now, according to this report, appearing to take the line where other colleges are to be deprived of the funds that had been granted to them, that had been agreed to and that had been worked out after many, many hours of discussion and work.

The point that needs to be made is that, in these proposals, all colleges of advanced education have had the opportunity to put their cases forward to VPSEC to deal with the Advanced Education Council. Everybody in education has had a democratic opportunity to put something forward. Whether they agreed with Government policy or not that is the way it has been. It now appears that the Footscray Institute of Technology, the Gippsland Institute of Advanced Education, and the Swinburne Institute of Technology will be deprived of this democratic right. This report has come out without any consultation and has overruled the decisions made after long periods of planning and after programs have been put into place for education for 1982. This planning has been turned completely upside down by this Government. Why has this been done? It has been done because the Government is not prepared to make enough funds available to carry out its policies. It is willing to turn the planning upside down in respect of three colleges and take away their democratic right to negotiate for their rightful share of funds. This is happening because the Government is not prepared to put enough money forward.

Let us have a look at a couple of points to highlight the situation. Let us consider two colleges, one in Bendigo and the other in Gippsland. In Bendigo the allocation of funding works out at $6,020 a student as against the figure for the Gippsland Institute of Advanced Education of $4,745 a student. It appears, from those figures, that Gippsland is a very efficient college and is running its business very effectively. In fact, it was able to run its college for $1,300 a student cheaper than was Bendigo. Yet, we find in the report that the funding that has been taken from a college like Gippsland is to be paid across to a college like Bendigo because of the redundancy requirements and because of the money that is required for the staff cuts that will have to be made in many parts of the State. This is a definite case of democracy gone mad. The Government seems to be prepared to put forward policies based on the fact that it says: 'There is X amount of dollars. You work out how that money will be spent'. Many, many hours, through the proper channels, are spent organising and meetings are held to decide how the money will be spent. But when pressure is put on the Government and it is decided that there is not enough money to cover the staff cuts and the amalgamation problems that the Government has created by its direction, rather than putting forward extra money, the Government decides that these colleges will suffer.

Let me make it quite clear. The Latrobe Valley area which is part of my electorate where this Institute is situated is one of the fastest growing areas in Victoria. It is the only really fast growing area in Victoria. It is also one of the fastest growing areas of Australia. This area needs a college that is growing, not a college that is being treated in this harsh manner. Much of the funding that was to be made available for that college was to increase the engineering area of that college and to upgrade overall the college so that it could keep up with growth in the area. This policy that the Government is putting forward will set that area back. The $400,000 cut that has been imposed upon that college will mean, from information that I have been able to find this morning, that no contract teachers who are involved in that college will be re-employed in 1982. How can any college in a fast growing area possibly plan for the future with this type of approach. How can education in vital areas be considered seriously by this Government when it takes this approach. The Cabinet of this Government has often been called a cow shed Cabinet. As a representative of a rural electorate and a farmer, I would like to give a little advice to this cow shed Cabinet. I will draw an analogy between a farmer buying a tractor and the actions of the cow shed Cabinet--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I suggest that the term the honourable member has used repeatedly is unparliamentary.
—Order! I gathered that the term was 'cow shed'.

—I am a dairy farmer and I know what it is like to run a farm. I do not think there is anything unparliamentary about what I have said. I was about to say that it is equivalent to a farmer who finds on buying a tractor that he is a little short of money to do the job. So, rather than spend a few bob extra, he brings home a tractor without any tyres on it, driving it on the rims. It will do the job all right, but it will not do it very well. That is the way this Government is running education.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter The Hon R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that I will have only four minutes of the allotted 10 minutes in which to speak in this grievance debate. I could spend 44 minutes on what I have to say. The matters that I want to mention represent a grievance of the most profound nature. They relate to the further penalties which I have exposed over the last week or two on people who live in the areas that produce the great wealth of this nation. I have been accused of being parochial and of repeating the same old comment, but the same old comment is as valid today, if not more so, as it has been since this country was founded. I speak not of people who are Martin Place farmers. I speak of people out in the back blocks not only of Queensland but also of every other State in this nation who are sustaining the industries that pour millions of dollars into the Commonwealth Treasury to sustain this great capital city of Canberra and everything that goes with it.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw attention to a particular grievance relating to telephone charges. It was with a great deal of joy that, after a great many experiments and a great deal of investigation, it was found that radio telephones were a goer. We thought that all of the difficulties, particularly in the central part of Queensland, were over. Believe it or not, there was no telephone-no telecommunications at all-west of the town of Winton. At long last the viability and the technical feasibility of radio telephones was achieved; but what happened? The charges were equally as high as the cost of the installation of conventional telephone lines though maintenance through storms and so on was eliminated-the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) would know about this as he has just told us he is a farmer-and there were difficulties with static and the rest of it. A thing of the past. We thought that all our problems were over; but were they? Only this morning a chap named Don Alexander, a genuine grazier, a fellow who roughs it right out in the bush with so many of my people, gave me some information on this subject. I wish I had half an hour in which to put just this case. The licence fee for his radio telephone, which was installed by him and a group of people in the area, has increased 500 per cent-from $80 to $400. I appeal to the Government to look at this matter and take steps immediately to rectify the situation regarding this very vicious imposition on these people. With due respect to the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair), we will be meeting with his senior officers within a few days to discuss these matters.

The other matter I want to mention-I note that the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) is present-relates to the real possibility of the termination of Trans Australia Airlines services in areas of inland Queensland. The Minister has created a vigilance group. I want the House and the nation to understand that we will meet and look very closely at this whole situation. In the half-minute remaining I point out that the one matter which occupies the minds of every person who lives in the areas affected is the sustaining of the standard of aircraft and the frequency of our services. We ask the Minister and the Government to look not only at the report of the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares, which says that if an airline shows a loss over a period of six months it can terminate its services, but also at the other requirement of the report, which is that if such a company shows a loss it should be subsidised by the Government. I appeal to the Government to do just that.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to report to the House about the shortage of air traffic controllers in Australia-the reasons for the shortage, the effect of the shortage and the actions being taken to overcome the problem. The matter has been of considerable concern to the Queensland Government, tourist interests and honourable members on both sides of this House in recent weeks. There has been justified concern about the circumstances which have led to the three-hour closure each night of Brisbane Airport since 10 September.

SPEECH.PARA: The Reasons for the Shortage of Air Traffic Controllers

The fact of the matter is that since the early 1970's the total number of air traffic controllers in Australia has increased from just over 1,000 to the present level of 1,156. Although we have a shortage of controllers to meet rapidly increasing aviation needs, we have more air traffic controllers today than ever before. The 1,156 controllers is below the number now needed to meet all the operational requirements resulting from industry growth rates and to introduce revised procedures with the support of industry at major general aviation airports.

I have had an analysis made of the national statistics on air traffic controller requirements, availability, recruitment, training and wastage from 1974 to the present time. The analysis shows, firstly, that in the mid 1970s the margin of trained controllers over actual requirements was eliminated. While the numbers of air traffic controllers available have continued to rise, the requirements for air traffic control services have increased at a faster rate over recent years. Taken in conjunction with the wastage rate, the result will be a shortfall of the order of 110 controllers by the end of the year. I must point out that the requirements include 19 Australian air traffic controllers serving in Papua New Guinea in fulfilment of our obligation to that country to the end of 1982.

Because it takes three years to train an air traffic controller-one year where a recruit has substantial aeronautical experience-the numbers required for recruitment must be anticipated more than three years in advance. The recruitment of air traffic controllers declined steadily from 1974 to 1976 when there was no intake. The trainee recruitment then rose to a peak in 1979 and has maintained a level of the order of 110 to 120 each year since. However, the major benefit from the increased recruitment since 1978 will not be felt until early in 1982 and subsequent years. My department's air traffic control training school has been operating to planned capacity since the beginning of 1979. It is expected that, from next year onwards, between 80 and 90 air traffic controllers will graduate each year. Plans to increase the training capacity further in the short to medium term are now in hand utilising a new system of progressive training which will enable six courses, each of 20 trainees, to commence in the next six months. Against the annual graduates has to be offset the wastage from retirement, resignations and long term illnesses, et cetera. Wastage has been of the order of 3.5 per cent each year to 1978. There was a significant decrease in 1979 followed by an increase to 3.8 per cent in 1980, which was the highest rate in recent times. The increase was due in part to the resignation of seven controllers to take up contract appointments overseas. The wastage for 1981 is again expected to be of the order of 3.5 per cent. However, in Queensland the wastage has been over 8 per cent for the past year. This is three times the rate of the previous years in Queensland.
The Problems Arising from the Shortage

In view of these circumstances, my Department had no alternative but to plan for the closure of Brisbane airport for a period from 9.00 pm to midnight which balanced the available manpower with the minimum disruption to the industry. The three hour closure of Brisbane airport affects one Trans Australia Airlines flight and one Ansett Airlines of Australia flight each night which normally arrive at 9.30 pm, as well as additional Ansett and TAA flights on Friday and Sunday nights. Ansett and TAA have rescheduled these flights to arrive earlier in Brisbane and thus maintain services. No scheduled jet flights from Brisbane to north Queensland are affected. Additionally, the closure has disrupted the night freighter operations which normally fly in and out of Brisbane between 11.00 pm and 1.00 am on week nights. The north-bound leg of the weekly Qantas Airways Ltd flight to Tokyo is also affected by the three hour closure, but the Brisbane passengers are being ferried to Sydney for the flight to Tokyo. The south-bound Tokyo-Brisbane flight is not affected. At locations other than Brisbane, air traffic control services are being maintained at the level of the published hours of coverage, though the general shortage is causing significant amounts of overtime to be worked by some controllers to cover short term absences for sickness and special leave. The situation varies between locations, but Sydney particularly was seriously affected by sick leave during the month of August when over 160 shifts were worked on overtime to cover sick leave in order to maintain services.
Actions Being Taken to Overcome the Problem

The following long and short term actions have been taken, or are being taken, to overcome the shortage of air traffic controllers in Australia. Action was taken by my Department to transfer controllers to Queensland. However, as the recent wastage in Queensland has involved senior terminal area controllers, it will take some months before transferees provide sufficient trained controllers to overcome the shortage. With the action now taken, there will be sufficient controllers in Queensland by the end of the year to meet requirements. When daylight saving commences in the southern States on 25 October, the effect of the closure on the domestic passenger flights will be alleviated. Coverage is planned for the scheduled and special airline flights in the period leading up to Christmas.

My Department has been supplementing its Australian recruiting campaign with a recruitment program in the United Kingdom, Hong Kong and New Zealand. Thirty-three suitable recruits have been offered employment as a result of the overseas recruitment efforts. We are investigating the possibility of recruiting air traffic controllers in Canada and the United States. Sufficient trainees are already available for the three courses scheduled to commence before the end of the year. There will be 20 trainees per course. In order to enable as many as possible of the industry requirements for additional services to be met with the available controllers, my Department and the Public Service Board have been negotiating with the air traffic controllers industrial association, the Civil Air Operations Officers Association of Australia-CAOOAA-for variations to the industrial agreement related to rostering principles. The variations would be of particular value at Brisbane in that the extent of the closure could be reduced and coverage provided for all scheduled passenger services. Regrettably, CAOOAA rejected the financially attractive proposals offered by the Public Service Board which were combined with proposals by my Department for a system of familiarisation flights by air traffic controllers. This has been an objective that the Association has sought for many years. Despite this set-back, my Department again requested CAOOAA, as a goodwill measure, to agree to varying the rostering principles to alleviate the effect of the current shortage in Brisbane, by maximising the coverage provided by the available controllers.

Following the Association's central council meeting last week, my Department has received advice that the Association will agree to the requested variations for a one to two year period in return for agreement to fundamental variations in salary and conditions of employment of air traffic controllers. The Association's response has been referred to the Public Service Board for consideration. My Department has completed negotiations to permit the temporary re-engagement of eight ex-air traffic controllers who can be temporarily released from their employment as Qantas pilots. It is expected that these ex-controllers will be deployed in Sydney and Brisbane after refresher training. My Department is working with the Public Service Board in developing proposals for engaging suitable controllers from the United States on a contract basis for a period of three years. The widespread shortage of air traffic controllers in many overseas countries has led to regular recruiting campaigns for air traffic controllers for service in the Middle East and far eastern countries. Hopefully this demand will be met in future from the pool of currently unemployed controllers in the United States, many of whom have expressed interest in employment in Australia.
Conclusion

As can be seen from my statement, the efforts already in hand will ensure that the air traffic control resources will be able to meet fully the demand for services by the end of 1983. In the meantime, the situation will be progressively improving and hopefully with the co-operation of air traffic controllers, there will be negligible impact on the travelling public from the beginning of next year. It is regrettable that due to unusually high retirements, resignations and sickness amongst air traffic controllers, and the unforeseen growth in the aviation industry, the shortage should show up at this time. There is no doubt that we are now experiencing the low level of trainees who com- menced their training during 1974, 1975 and 1976. I regret that some inconvenience is being occasioned to some travellers to and from Brisbane. I appreciate the efforts being made by the great majority of air traffic controllers to help overcome the immediate problem. I give the assurance of the Government that everything that can be reasonably done is being done to obtain sufficient air traffic controllers to meet the needs of aviation and travellers in the 1980s. I present the following paper:
Air Traffic Controller Shortage-Ministerial Statement, 24 September 1981.
Motion (by Mr Wilson) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes the opportunity which the statement of the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) provides for parliamentary discussion on this critical issue of air safety and, more particularly, the serious shortage of air traffic controllers which has resulted in the early daily closure of Brisbane Airport and which is most likely to lead to the early closure and reduced availability of other airports within Australia. I understand it has also led to concern at Sydney Airport where a heavy work load is being placed upon air traffic controllers and excessive overtime is being worked. Some two out of three shifts at Sydney Airport are worked by people on overtime.

SPEECH.PARA: In essence, the statement constitutes a confession of failure and misjudgment of air safety services by the hapless Minister for Transport. To an extent, he inherited some of the problems from his equally hapless and embattled colleague, the present Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon). Whilst the Minister has sought to detail the position with respect of air traffic controllers, the information his predecessor provided to this Parliament on an earlier occasion refutes much of what the Minister has said. I will come to that later.
