Both Ministers, the present Minister for Transport and the present Minister for Primary Industry-the former Minister for Transport-have employed, on numerous occasions, the standard National Country Party tactics of denigrating critics of their shortcomings rather than responsibly and carefully investigating and acting upon claims of deficiency in air services. Those claims have come from across the full spectrum of the industry, executives, operators, unionists, members of the parliament and ordinary members of the community. The Department, the Minister and his predecessor have been aware of those claims but have chosen instead-as the Minister did last night in his statement about the crash at Mascot on 21 February last year-to ridicule and besmirch those making criticism of their failings and shortcomings. I refer to the attitude to air safety of the Minister's predecessor. On 23 July 1979 a Press statement released by Mr Nixon stated:
Mr Nixon said he was vitally concerned to ensure that Australia's aviation safety standards were fully and adequately maintained.
'I have said before, and I repeat now, that I am not prepared to put up with any condition that leads to the view that air safety in Australia is being jeopardised,' Mr Nixon said.
The present Minister has made similar high sounding statements. His predecessor, in the Parliament on 16 August 1978, said:

. . . it is the Government's policy to maintain aviation safety at the highest possible level. However, aviation safety is for experts to maintain; it is not for politicians, journalists or laymen to determine.
I suggest that they are the potential victims of failures in air safety procedures. He continued:
. . . I will continue as always to rely on those experts in my Department and in the industry itself who can and do advise me.

I say to the Minister and his predecessor that I have seen the results of that attitude in the damning report of the Air Safety Investigation Branch into the Advance Airlines of Australia disaster of 21 February last year. The Minister also sought in his statement to play down the costs of his failure to keep Brisbane Airport open. We know that a major tourist development to the value of $30m in the Whitsunday area has been deferred as a direct result of the insecurity of the availability of Brisbane Airport. The decision was not taken because of problems associated with the commercial side of the development. It was the direct result of the failures of the Minister and his Department. The major disruption to domestic airline scheduling has led to a lower utilisation of its expensive aircraft. The Minister has played down that aspect. He said that the airlines have re-arranged schedules and that everything is okay. He pointed out that only a minor number of flights are affected. Costs are now being incurred through a lower utilisation rate of aircraft by the airlines and through the unavailability of services. There are problems for the tourist industry in the preparation and planning of tourist packages because of the uncertainty associated with airport availability.

The fundamental problems involved are the Government's failure to plan ahead and its refusal to bring the conditions and entitlements of air traffic controllers into line with those available in countries that are poaching our very highly regarded and well trained air traffic controllers. In an incredible fashion in the Minister's statement and at the Estimates Committee last week he foolishly sought to blame the present shortage of air traffic controllers on the Whitlam Administration. Honourable members should bear in mind that the training period for air traffic controllers was two years. It later became three years. There has been time since the Whitlam Administration was in office for two classes of air traffic controllers to graduate. The Minister has advanced differing reasons from time to time for the shortage of air traffic controllers that his Department has. Mr Thompson of his Department appeared at the Senate Estimates Committee on 30 April this year. In answer to a question by Senator Georges he said:

You were referring to Brisbane airport. It is true that in certain areas the Department is short of air traffic controllers but that is a problem caused by the lead time required in training and problems in recruitment.

There was no mention of the Whitlam Administration or a low intake of air traffic controllers in earlier years. On 25 August the Minister in answer to a question by the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Jull) in this chamber referred to the shortage of air traffic controllers at Brisbane Airport. He said:

One of the great difficulties we have with the controllers there is that many of them have in fact been working for two years without recreation leave, and in the terms of the conditions under which they have to operate they must take their leave at the end of the second year. This has contributed to a shortfall of air traffic controllers in Brisbane as from 10 September.

There is no mention of the Whitlam Administration or the low intake. They are the latest stories that the Minister has dreamed up. We should look also at the disparity in entitlements and conditions of air traffic controllers in this country and those available elsewhere, to which I referred a few moments ago. We should also look at the onerous and most responsible tasks that air traffic controllers have to fulfil in the course of their duties. Add to that the excessive overtime and work load and we have some understanding of why there is a limited life for air traffic controllers and why grave risks are associated in the operation of our air services if too much overtime is being worked, if not enough air traffic controllers are available and if the Government is not acting in a positive way to remedy the situation.

I have mentioned some of the problems associated with the matter which the Minister has advanced on earlier occasions but which contrast with his statement today. The invalidity rates for air traffic controllers between 1976 and 1980 reflect the nature of their occupation. Forty-one per cent of retirements due to invalidity were due to psychiatric conditions. There is a grave responsibility upon air traffic controllers. Likewise, there should be a grave responsibility upon this Government to act honestly, forthrightly and positively on this issue. It should not try to politicise it, as it has in the latest exercise, and blame the air traffic controllers for not accepting an offer that the Minister and the Public Service Board knew they would not accept. The Minister gave the impression that they were likely to accept it. He has not revealed the details of that offer. It would help public discussion if he did. It would certainly interest the other members of the Public Service. Everything this Minister has said about the number of air traffic controllers, the reasons for their problems and the numbers required in the early 1970s and the late 1970s is refuted by the parliamentary record of his predecessor. In a general discussion about the problems of air safety Mr Nixon on 16 August 1978-this is recorded at page 360 of Hansard-said:
In the area of air traffic control staff numbers are down less than 3 per cent of the presently required strength of 955 in the regions, or down 27 officers.

The required strength was 955, not more than 1,000. Mr Nixon said that three years ago. There is no mention of the Whitlam era or low intakes in the middle 1970s. Those are the facts from the Minister's predecessor and the Department which has now produced different information for the present Minister. Mr Nixon continued:

This requirement takes into account all operational needs plus relief for leave and sickness. I point out that this is not an abnormal situation for any organisation of this type; but in addition the Department took action some time ago to accelerate the trainee intake to alleviate even this small shortage as quickly as possible. More particularly, the Department and the Public Service Board are currently giving urgent consideration to a restructuring of air traffic control training. This will give even earlier relief, whilst at the same time giving better training and improved prospects of career satisfaction.

I put it to the House that there is the absolute rebuttal of the tomfoolery the Minister has presented to us today. His predecessor three years ago said that strength was down by 27 officers, that the Department had increased the intake and was changing the training regime, that there was only a minor shortage and there would be no problem. He said that the Department had had discussions with the Public Service Board on restructuring air traffic control training. Three years and one month, less six days, later, Brisbane airport has been closed down by this Minister and this Government because not enough air traffic controllers are available. Which Minister was telling lies? They both cannot be correct. Was it the Minister at the table or his predecessor? Which officers in the Department were telling lies? Was it the present ones or the ones in 1978? Whilst we accept and welcome what we hope is a faithful undertaking to try to alleviate the situation and ensure that action is taken to recruit sufficient air traffic controllers to keep the airport open during normal operational hours, the Minister's statement is not acceptable. It is a false statement. It is a paltry attempt to blame, of all people, former Prime Minister Whitlam as being responsible for the present shortage of air traffic controllers.

We should note also from the Minister's statement that it is not expected that the full strength of air traffic controllers will be reached for another two years. The Minister gave the impression in the earlier part of his statement that by early 1982 everything would be back to normal. Later in his statement he said that we will not get up to full strength until 1983-another two years away. This is five years after his predecessor said: 'Everything is okay. We are on strength. We are recruiting quickly and we are changing the training program'.

Whilst these belated attempts to remedy the situation are welcome, we have no confidence in this Minister. This Minister changes on the hour, by the hour. This Government's policy on aviation is made on the hour, by the hour. Let us revert to a statement the Minister made at 8 o'clock last night. He said of the report of the aircraft accident at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport-the air safety investigation report on the Advance Airlines disaster:
I have considered the need for the appointment of a Board--
Being a board of inquiry-
I have concluded that such action is not warranted in the circumstances of this accident.
In reaching this conclusion, I was aware of the actions which had been taken by my Department in relation to some issues which had advanced during the investigation.
Less than 14 hours later he said:
In giving further consideration to the conclusion of the report, particularly recommendation 14--
Which I will not bother to read-
. . . I feel that there is a public interest matter that should be resolved by a board of inquiry.

How can anybody have any confidence in the competence of this Minister or the advice that he is receiving? We cannot. The tourist industry and the aviation industry cannot have any faith or carry out any firm planning on the basis of what this Government says are its aviation policies on the hour, by the hour and sometimes 12-hourly. We must always be prepared for the unexpected as far as this Minister is concerned.

The proposals put forward for rapid recruitment of air traffic controllers in effect amount to band aid solutions to a very serious problem. The basic problem is to bring the conditions entitlements of air traffic controllers into line so that the air traffic controllers on whom we spend $100,000 each training are retained for our services on our airline system. The reason the world wants them, apart from the fact that the money is better elsewhere, is because they have such a high reputation.

Let me make the following point which the Minister neglected to mention. The overseas recruitment training program that the Minister put forward early in the year was to have solved things. The Senate Estimates committee dealing with this matter was told that there was a rapid recruitment of air traffic controllers abroad. It was expected that a certain number of air traffic controllers would be recruited and that that would get things right. Taxpayers paid, in addition to the $135,000 that year, another $440,000. In total, some $575,000 has been spent on travel associated with the recruitment of air traffic controllers and key personnel abroad. What have we to show for that expenditure? We see closed airports, airports not available for service, services disrupted, and unnecessary costs being incurred.

As I said, we welcome the statement. We hope that these belated attempts by the Government to remedy the situation will be carried through. We hope, for the sake of the industry and the travelling public, that they will be fruitful. We cannot accept the Minister's statement as being factual. In the light of his past performance, we have little confidence that he will carry through the initiatives that he has indicated.
Motion (by Mr Hodges) proposed:
That the debate be now adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND ISLANDER LAND RIGHTS IN QUEENSLAND AND WESTERN AUSTRALIA

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The threat to Australia's international reputation arising from the Prime Minister's failure to protect and extend the rights of Aboriginal and Islander people in Queensland and Western Australia.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In six days' time the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) will preside over the opening of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne. This meeting, as we have been reminded, will be the largest meeting of foreign leaders ever to assemble in Australia. It will bring together leaders representing 25 per cent of the world's population, from both developed and developing countries. It will be the Prime Minister's crowning glory, his political climax. It will be the result of his relentless pursuit of fame-international fame. The Right Honourable John Malcolm Fraser will have arrived.

SPEECH.PARA: At the same time as the Prime Minister achieves his ultimate triumph in one Commonwealth, the Commonwealth of Nations, we observe in stark contrast his failure in another Commonwealth, the Australian Commonwealth. In the Commonwealth where he can only grandstand, posture and interfere, he is immensely active. In the Commonwealth where he can actually right the wrongs, where he has the responsibility for action, he does nothing. When abroad he is a crusading statesman. At home he is a feeble political weakling. In international affairs, the Prime Minister was rightly concerned about bringing democracy to Zimbabwe. He continues, quite rightly, to campaign on the North-South question, which seeks a better deal for the underdeveloped countries from the developed countries. He is right to be concerned about Namibia. It is certainly not my intention to belittle his role on these important issues. I simply ask the question: In the face of this frenzied activity overseas in relation to other countries, why is there so little activity at home in relation to the position of Aborigines and their lack of control over their lives, their poverty, their persecution, their denial of basic human rights? In July of this year the Prime Minister said in his address to the Royal Commonwealth Society in London:

The scope for Commonwealth action is not pre-determined and fixed by some objective law. To a very considerable extent it depends on our own attitudes and commitments. Of course, there are objective limits to the role we can play, but we should not allow timidity or exaggerated modesty to circumscribe that role unnecessarily. Indeed, we should be alert to any opportunity to expand it.

That is what he says about the opportunities and responsibilities of the Commonwealth of which he is but one among 40. Compare that with what he says about his role in the Commonwealth of which he is head, the Commonwealth of which he is the Prime Minister. In answer to a question from the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) on 26 August last year, the Prime Minister said in relation to his dealings with the Western Australian Government:
. . . it is true that the Conference-
That is, the National Aboriginal Conference-

put to us that it would prefer this Government to use the totality of its Commonwealth power. The Government, in response, said that if these matters are to be resolved through negotiation and consultation, it will be not only a question of negotiation and consultation among Aboriginal groups, the State Government, miners or the Federal Government but also a question of negotiation and consultation between governments. It is not a question of one government arbitrarily using powers in relation to another.
Before that he had said:
It will not advance the cause of Aborigines if one government is virtually to go to war with another over the question of what ought to be done.

Is this not evidence of the sort of timidity which he was exhorting the other Commonwealth to avoid? The worst conditions confronted in Australia by Aboriginal and islander people are no better than those experienced by blacks in Zimbabwe during minority rule, no better than those experienced by the poor and the sick in underdeveloped countries. In the face of this double standard-the piety abroad and the neglect at home-the Prime Minister's efforts overseas only serve to mock him. But more than that, his activities abroad attract international attention to his efforts at home and that is really beginning to hurt. The National Aboriginal Conference has already taken its grievances to an agency of the United Nations in Geneva. The Australian Council of Churches invited a team from the World Council of Churches to visit Australia to examine the predicament of Australian Aborigines. Its report is a damning indictment. Under the heading 'Mining', the report says:

In the top end of the Northern Territory and in the Kimberley region of Western Australia, Aboriginal communities are living in fear of the impact the massive mining developments will have on their life style, their freedom, their culture, and their land and sacred sites.
It goes on:

The West Australian Government in its actions in support of or on behalf of the mining companies is showing a callous disregard for the people. Community development programmes for Aborigines are apparently being stopped in order to prevent any hindrance to mining development.
Under the heading 'Legal System', the report says:
The relationship between Aborigines and the legal system is one of conflict at all levels.
It goes on.

In Queensland, Aborigines represent 2 per cent of the general population but 35 per cent of the prison population. In Western Australia, the general population is 2.4 percent Aboriginal but the prison population is 41 percent Aboriginal.
Under the heading 'Health', the report says:

Nothing shows more clearly the total neglect of Aboriginal people and the racial discrimination against them by white Australian society than the alarming health conditions of Aboriginal people. Their standard of health is far lower than that of the majority of Australians and would not be tolerated if it existed in the Australian community as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—It was also said by the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs of which the honourable member for Dundas was Chairman and of which I was a member. Under the heading 'Housing', the report says:

SPEECH.PARA: Aboriginal communities in all the States we visited are inadequately housed. In some rural areas, Aboriginal people live without such basic needs as a water supply and minimum shelter.
Under the heading 'Education', the report says:
Our attention was drawn to the insensitivity and inflexibility of the education system which has resulted in statistics that indicate:

from a total of about 60,000 Aboriginal children, approximately 15 per cent are currently studying at secondary school but only 2 percent proceed beyond Grade 9, compared with 24 percent of white children;
Under the heading 'Employment', the report says:

Aborigines are the poorest people in Australia primarily because for the majority of them, their only income is inadequate social security benefits. Put simply, because they are unemployed. Yet time and again Aboriginal people told us they wanted to work and scorned 'sit down money'-their term for unemployment benefits.

The report is a picture of unrelieved horror, something of which we should all be ashamed. I do not believe for one moment that the Prime Minister condones the conditions of Aboriginal people in Australia. Indeed, his abhorrence of racism is one of the very few issues on which he has been consistent and passionate. But this only makes it worse. If he thought Bjelke-Petersen and Court were right, it would be understandable for him to do nothing to contest their actions. But that is clearly not the case. He knows they are wrong; he disapproves, and yet he still does nothing. What greater failing can there be in a Prime Minister than to recognise an evil, to have the power to correct it and to do nothing? The Prime Minister has expressed himself eloquently on Aboriginal issues in the past. I quote from a speech he made:

The denial of fundamental human rights to any group in a society diminishes that society. We must all be resolved that such discrimination and bigotry will never happen again. All Australians are entitled to be treated equally under the law whatever their colour, whatever their race. All are entitled to equal respect and equal protection. The Government is resolved to put an end to the hurt, indifference and intolerance which almost destroyed the Australian Aboriginals and their culture.
He goes on:

Throughout all our work together we must never forget that any policy based on the superiority of one race over another is a policy doomed to failure. Just as the Government's policies towards Southern Africa are founded on this fundamental principle so in Australia we must achieve nothing less than real equality of all Australians-equality of rights, equality of opportunities, equality of protection under the law.

Yet the rhetoric of the Prime Minister, however well intentioned, has been particularly cruel. He has expressed his sympathy for the cause of Aboriginal people. He has expressed his horror at their current circumstances. He has expressed his concern for the preservation of their culture and their sacred sites. He has, in short, raised the expectation of the Aboriginal people only to disappoint them with his lack of action. This approach has been mirrored by his Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs-first Viner, then Chaney and now Baume. They have dragged their silver tongues from one end of Australia to another mouthing sweet platitudes, making the right responses, but when it comes to delivering on their promises or their implied promises they have all been found to be sadly wanting.

Since this Government has been in office it has clipped $213m off the budget for aboriginal affairs, despite its initial promise to maintain funding for Aboriginal programs. Time and time again this Government has refused to take on the governments in Queensland and Western Australia. There was one feeble attempt to take over the reserves at Aurukun and Mornington Island, a move which was calculated to be subverted, and was, by the Queensland Government. The Queensland Government got its way and the Aborigines at Aurukun and Mornington Island lost out. Now, as the Queensland Government moves to provide leases instead of reserves, this Government will again do nothing. These leases are practically worthless to the Aboriginal people. They provide no tenure. They bestow no rights in terms of what can be done with the land and who can occupy it. The terms of the leases could at any time be overridden by the Queensland Government. In Western Australia the situation is just as bad. That Government has set its face against providing land for Aboriginal people. Yet this is the single most important demand of Aboriginal people throughout Australia. As the World Council of Churches team reported:

The cry for land rights is universal among all Aboriginal communities, rural and urban, particularly in the Northern Territory, Queensland and Western Australia. It is part of their struggle for social and human justice for human dignity and identity. It is not a matter of political and economic convenience or of acquiring a piece of real estate.

We have been told over and over again by Aborigines that land is their spiritual heritage. It is part of their being a people. Land was the basis of all relationships with Aboriginal human and physical environment. Land defined the clan, its culture, its way or life, its fundamental rights, its religious and cultural ceremonies, its patterns of survival and above all, its identity. Land was synonomous with Aboriginal existence. It could not be defiled, desecrated or cheapened. The expropriation, erosion, plundering, misuse or spoil amounts to the destruction of the Aboriginies' cultural and spiritual heritage: In contemporary understanding, it amounts to cultural genocide. Therefore, recovery of land has a deep spiritual meaning for the Aboriginal communities.

What the World Council of Churches has drawn attention to is that very little can be done about the appalling health, housing, education and poverty of Aboriginal people unless people have secure access to their land. So, the efficacy of all the programs of support for Aboriginal and islander people is greatly diminished without the Commonwealth first securing land rights throughout Australia.

There is no question that the Commonwealth has power. The referendum passed in 1967 quite specifically gave the Commonwealth the power to make laws in respect of the people of any race, including the Aboriginal people. The Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in its report on the situation at Aurukun and Mornington Island has quite clearly confirmed the power of the Commonwealth to acquire land for Aboriginal people and determine the way in which it will be handed over to the Aboriginal people. Not to use this power by this Government is evidence of unbelievable political cowardice. It is to be compared with the Prime Minister's actions in browbeating young sportsmen and women over the question of the Olympic Games just last year. He had no compunction about taking on those people, about telling them what their responsibilities were not only to Australia but also to the rest of the world. He had no compunction in telling the Prime Minister of New Zealand what he ought to do about the tour of the visiting South African rugby team this year. But when he is confronted with the real intransigence of two Premiers elected by outrageous gerrymander the Prime Minister goes to water.

Without the sort of action in Australia that is necessary on these important issues how can we possibly be taken seriously by the rest of the world in relation to those questions on which the Prime Minister wants us to be involved? We cannot be taken seriously on the North-South question. We cannot be taken seriously on the question of providing democracy in other countries if the Commonwealth of Australia is not prepared to take the same sort of action on the same sort of issues in Australia where it has the power to act and where it has just shown itself too spineless to take action. If we do not take the necessary action in Australia our international reputation is likely to be comprised to the extent that the Comonwealth Games in Brisbane are likely to be imperilled all for the want of action by this Prime Minister, all for the want of action on the part of this Commonwealth Government. Negotiations have already been set in train on a proposed makarrata following preparations which the NAC has made. Those negotiations must proceed. Without that, without some resolution of the conflict which exists between the original Australian and the rest of the community, the hypocrisy of the Prime Minister will stand condemned before the whole world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —One must read the words of this matter of public importance to understand its implications. The words are very important, I think, for all honourable members to note because this is a personal attack upon the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) at a time when he is embarking upon the organisation of one of the most important international conferences in which this nation is participating. The matter of public importance is written in this form:

SPEECH.PARA: The threat to Australia's international, reputation arising from the Prime Minister's-
Mark this, the Prime Minister's-
failure to protect and extend the rights of Aboriginal and Islander people in Queensland and Western Australia.

This reads as if this is some personal responsibility of the Prime Minister. The honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) had the audacity to say that the matter of public importance was not intended to belittle the role of the Prime Minister. But that is exactly what it does. That is exactly what the honourable member thought to do. That is exactly what the matter of public importance is designed to do. It was designed by the Australian Labor Party, knowing that Australia was to participate in this important conference, to embarrass the Prime Minister in some covert way, to undermine his efforts to assist the world scene- a denigration of Australia by Her Majesty's Opposition, a denigration of Australia in the eyes of the world offered by some of its own citizens. I see it very much that way. I very much regret it. I do not think that the Aboriginal cause ought to be misused, as I believe it is in that way, by linking it with such an important national event. When the eyes of the world are to be focused upon Australia it is not for Her Majesty's Opposition, in my view, to be using the opportunities that it has in this House to advance arguments that have absolutely no validity at all. To the extent that one recognises that there have been a large number of problems in the field of Aboriginal affairs over a long time with various governments in office, with various elements of success in their programs, I think to put the matter in the way in which it has been put and to subscribe the blame, as has been endeavoured, to the Prime Minister personally is a reflection upon those who advanced the argument.

I am always disappointed when people who ought to know better advance arguments about what can or cannot be done in the field of Aboriginal affairs on the basis of the 1967 referendum proposals. I think it is timely to take this House once more through the circumstances that occurred at that time because some people believe-the honourable member personifies this-that the passing of that referendum gave the Commonwealth all sorts of powers to interfere in all sort of government activity, State and Federal, simply because it has some incidental relationship to Aborigines. To imply that is wrong. To promote that argument in the community is wrong. It is wrong, in my view, in law as much as it is in anything else. It is certainly wrong to mislead Aboriginal people into thinking that the Commonwealth has some power that it has not. The fact of the matter is that placitum (xxvi) which was incorporated in section 51 of the Constitution has never been tested in the courts. Honourable members should look at the words that were involved. The honourable member did, at least, mention that it did not refer specifically to Aboriginals when it was incorporated in the Constitution. It did in fact refer to making laws for people of a particular race. The reference excluded the previous exclusion in the section; that is, Aboriginals were not in that section before. The section simply dropped it. In debates at that time the Honourable Harold Holt, I am told, explained the matter in these terms:

An effect of omitting these words will be the removal of the existing restriction of Commonwealth power to make special laws for people of the Aboriginal race in any State if the Parliament considers it necessary. As the Constitution stands at present, the Commonwealth has no power, except in the Territories, to legislate with respect to people of Aboriginal race as such.
He identified the words in this way. He said that if the words were deleted the result would be that the Commonwealth would have vested in it:

. . . a concurrent power with respect to Aboriginals as such, they being people of a race, provided the Parliament deemed it necessary to make special laws for them. It is the view of the Government that the national Parliament should have that power.

It was seen as being a concurrent power, a power that would be exercised in co-operation with the States-not an overriding power, not a power that was to give it responsibility in all areas. That is the case with that particular section. In any event, we do not know the extent of that power. It has never been tested before any court.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you test it?

—The honourable member says: 'Why don't you test it?' That really gets to the crux of this matter as far as I am concerned. It is the very basis on which the Labor Party seeks to use Aboriginal people in a system where we confront Aboriginals and non-Aboriginals on issues which can be negotiated and discussed. The honourable member for Fremantle suggested that was cowardice. What is the reality? The reality is that if there is confrontation, Aboriginals suffer a great deal of anguish and difficulty, not that they are not suffering that now. They suffer it to a greater extent when they are put in conflict with other non-Aborigines in the community and when under the system there is grave uncertainty, worry and concern. What would be the concern? The concern would be in relation to the very programs that are in place at the moment. The concern would be if the Commonwealth were to take up the options of honourable members opposite, moved in to acquire the land and handed it over to the Aboriginals. Nobody knows on what basis the Commonwealth can do that, except we know that whenever it does, it has to do it on just terms; and just terms mean that there is a cost. Let us say that the cost is $1,000m. Some people have suggested that it might go higher. What would that do to Aboriginal programs in Australia? It would mean that we could not fund Aboriginal programs for five to 10 years at the existing rate of funding. What would it do to a Budget? What would be the cost?

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is brought home to people very clearly if they look at the Bill proposed by the Labor Party to try to give effect to Aboriginal land rights in Queensland. In, I think, clause 14 of the Bill there is a proposal to deal with the range of other activities that are provided by Queensland. Some of them relate to law enforcement proposals. That clause seeks to remove from Aboriginal settlements elements of Queensland law-its criminal code, its consumer legislation and so on. One could go on and on about the legislation, of beneficial programs for Aboriginals that would be excluded simply by that provision being in the Bill. I am not arguing about its constitutional validity at this time. But assuming that it was valid it would create a situation in which the Commonwealth would have to put into place in Aboriginal reserves, or whatever else they became, its own laws to replace all those laws of Queensland which would otherwise apply. Nobody can justify a situation in which schools, health services and police would not be available. Nobody can justify a situation in which Aboriginal people are totally separated from mainstream Australia.

The honourable member for Fremantle in his speech today suggested we should rely in some way upon this magnificent World Council of Churches report. I interjected during his speech because he was quoting at length words in that report which were in fact words I had drafted for the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs report on Aboriginal health. I do not demur from what was said because I believe it to be correct; there was nothing new or novel in the Council's report. Much of what was said in that report had been said by parliamentarians on both sides of this chamber, by parliamentarians in the States of Australia and by people who are concerned about Aboriginal issues. There was nothing new in that document. In fact, the document was deficient in the sense that I have heard other people describe documents as deficient; that was in respect of the shortness of time in which the people who deigned to comment prepared themselves to look at the question.

I was recently in India and I had the opportunity, as leader of a parliamentary delegation, to talk to Mrs Indira Gandhi. She asked the group how long we intended to be there, and I answered nine days. She said: 'That is good. Most people come for two days and then think they can write a book'. I think that is very much the case in relation to this World Council of Churches report. I suggest that a gentleman here in Australia, holding office for the Australian Council of Churches, went through all the reports, picked out the most difficult parts that he surmised others might have to answer and put them down as the views of the people who came to Australia. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) was with me recently in the Northern Territory. He did not visit the particular place mentioned in this report-Papunya-but if he had, he would know what was said on that occasion by the school principal at that place and some of his teachers about what happened on the day when the representatives of the World Council of Churches were there. Honourable gentlemen may have seen the photograph of children jumping from car body to car body in what was depicted as a playground but what was in fact the tip. Those who wanted to get good pictures for their books took the children out there from the school and had them jumping around for the photographers. It was a place where they would rarely go under other circumstances. To put such emotionalism into a topic like this does no justice to those who wrote the report and does no justice to Australia. It certainly does not provide a basis for reasoned discussion in this House of these important issues.

I want to take honourable members through the important achievements that have occurred not only over the period of the Liberal-National Country Party Government but also over the period of the previous Labor Government. Some of these matters have been happening for quite a considerable period. Honourable members have given their attention to Aboriginal questions in Australia and they do not show any deficiency of concern or any lack of willingness to work for improvement on behalf of Aboriginal people. Since 1968 we have seen an estimated 11,659 houses provided for Aboriginal people. Aboriginal hostels now provide a bed capacity in Australia of some 2,500 beds. We have over 244 independent Aboriginal housing associations operating. We have over 15,000 Aboriginal children now in secondary schools. We have 138 Aboriginals utilising Aboriginal study grants in universities; 184 are undertaking teacher training, 681 are in other tertiary studies and 229 are doing technical studies. We have more Aboriginals graduating from tertiary institutions. This year over $10,948,000 has been spent by way of State grants and grants-in-aid for education. The Government supports over 19 independent Aboriginal medical services. We fund over 40 Aboriginal alcohol rehabilitation programs. The Government is committed to providing over $50m in the next five years for Aboriginal public health improvements. That was a direct result of the health report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs. There are over 11 independent legal services operating from some 46 offices throughout the Commonwealth and handling over 750,000 cases. We have seen over $6.5m provided for legal aid in this year alone. We have seen over $11.67m directly spent for employment purposes in 1980-81. The national Aboriginal employment campaign, launched in association with the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs, has resulted in over 2,000 jobs being provided for Aboriginals. We have seen 2,638 Aboriginals receiving training under the National Employment and Training System in this year. We have had the Community Development Employment Projects which are very important in providing support for Aboriginals in remote areas. Some 1,300 people in the past year have participated in that program at a cost of over $7m.

This financial year the Commonwealth has provided about $228m specifically for the advancement of Aboriginal people in Australia. Direct spending in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs this year will be over $147m, an increase of $19.5m on spending in 1980-81. That has been done in the areas retained by that Department. It does not include the additional expenditure in the areas of education and the like. This is a magnificent record. It is a record of achievement by the Government. It is a tangible expression of our concern. But those who want to suggest that the problems that have been with us over a long time have resulted from generations of differences between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people ought to recognise that those problems will not be overcome overnight. They will certainly not be overcome by confrontation. The problems will be overcome by co-operation. I entreat the Opposition to join with us positively in this program, and the program for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.
—Mr Deputy Speaker--

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Thomson) agreed to:
That the business of the day be called on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present the report of the interdepartmental working group on Policy of Assistance to Public Libraries. I seek leave to make a statement on that report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members will recall that, on 13 November 1979, the then Minister for Home Affairs informed the House that the Government, in considering the report of the Committee of Inquiry into Public Libraries, had decided to establish an interdepartmental working group to review the current level of library resources and facilities to identify the developments that had taken place since 1976. That working group included the departments of Home Affairs, Prime Minister and Cabinet, Education, Social Security, Science and Technology, and the National Library of Australia, the Schools Commission and the Tertiary Education Commission. The two latter bodies attended later meetings of the working group. The Minister indicated that the review would have regard to the library services currently available at educational institutions and the scope for public access to these and the special library resources and facilities which are available for handicapped persons and proposals for handling any improvements necessary in this field. The Government's decisions have been taken having regard to the recommendations of the working group and the recommendations of the report of the Committee of Inquiry into Public Libraries. The Government has also kept in view its policy of co-operative federalism.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members will be aware that the report of the Committee of Inquiry into Public Libraries-the Horton report-contained 53 recommendations, mostly of State concern. Two of those recommendations called for Commonwealth implementation. Those were:
(a) Commonwealth financial assistance to the States amounting to $20m per annum over 10 years; and
(b) the establishment of a Public Libraries and Information Council to co-ordinate the development of library services and to formulate advice on national policies for development.
The interdepartmental working group put forward several proposals based on those recommendations. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the recommendations of the working group.
Leave granted.
The recommendations read as follows-
1. The Commonwealth support an evaluation of school-community libraries in Australia through the appropriate body, the Schools Commission.

2. The Commonwealth agree to the provision in 1980-81 of additional finance to the extent of $19,000 to the Schools Commission to undertake the evaluation study, over and above its 1980-81 appropriation.

3. The Commonwealth agree in principle to the further development of library services for the handicapped at the national level, the precise requirements for additional staff and finance for the National Library remaining a matter to be determined in the annual budgetary context.
4. In view of the Government's federalism policies, no special funds should be allocated to the States for the provision of public library services.
5. The Commonwealth should play a role in nationwide co-operation and co-ordination of library services. This should be achieved through:

(i) the establishment of an Australian Libraries and Information Council, as proposed by the State Librarians' Council and the National Library of Australia, to be responsible for providing advice to Governments at all levels on the development of library and related information services in Australia, with particular regard to:
(a) the formulation and progressive development of a national plan for the development of library and related information services at the national, state and local government levels; and
(b) the establishment and operation of mechanisms to facilitate resource sharing in the field of libraries and related information services.

(ii) the strengthening of the Advisory Committees of the National Library of Australia and the Network Committees of the National Library to ensure effective co-operation with the Australian Libraries and Information Council; and
(iii) the support at an appropriate level by the National Library of the activities of AACOBS (Australian Advisory Council on Bibliographic Services).
The Government has endorsed all these recommendations. I now turn to specific aspects of the recommendations.
Library Resources Currently Available at Tertiary Educational Institutions and Secondary Schools and the Scope for Public Access to These

The working group's report examined in detail the library resources held in educational institutions in Australia. Holdings of bookstock held by universities in 1978 totalled 12.5 million volumes while 66 of the 73 colleges of advanced education had a total bookstock holding of 5,436,000 volumes in 1978. In this regard, as the working group points out, total holdings are substantially less than for the university sector but some of the large multi-purpose institutions have collections which match the size of some of the more recently established universities. The working group report provides details of recurrent expenditure in 1978 on library resources in tertiary education institutions. Honourable members will be aware that while universities and colleges and their libraries are fully funded by the Commonwealth Government, the costs of the State technical and further education systems are shared between the Commonwealth and the States. In 1978 total recurrent expenditure on university and CAE libraries was $49,915,000 and $28,442,000 respectively. Estimated recurrent expenditure on TAFE libraries in 1978 was $8,871,000.

Primary and secondary school libraries are funded from a number of sources-the Commonwealth Government, State-Territory governments and the schools themselves, through school councils and parents' associations. Commonwealth Government grants for school libraries are provided through the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act as a notional element of the capital program. The working group report indicates the capital grants to be so provided in 1980 and the amounts which it is expected will be directed to libraries will be for Government schools, $92,722,000 and $9,179,500 respectively and for non-Government schools, $27,858,500 and $3,296,500 respectively. The working group report examined the scope for public access to libraries in educational institutions and concluded that the additional burden which would be placed on both the staff and financial resources of these libraries through increased public access would be too onerous and that the development of this option would not be realistic at this time.

The working group report notes that the provision of library services for joint public-secondary school use does occur in a limited number of cases and in a variety of forms. The report indicates that South Australia, at the time the interdepartmental working group report was submitted to me, was the only State to have published officially accepted guidelines for a program of school-community library development. The working group sees advantages associated with the development of joint school-community library services, but considers that there is a need for a detailed study of this area and hence its recommendation for an evaluation study to be undertaken by the Schools Commission. In this regard, I am advised that the Schools Commission has made an approach to the States with a view to the formation of a management committee, representative of those States which will participate in the evaluation study. The task of the management committee will be to develop the guidelines for the evaluation.
The Special Library Services and Facilities Which Are Available for Handicapped Persons and Proposals for Handling any Improvements Necessary

The working group report notes and endorses the significant initiatives taken by the National Library of Australia in the development of a national policy for the provision of library resources for the handicapped. In this, the International Year of Disabled Persons, it is appropriate that I refer briefly to the initiatives being undertaken by the National Library in the development of library services for print handicapped persons. In 1978, the Library conducted, on behalf of the Working Party on Library Services for the Handicapped, a nation-wide survey into the whole question of meeting the informational, recreational and cultural needs of the print handicapped. In particular, the survey sought views on the structure of library services for handicapped people and an indication of the role that might be played by the National Library, if any, as well as State and local libraries, educational agencies and institutions. The results of the survey formed the basis of a national seminar held at the Library in August 1978. The Library's current program, which was discussed at a second national seminar in May, includes: The development and maintenance of the national union catalogue of library materials for the handicapped; the development and maintenance of a production register of library materials for the handicapped; the provision of other services facilitating co-ordination and co-operation of library programs for the handicapped on a national scale; and the publication of a newsletter.

The second issue of the National Urban Catalogue of Library Materials for the Handicapped, which has been published by the Library, lists 4,000 items in 10 major institutional collections. By December this year, one-third of the total resources of these materials in Australian insitutions-estimated at 35,000 different items-will have been made available for use by service agencies. I might add that the National Library's catalogue is the second such computer-produced listing in the world. Other initiatives include compiling a register of materials being produced for handicapped readers and establishing a national advisory committee on library services for people with disabilities. The aims of the advisory committee are to consider the special needs of handicapped people for library services and to advise the National Library Council on the organisation, development, co-ordination and co-operation of these services.

State governments are sympathetically inclined towards the establishment of advisory committees concerned with library services for the handicapped to ensure co-operation and co-ordination among State, local and voluntary organisations providing library services to handicapped persons and to liaise with the National Library's advisory committee. The governments of Western Australia and Tasmania have already set up such committees. Honourable members will also be aware that the Copyright Amendment Act, which came into effect on 1 August, contains particular provisions which will remove the copyright impediments that have hindered the production of versions of published work for handicapped readers.
As a Result of the Government's Federalism Policies, States and Local Government Have Increased Revenue To Meet Objectives within Their Own Priorities

The report of the inter-departmental working group takes into account the Government's federalism policies and notes the increased funding made available in recent years to States and local government through the income tax sharing Acts and the flexibility available to local government to deteremine its own expenditure priorities. In endorsing the recommendations of the working group, the Government was mindful of the significant increases in tax sharing payments to the States and local authorities. Both the States and local government can look forward to substantial increases in funds provided by the Commonwealth. On the basis of estimated revenue and income tax collections this year, local government's 2 per cent share of personal income tax collections is expected to rise next year by about 19 per cent. In the same way, the States' share of general revenue, based on revenue collection estimates for the current financial year, is expected to rise substantially by some 16 per cent. In other words, States will have substantially increased general revenue funds from which they can meet these important objectives within their own priorities.
Co-operation between Library Services

One of the major recommendations of the Horton report was the establishment of a body to co-ordinate the development of library services in Australia. In its report, the interdepartmental working group referred to the desirability of such a co-ordinating body and also noted that several government inquiries in the 1970s recognised the need for national guidelines in relation to the co-operative co-ordination of library and information policies. The interdepartmental working group supports the view that the Commonwealth Government has a role in the development of co-operation and co-ordination in library services. To this end, the working group supported the proposal by the State Librarians Council and the National Library of Australia for the establishment of an Australian Libraries and Information Council. The Government has agreed to this proposal and it received the unanimous support of Ministers at the February 1981 conference of Ministers having responsibility for cultural affairs and the arts.

The function of the Council is to advise Ministers on means of securing co-operation and co-ordination between the Commonwealth and the States and among the States themselves in the development of library and related information services. The Council would not have a funding role. The membership of the Council will include the Director-General, National Library of Australia, the State librarians and the Director of the Northern Territory Library Service, three nominees of the Commonwealth Minister for Education and one nominee of the Commonwealth Minister for Science and Technology. I will be discussing with my colleague the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) the actual arrangements for the nominations of the three representatives of the education sector. The Government has now approached the State Premiers and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory seeking their respective agreement to the appointment of the State librarians and the Director of the Northern Territory Library Service to the Australian Libraries and Information Council-ALIC, as it is coming to be known.
Conclusion

The provision and co-ordination of information services is one of the great challenges of our time. We live in a complex society in which we are coming to grips with the information revolution. The revolution, opening up all sorts of exciting possibilities with regard to the provision of and access to information from businesses through to our own homes, has coincided with, and has been encouraged by, the rapid expansion and development of new technology. We are acquiring almost daily better and more efficient ways to store, locate and provide information, whether it be for our large companies and businesses, or the latest information about the weather on a teletext link on our own television screens at home. Libraries, traditionally society's store of information, are of course crucially involved in the information revolution, adapting to meet the challenges and demands being placed upon them.

The report of the interdepartmental working group canvasses some of these issues. The interdepartmental working group's examination of public library services in the States in the post-Horton era, shows that there has been a growth in public library services although this varies from State to State. Furthermore, it is evident that the role of the public library is being extended in acknowledgment of community attitudes and needs. Developments in the planning of public library services on a State-wide basis also reflect greater commitment on the part of State library authorities to the improvement, equalisation and extension of public library services. There has been continuing attention to the provision of special library services for clients with special needs, such as ethnic readers, the partially sighted and the blind. State and local libraries have especially supported the development of general information services for local communities which have regard to the needs of ethnic and other groups for information on government welfare and health agencies and activities of clubs and organisations. There has been a move towards greater co-operative action, aided by the development of new technology, which may be seen as a response to the growing need for resource sharing to cope with greater pressures on library budgets due to the rising cost of resources and the increasing and diversified demands on library services.

On the national level, the Government recognises the continuing leadership role of the National Library in the development of library and information services in Australia. The Government acknowledges its responsibility to contribute to this development through its support of the National Library's activities, as well as those of such other agencies as the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, not to mention the libraries at each level of education. In this regard, provision of $17.392m has been made available for the operating expenses of the National Library in 1981-82. Some of the services currently being provided by the National Library to Australian libraries include its central bibliographical service which in 1980-81 filled 800,000 orders for cataloguing information in card and machine-readable form, and made available on micro-film more than one and a half million records from its massive union catalogues. The Library's inter-library loan services also provided approximately 200,000 items from the Library's collections to other institutions.

As I mentioned, the Government recognises that today's society is information orientated and that information services are very much bound up with technological change. In line with this, the Government has endorsed the National Library's proposal to develop an Australian bibliographic network. When developed, the network will enable Australian libraries to consult through the Library's computer the substantial data base of cataloguing information compiled from Australian and overseas sources. Libraries will be able to use this information for their own cataloguing or, when no entry is found, to contribute their own so that it can then be used by others. In addition to enabling libraries throughout Australia to reduce cataloguing costs, and in some instances to reduce them quite significantly, and to avoid unnecessary duplication in the acquisition of library materials, the network could also be developed to take the place of the present national union cataloguing program and to provide libraries with sophisticated reference and acquisition systems. It will also enable State and regional libraries to better support the services of local public libraries and allow smaller libraries better access to the nation's library resources. The potential of such a system is immense and, in terms of library and information services of the nation, it will improve co-ordination and enhance resource sharing to make more effective use of resources in libraries generally.

The Director-General of the National Library has described the proposal to establish the Australian National Bibliographic Network as the most important development that the Library could undertake at present. This proposal, along with the decision to establish the Australian Libraries and Information Council, is indicative of the progress that is being made towards achieving greater co-ordination in the nation's library resources. The Government remains determined to ensure that the information revolution is harnessed to the benefit of the whole community through the gradual development of a more efficient and effective network of libraries in Australia. I commend the report to honourable members. I present the following paper:
Policy on Assistance to Public Libraries-Ministerial Statement, 24 September 1981.
Motion by (Mr McVeigh) proposed:
That the House take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Fraser Government's response to the report of the Horton Committee of Inquiry into Public Libraries is miserable and constitutes a further betrayal of Australia's intellectual resources. This is part of a deliberate policy by the Fraser Government of winding down Australia's intellectual resources as witnessed by the declining numbers of students who complete secondary education, the falling numbers in tertiary institutions, the re-introduction of fees for second degrees, the declining investment in research and development, the ending of the Australian Government Publishing Service bookshops, and the imposition for the first time in Australia's history of a sales tax on books, magazines, periodicals and newspapers. Despite the enthusiastic words of the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson) Australia is not well placed to cope with the information revolution. It is cynical to suggest that these makeshift, cheapskate arrangements referred to in the Minister's statement constitute an effective response to the challenge.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee of Inquiry into Public Libraries was appointed in March 1975 and it reported to the Fraser Government in February 1976 on the shortcomings of Australia's public libraries. The Chairman of the Committee was Mr Allan Horton, the university librarian of the University of New South Wales. He had six other distinguished people on the Committee with him. It is striking that it took them only 11 months to produce the report. It has taken this Government five and a half years to announce its response to the report. This illustrates the enthusiasm it feels for the information revolution. The Horton report recommended total expenditure of $700m over a 10 year period to upgrade book stocks and the means of access so that Australia could come to grips with the information explosion sweeping the Western world. The money provided in the Minister's policy document is not $700m but only $19,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!
—Shame indeed. This $19,000 enables the Schools Commission to carry out a further evaluation of school and community libraries.
—That surely could not be right.
—It is certainly right. The Government's response is a sick joke. The grant provides 0.0000271 per cent of the sums recommended.
—That is unbelievable.

—Quite so. But if we look at the Government's record, it is perfectly consistent. The Minister's statement simply restates the notorious new federalism policy that public and municipal libraries are State responsibilities. If they want to increase their book stocks, the best of British luck to them. They must do it from their own resources. I draw the attention of honourable members to the fundamental recommendations of the report into public libraries of Australia. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the sections on guidelines and the role of public libraries.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
SUMMARY OF CONCLUSIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS
The Committee recommends that:
Guidelines
(Recommendation 1) The following broad guidelines should be accepted as a basis for a program of assistance to public libraries in Australia:

(a) the provision of public library and information services should be the collective responsibility of the Commonwealth, State and local levels of government, funded in part by each of these levels of government;
(b) the provision of equality of service on the basis of reasonable need should be ensured by the Commonwealth and State Governments;
(c) the provision of public library and information services should be free of charge to all members of the community;

(d) the provision of total library service cannot be achieved by any one type or unit of library or information service, but only by the co-operative efforts of all types of information agencies working towards a commonly accepted and planned system;

(e) the expansion and extension of individual library and information services should be achieved through co-operation, and/or contract and the formation of library systems and networks, with each service retaining its autonomy within the overall State plan for the development of these services;

(f) the integration of these State systems and networks into a national network should be ensured by the Commonwealth Government in consultation with State Governments, with the Commonwealth Government giving highest priority in assistance to State Governments who demonstrate effective plans to develop a State system and networks;

(g) the further development of the informational role of the public library should be given priority by funding authorities and the library profession, while at the same time the recreational and educational role should not be diminished;
(h) the participation of users in marketing, developing or extending public library service should actively be encouraged by State and local authorities;

(i) the improvements of public library service is dependent on the clarification of the role of the public library, the assessment of user needs, the education programs for staff, the provision of increased resource materials, the introduction of new methods and management techniques and the provision of support services.
(4.12) Role of Public Libraries

(Recommendation 2) Public libraries should consider the relevance of each of the following functions of libraries when planning library and information service for the people of their specific communities:
as a source of recreational material for reading, listening and viewing, related to the people's interests whatever they are;
as a source for information useful to people in their day to day living;
as a source of advice to people about community, local, regional, State and Commonwealth government activities;
as a point of referral when people are in doubt as to which group or organisation to approach in connection with a probem;
as a source of material for people's vocational continuing education either directly or by arrangement with specialised services provided by regions, State or Commonealth government libraries;
as a source of material for people's life-long education.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The major point is this: The report stresses that there must be the provision of a quality of service on the basis of reasonable needs which should be ensured by Commonwealth and State governments. The provision of public library and information services should be the collective responsibility of the Commonwealth, State and local levels of government funded in part by each of these levels of government. The report speaks about the integration of State systems and networks into a national network. It is true the word 'network' appears once in the very last words of the Minister's statement. He says: 'Let the network be funded by the already existing resources available to the State and local government'.
—A very thin net!

—It is so thin that the nation may fall through it. Let us look at the response in the document tabled today entitled 'Policy on Assistance to Public Libraries', submitted by the interdepartmental working group to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. It gives the game away. Page 1 points out that the Horton report had two major recommendations. They are as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) Commonwealth financial assistance to the States amounting to $20 million per annum over 10 years;
That is in 1976 money; and
(b) establishment of a Public Libraries Information Council to co-ordinate the development of library services and to formulate advice on national policies for this development.
The first part, which is the most important part, is rejected. The second part is adopted, but we are told that the PLIC will have no funding powers. The report continues:

Furthermore, the Horton report estimated that in order to implement the programs proposed by the States to bring public libraries in Australia to a reasonable standard a total amount would be needed at State and local levels of approximately $500 million or $50 million per annum over a ten year period.
On page 3 the report continues:

At the outset, the Working Group noted that the provision of public library services is constitutionally and historically the responsibility of State and local government. In giving consideration to this basic issue the Working Group was required to bring forward any proposed action against a background of the Commonwealth's federalism policies.

In other words, the working group said: 'Look, let us face it, the game is up. Under the new federalism you are not going to get anything. If you are going to raise the standard of State and municipal libraries, the States will have to fund it themselves. That is really the end of it'. Again, we note the extraordinary situation of how the provision of public library services and the book stocks have fallen very dramatically behind the universities. We do not want to downgrade the importance of university libraries, but if we really want to bring the benefits of the information revolution to everybody, as the Minister has stated, we have to maximise the access to information by ordinary citizens. The public library traditionally and historically has been the great place of access for the ordinary citizen who wants to increase his own knowledge, to improve his own competence, to familiarise himself with things that are unfamiliar to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't want the ordinary people to have access to libraries.

—Of course the Government does not. It still sees access in absolutely elitist terms. That is the tragedy of it all. That is why this is such a hollow and cynical document. It is very striking that the total number of books that are provided in State libraries throughout Australia is only of the order of 5,896,000; in municipal libraries the figure is 18,720,000. Those libraries will include an infinite number of sets of the complete works of Enid Blyton and so on. Quite correctly, there will be an enormous number of children's books, but there will be a great deal of duplication which will not add a great deal to the intellectual resources of the Commonwealth. University libraries have over 11 million books and colleges of advanced education over 5 million books. It is difficult to see whether there is any provision for reading at all in the technical and further education institutions. The working group's report says that:

SPEECH.PARA: 340 of the 487 TAFE institutions in Australia in 1978 had no library at all. Even those libraries that do exist range from an acceptable level of provision down to very small holdings.

The Minister says: 'That is all right. We will solve the problem. This year we will kick in $19,000, not $700m'. I say that it is a sham and the Opposition is appalled by the poverty of the response we are getting. On page 63 the report states:
The Government's federalism policies have had an all pervasive influence on the Working Group's approach to the financial recommendations of the Horton report.

You can say that again. The working group took account of the political climate in which the Horton recommendations were brought down and the changes in government policy and the approach of the States since that time. It is thumbs down all the way. What the Minister said is correct: We face an information revolution. That is something I have talked about, it seems almost interminably, from this side of the House. James Martin and Adrian Norman, in their book the Computerised Society wrote:

. . . the sum total of human knowledge changed very slowly prior to the relatively recent beginnings of scientific thought. It has been estimated that by 1800 it was doubling every 50 years; by 1950, doubling every 10 years; and that presently it is doubling every five years. One wonders how long this acceleration can continue. Computer technology may make a frighteningly high rate of increase possible for centuries.

The Government's response is to say: 'Do not worry. We are almost, but not quite, keeping up with inflation'. What about the book stocks? The Government says: 'Well no, we are not able to provide adequate money to put up for replacement level on the basis that you have to get rid of 12.5 per cent of your book stock every year'. In no way is this government response adequate to deal with the information explosion. The US National Academy of Sciences estimated that in the early 1970s about two million scientific writings were published every year, that is 8,000 for each of 250 working days. It said that this figure would quadruple by 1985. George Anderla wrote a very important study called Information in 1985. A Forecasting Study of Information Needs and Resources which was published by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. Professor Anderla noted:
The figure of 8 million scientific documents yearly put into circulation in 1985 as against two million in 1970 must be considered as a conservative forecast.
A mere continuation of the present tendency-
He wrote this of the years 1967 to 1971-

would produce a total of some 13 to 14 million per year, i.e. equivalent to the stock accumulated since the origins of science until the present day. A projection midway between these figures would seem fairly reasonable.
The mathematician, Stanislaw Ulam, found that in the 1970s about 200,000 new theorems were published each year in mathematical journals and decided that this was something to worry about. He said:
If the number of theorems is larger than one can possibly survey, who can be trusted to judge what is 'important'?
The Government is standing still on a descending escalator.

TALK.START.PARA: —We should send the Minister to a library.

—Every member, not just the Minister, could benefit by the use of libraries. I think it is tragic that the response of the Government is so pathetically inadequate. It must change. If the Minister is earnest in trying to adopt some of the best elements of the Horton report-I would like to think he was sympathetic-much more has to be done. Of course, we welcome some things in the Minister's statement, for example that special library services and facilities will be made available for handicapped persons. That is long overdue; it ought to be done. But there are not very many good things in the report. We are glad that the Australian Libraries and Information Council has been set up but essentially it is toothless. It is a mere aggregation of public servants. It will have no money. There will be no responsibility on it to report to the public and there is no reason to assume that it will. ALIC will be completely dominated by public servants. It is difficult to see that it will in its own way make much of a contribution to Australia's information revolution.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister's definition of the information revolution and the examples he gave in his speech were extraordinarily narrow. He referred to the information revolution in a purely economic and commercial context. There was no hint of raising levels of consciousness or widening personal horizons. Access to information was seen in a very limited way. The Government said that people would have access to information from businesses to find out what is happening in large companies and the latest information about the weather. In other words, presumably people will find out whether to go out and buy an umbrella and a raincoat or whether to buy a sunhat and shorts. That is the view the Government has of the information revolution. The Minister said:
On the national level, the Government recognises the continuing leadership role of the National Library in the development of library and information services in Australia.

What is the situation? The National Library has had a 2 1/2 per cent reduction in staff this year. It has had an 8 per cent increase in its annual vote but in real terms, when we take inflation into account and the enormous increase in the cost of books, that is a very severe cut. Books have increased in price on average by 24 per cent over the last year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Plus the sales tax.

—There is also the sales tax of 2 1/2 per cent. Presumably libraries will be able to receive exemption but it is a tragic situation.
