In the nineteenth century some of Australia's public libraries were regarded as among the best in the world. The Melbourne Public Library, or the State Library of Victoria as it is now known, had one of the best collections of books in the world in the nineteenth century. It kept very much up to date with current publishing. Now our libraries, relative to the enormous flow of information and the exponential increase in publications, are falling far behind. They have a token access to the books available that are published overseas. That is tragic. It puts Australia right down the chute. I urge the Government to look again at the Horton report. Instead of producing this pious collection of cliches, it should make sure that the information revolution really does work. It should recognise that the new federalism is intensely destructive to Australia's intellectual base. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the proposal the Labor Party will advance for a national information policy. That is something we need.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
National Information Policy
A National Information Policy shall provide that:

1. All Australians are entitled to free access to information and library services of acceptable standard relative to the affluence of the State, regardless of where they live, of their social and economic position, of their language, their age, their mobility, or physical disabilities.

2. The effective working of democracy depends on the availability of adequate information and the capacity for its independent evaluation. The right to know, to be informed, is basic to every person. Access to information and the right to its availability should be vigorously pursued. In our society, access to information is a vital resource of government and of the public, and like other resources it should not be concentrated in the hands of the rich.

3. The Australian community is divided between the 'information rich', and the 'information poor'. Women, migrants, the aged, the young, the poor and the handicapped are victims of inadequacies in the information delivery system. Information facilities are remote from those who need them most. They do not know what is available and do not know how to remedy their lack of information.

4. The enormous inequity in 'information transfer' means that the position of the individual compared to governments and corporations may deteriorate rapidly. The increasing volume of available information may lead to:
(i) increasing tendency towards specialisation and the fragmentation of knowledge
(ii) a growing sense of 'alienation' or 'anomie' from many people who feel unable to understand what is going on around them, and
(iii) a risk that power will move towards the technocrats and away from elected institutions such as Parliaments.

5. Information problems should not continue to be treated in the narrow perspective of science and technology, and left to scientists and experts alone, but should be envisaged in the broader context of knowledge and social welfare in which information is regarded as a fundamental resource.

6. Governments must not allow automated systems and networks to develop in a chaotic fashion for strictly commercial motives. They must understand and plan for the new technologies which will come into general use everywhere in the next ten years.
7. As recommended in the Coombs Report on Government Administration, a Commonwealth Information Advisory Council should be set up to define and codify:
(i) the right of access of individuals or public or private bodies to this information resource and the inherent limits to this right:
(ii) the political and social guarantees which individuals and institutions can legitimately expect, including protection of privacy and professional secrecy;
(iii) the basic rules of reciprocity which should govern relationships between public and private systems and networks;
(iv) a code of ethics for professions and industries concerned in this field.
8. The provision of public library and information services should remain the collective responsibility of the Commonwealth, State and local levels of Government, funded in part by each of these.

9. Public libraries must become information resource centres including local data banks, information about access to government services, with greater emphasis on non-book material such a gramophone records, tapes, cassettes, microforms and audio-visual material generally.

10. The expansion and extension of all library and information services should be achieved through co-operation and/or contract and the formation of library systems and networks with each service retaining its autonomy within the overall State plan for the development of these services. Already existing information services should be co-ordinated and integrated to avoid duplication and waste of resources.
Debate (on motion by Mr Hodges) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF COMMONWEALTH OFFICE BUILDING, TOWNSVILLE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Construction of a Commonwealth office building, Townsville, Queensland.

The proposal is for an office building which will replace existing widely dispersed accommodation and consolidate most Commonwealth activities in a central location in Townsville. The building will accommodate 600 people and the works will comprise three floors of office accommodation, a basement providing storage areas and secure parking for official vehicles, site landscaping and an open car parking area.

In reporting favourably on the proposal, the Committee also made certain recommendations and comments. Firstly, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority will be a tenant in the building as recommended by the Committee. The Committee sought a report on the future of the old Customs House. An interim report has been made to the Committee. For the present the Customs Bureau will continue to operate from the old Customs House. However, the appropriateness of this arrangement will be kept under review.

A further recommendation was that there be liaison with local authorities to determine whether the building should, in whole or in part, be designated and constructed as a cyclone shelter. Discussions have taken place with State counter-disaster authorities and it has been agreed that the Commonwealth will make the basement of the building available for use as a cyclone refuge area. Detailed arrangements on access and security have yet to be finalised. The Committee called on the Government to clarify its policy on car parking to ensure, where possible, that the Commonwealth complies with local by-law provisions. Government policy is that each project should be considered on its merits, taking into account various constraints including car parking and other requirements of local planning authorities. Wherever practicable there is compliance with the local authority requirements in a spirit of co-operation.

In the case of the Commonwealth office building at Townsville a compromise was reached in discussions with the Council which facilitated the design of a building in harmony with the civic precinct of Townsville. The Committee in paragraph 37 of its report suggests that in future departments consider more fully the economies of accelerating completion of construction of projects and that such considerations be reflected in the departmental evidence. Note has been taken of this suggestion for adoption where appropriate in future references. At the same time I point out that overall budgetary considerations largely determine priorities and timing of commencement of individual proposals. In the case of the Townsville offices the date for commencement of the project will be considered in the context of the 1982-83 Budget.

Finally the Committee expresses an option that further consideration should be given to the provision of food services in the building. This has been done but no such provision is proposed. The estimated cost of the proposal examined by the Committee was $8.7m at August 1980 prices. The Committee recommended construction of the work in the reference. If the House agrees to support this motion, detailed planning can proceed in accordance with the recommendations of the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dean Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly in support of the motion. The question of a new Commonwealth office building in Townsville is one which I raised with the Government soon after I was first elected to this Parliament early in 1978. It is a project that I have pursued fairly vigorously since then. The problem is that in Townsville accommodation for various sections of the Commonwealth Public Service is diverse in nature, scattered, and often sub-standard. All of those matters were dealt with, of course, by the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and have been reported on.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government made a commitment to go ahead with this building some 18 months to 2 years ago. After that, the matter was referred to the Public Works Committee. An inquiry was held and the Public Works Committee, of course, recommended in favour of the building. Then came the announcement that no funds would be provided for the building in the current financial year.

That announcement was greeted by me and by the Townsville community with a good deal of alarm and disappointment. We felt that a commitment had been made to construct the building and we could demonstrate that the building was needed. Then, of course, a decision was made to defer it as far as the 1981-82 financial year was concerned.

It is, therefore, heartening that the Government now sees fit to move this motion that it is indeed expedient to carry out the works. This means that all the detailed planning and design work can proceed unhindered. If funds are provided in the 1982-83 financial year and all the detailed design and document work has been completed there ought to be no great delay in starting on the building. It is that course of action that I urge upon the Government.

The only other comment I would like to make relates to the future of the old Customs House in Townsville. It is a very fine historical and very good looking building. It is a building that, to some extent, is inefficient in terms of its use by the Bureau of Customs. Yet, of course, it has the advantage of providing that Bureau with a single base of operations. My preference would be to see the Customs Bureau take advantage of facilities in the new building. There might then be a question of what to do with the old building which, as far as an office building is concerned, is expensive to maintain and, as I have said, somewhat inefficient in terms of its size. I have said also that it is a very fine looking building, well situated on the Strand in Townsville. It is my view that the building would be eminently suited to being put aside to some public use, perhaps as a North Queensland museum or a branch of the Queensland museum.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps an art gallery?

—We already have an art gallery. The honourable member for Griffith is a little bit behind the times as far as Townsville is concerned. Certainly a museum would be an admirable use for it. I am sure that the honourable member for Griffith would agree with me on that. Because of the cost of continually maintaining the building, and because the Customs Bureau could otherwise be well accommodated in the new building it seems to me that it would be preferable for Customs to go to the new building and, therefore, for the Government to consider making available this grand old historic building for public and community use. I support the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: GARDEN ISLAND, NEW SOUTH WALES, MODERNISATION STAGE 2

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Garden Island, New South Wales, Modernisation stage 2.

This proposal is for the second stage of an overall modernisation program which is aimed at improving the effectiveness and efficiency of the Dockyard and the fleet base. The Committee has recommended the construction of the various facilities included in the reference except for the surface preparation and preservation facility and oily bilge waste treatment plant. The facilities which are the subject of this motion comprise: Woolloomooloo fleet berth wharves; West Dock workshop modules 'B' and 'C'; guided missile launching system overhaul facility; conversion of building 30 to a ready-use store; conversion of buildings 89 and 90 to an office complex; production administrative centre and dock refit berth support facility; groundworks; and reticulated engineering services. In respect of the surface preparation and preservation facility and oily bilge waste treatment plant, the Committee has recommended that they be deferred and referred back to the Committee for separate consideration. The Government accepts this recommendation and I foreshadow that in due course I will propose a further motion to refer these facilities to the Committee for separate consideration and report.

I wish to bring to the attention of honourable members the fact that the liquid trade waste plant was considered and endorsed by the Committee as part of the stage one modernisation works, but was to be housed together with the facilities which are now to be referred back to the Committee. In view of this there will be no action taken on the liquid waste treatment plant until the Committee has reported on the surface preparation and preservation facility and oily bilge waste treatment plant.

The Committee has recommended that there be a design development provision of $1m and that the justification of a further $1.5m design development provision proposed by the Department of Housing and Construction be examined when the surface preparation and preservation facility and oily bilge waste treatment plant are referred back to the Committee. The Government notes the Committee's recommendation and further justification will be provided.

In the body of the report the Committee has drawn attention to the fact that there is as yet no agreement between the Commonwealth, the State and the Council of the City of Sydney on financial arrangements for providing and maintaining the public park on the roof of the carpark. The Committee reaffirmed its view that the State and the City Council should be financially involved. The Commonwealth is pursuing this matter with both the State and the Council and has received a proposal from the Council to contribute to maintenance subject to the State Government also becoming involved.

During the Committee's hearing, a number of undertakings were given on the treatment to be accorded historic buildings and machinery at Garden Island. The Government will ensure that appropriate action is taken. The Committee requested that further discussions be held with the Council of the City of Sydney regarding an alternative site for Harry's Cafe de Wheels. This will be done and I understand that a new site will be suggested to the Council.

In paragraph 74, the Committee has noted that no further works are planned for construction until 1988 at the earliest. There could, however, be a need to undertake further work before 1988 to meet operational requirements. In paragraph 69, the Committee has noted that careful management of the project will be required to minimise disruption to both dockyard and construction activity while the work proceeds. Appropriate management controls will be exercised.

Finally, I note that the Committee has commended the attention being paid to environmental aspects and to the preservation of historic buildings at Garden Island. With the deletion of the surface preparation and preservation facility and oily bilge waste treatment plant the estimated cost of the proposal recommended by the Committee is $75.4m at April 1981 prices, inclusive of a design development provision of $1m.

Except for the surface preparation and preservation facility and oily bilge waste treatment plant, the Committee recommended construction of the work in the reference and if the house agrees to support this motion detailed planning can proceed in accordance with the recommendations of the Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Armoured centre redevelopment, Puckapunyal, Victoria.

This proposal is for the consolidation of new and refurbished facilities into an integrated complex for training, administration and accommodation. The works will comprise: A headquarters and instructional building; driving and servicing training facilities; a technical support building; a Q-store and guard complex; sleeping accommodation; new and refurbished mess facilities; refurbishing of tank hangars; a parade ground, roads, carparks; and engineering services.

In reporting favourably on the proposal the Committee has made certain other recommendations and comments. Firstly, the Committee has recommended that the Department of Defence in conjunction with the Department of Home Affairs and Environment review the methods of disposal for all pollutant substances throughout Australia to ensure its practices are in accordance with the requirements of existing legislation and relevant local authorities.

The Department of Defence already makes efforts to ensure that its methods of disposing of pollutant substances accord with the requirements of existing legislation, relevant local authorities or community standards. In regard to any new works, statutory or other requirements are taken into account by the Department of Defence and the Department of Housing and Construction. This includes the reference of works to the Department of Home Affairs and Environment for advice on their possible impact on the environment. The Department of Defence will take note of the Committee's recommendation and take action where appropriate.

In the body of the report, the Committee has indicated that it believes a pollution problem has been allowed to develop through the use of waste oils for laying dust in range areas. Only a small amount of the waste oil produced at Puckapunyal is used to suppress dust. Where it is used it is confined to a small area. There is no evidence that the small quantities of waste oil sprayed in such situations have significantly harmed the environment. Pasture grasses in the general area discourage run off, and assist bacterial decomposition of the oil; river monitoring stations have not indicated any oil flowing out of the Puckapunyal catchment area; oil from the centre is not contaminated by lead; the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, which is Defence's consultant on environmental aspects of managing this and other training areas, has not specifically commented on the spraying of oil at Puckapunyal to suppress dust.

The Committee expressed concern that the environmental approval for this project was issued at a time when the Department of Defence was not ready to put a proposal for the full work. The Department of Home Affairs and Environment concluded in 1977 that the proposed works at Puckapunyal would have no significant impact on the environment. Further design development of the works since then has not significantly affected their general nature or intended use. At paragraph 33 of its report the Committee indicates concern that waste water from the tank hangars might pollute the stormwater system. Interceptor traps have in fact been included in the project to ensure that this does not occur. Also in the body of the report the Committee notes its conern at the delay in upgrading kitchen and mess facilities. To this I can say only that overall budgetary considerations largely determine priorities and thus the timing of commencement of individual proposals.

Finally the Committee has commended the efforts of those who have developed and maintained the Armoured Corps Museum. It has also recommended that the Department of Defence should, in conjunction with the Australian War Memorial, begin planning for the eventual reconstruction of the museum on a new site at Puckapunyal. Defence is developing its policy towards military museums in the context of the Government's general policy on museums. Buildings suitable for the armoured corps' museum are expected to become available at Puckapunyal after the works proposed there are completed. The estimated cost of the proposal when examined by the Committee was $12m at May 1981 prices. The Committee recommended construction of the work in the reference. If the House agrees to support this motion, detailed planning can proceed in accordance with the recommendations of the Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fry Mr K.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, I present the Committee's report on energy use, distribution and conservation in the Australian Capital Territory, together with copies of the transcript of evidence and the minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The report I have just tabled deals with the subject of energy in the Australian Capital Territory. Availability and distribution of energy supplies are important and complex issues for governments everywhere and the last decade has seen major shifts in the patterns of usage and availability of certain primary sources of fuel. This has resulted in the growth of conservation movements and the realisation that present energy resources are exhaustible and costly unless attempts are made to examine alternative solutions to present problems and to develop long term strategies for more efficient energy use and distribution.

SPEECH.PARA: Within the Australian Capital Territory there have been numerous disruptions to petrol supplies as a result of industrial disputes. While these short term disruptions have caused inconvenience to local residents, they have also served to indicate long term consequences of such disruptions. It is generally acknowledged that Australia is richly endowed with a range of energy sources. However, the question of access to supplies of petroleum is one which looms large in the future for all Australians, particularly given the dependence on oil of the society of which Canberra is a part. It was against this background of short term disruptions to petrol supplies as well as the long term outlook for the availability of energy that this inquiry was undertaken.

This report is the result of a concentrated period of work by the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory. The terms of reference for the inquiry were referred to the Committee in the previous Parliament. The Committee was unable to complete the inquiry in the life of the thirty-first Parliament and requested that the inquiry be referred to the Committee again in the thirty-second Parliament. During the life of the inquiry the Committee received over 60 submissions and held several public hearings in Canberra, Sydney, Melbourne and Adelaide. In addition, the Committee held informal discussions with State authorities and conducted several days of inspections and examined several energy research facilities.

In this report the Committee has paid particular attention to energy conservation since it considers this issue to be of particular importance. A special chapter has also been devoted to the issue of energy research, particularly the suitability of Canberra as a centre for such research. The remaining chapters deal with the terms of reference of the inquiry and recommendations have been made on each of these. One chapter deals with petrol prices as the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) has indicated that he expects the Committee to comment on this issue.

It has been suggested that the introduction of natural gas in the Australian Capital Territory will lead to a diversion of demand from petroleum to natural gas and that there will also be increases of consumption of energy from alternate sources. However, petroluem will continue to be the main source of energy in the immediate future. In regard to the adequacy of petroleum delivery, distribution and storage in the Australian Capital Territory, the Committee concludes that there is around fifteen days' supply of petrol for private requirements and three weeks for Government requirements. In addition, the storage capacity for bus networks is around two months' supply.

To cover disruptions to supplies, the Committee has recommended that steps be taken to redraft the Fuels Control Ordinance and that the fuels use advisory committee be formally established. Supply of petrol to the private motorist should be available at the service station and the Committee has recommended that, rather than freeze all fuel stocks during an emergency, only a certain percentage of stock be retained for emergency service. This petrol should be purchased by the authorities or at least compensation should be provided to the service station owner for the costs involved in storing the fuel. Such a procedure would encourage service station operators to obtain and sell petrol rather than placing a complete ban on such sales. During times of emergency the Committee would support a system of rationing fuel to private motorists on the basis of odd and even number plates and the setting of a maximum amount of petrol able to be purchased at any one time. The Committee has also examined the question of petrol prices and the apparent disparity in prices charged for petrol in the Australian Capital Territory and surrounding areas of New South Wales and has recommended that the Minister for the Capital Territory take immediate measures to eliminate the petrol pricing differential between the Australian Capital Territory and New South Wales.

The Committee believes Canberra is ideally placed as an energy research centre and supports reseach currently being carried out by the Australian National University and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation into areas of alternative sources of energy and fuel. The question of energy conservation by means of electric vehicles has been considered in some detail and the Committee has recommended an electric vehicle trial for the Australian Capital Territory. Such a trial was proposed by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and endorsed by other organisations.

In the area of energy conservation, the Committee has been informed of the establishment of energy information centres in Sydney and Melbourne as well as a proposed centre in Adelaide. Both the Australian Capital Territory Electricity Authority and the Australian Gaslight Company have indicated their support for such a centre and the Committee considers its establishment of crucial importance to energy conservation in the Territory. The Committee has considered the question of energy conservation under several headings. It would appear that the main avenue for conservation is in the area of transport. At present, the principal method of transport is the private car and the Committee has suggested that the registration system by revised to encourage cars with smaller engine capacity. The role of the public transport system has been noted, particularly that the level of subsidy to the bus service compares favourably with other capital cities. The encouragement of cycling has also been suggested. The Committee has noted recent improvements to the rail service between Canberra and Sydney and has indicated that priority be given to a feasibility study currently being undertaken on a proposed railway link between Canberra and Gunning. As a greater incentive to encourage rail travel as air fares continue to increase, the Committee recommends that the Government expedite the provision of XPT trains on the Canberra to Sydney link.

Under the heading of 'Conservation and Housing' the Committee has suggested that residents need to be more aware of steps that can be taken to reduce energy consumption. This could be achieved by the publication of a pamphlet outlining steps that may be taken. As a further measure to increase general awareness about energy conservation in housing the Committee has recommended that annual prizes be awarded for designs which take account of energy conservation criteria. The divided responsiblity for energy conservation in Commonwealth buildings is also commented on in some detail. The Committee recommends the establishment of a special task force to carry out energy audits in government buildings and further recommends that high priority be given to energy efficiency and conservation in the design of Australian Capital Territory school buildings.

In summing up the conclusions to this report I am conscious of the importance of energy consumption and conservation. Of particular significance is the Committee's proposal to establish an energy information centre which would act as an advisory and promotional body and could play a major role in determining future energy use and availability in the Australian Capital Territory. I believe that it is possible to overcome some of the present shortcomings and adopt a co-ordinated approach to the conservation issues highlighted in the report and that some of the measures proposed in the report can be of direct personal benefit as well as benefiting the general community.

In conclusion, I express my thanks to the staff of the Committee for the dedicated work they put into the report. I also advise the House that the Minister has apologised for not being here when the report was tabled. He has commitments in the Cabinet but he has assured me that he will be giving attention to the report and will be discussing it with the Committee at an early stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I welcome this report by the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Australian Capital Territory into energy and I congratulate the Committee for the excellent report it has produced. Before I make any specific comments on that report, I would like to pay tribute to the work done on this report by the former Chairman of this Committee, the late Senator John Knight. Senator Knight was, in fact, the Chairman of this Committee for the great majority of the time it was deliberating on this subject. I think that special tribute should be paid to him for the contribution he made to this report.

SPEECH.PARA: The inquiry reviewed existing sources of energy, the outlook for the future, conservation measures and initiatives which might be taken by the Government in its territorial and municipal role to encourage and facilitate energy conservation measures. The inquiry also provided an assessment of the adequacy of delivery, distribution and storage facilities for petroleum and related products in the Australian Capital Territory. I particularly welcome recommendation No. 6, which states:
The Committee recommends that the Minister for the Capital Territory take immediate measures to eliminate the petrol pricing differential between the ACT and NSW.

Last December I presented the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) with a detailed submission recommending that the maximum wholesale and retail price of petrol in the Australian Capital Territory be declared items under the Prices Regulation Ordinance 1949. It has been apparent for some time that Canberra motorists have been paying higher prices for their petrol than their counterparts in Queanbeyan, even though the bulk of the petrol comes from the same Sydney wholesale source and on the same train.

Both government departments and the oil companies treat the Australian Capital Territory as an integral part of the New South Wales geographical and economic sphere. This was emphasised by the submission of the Department of Transport to the Committee on 12 May 1980 in relation of policy development and future energy supplies. This was also stressed by the oil companies in their submission to the Committee on 30 July 1980 in relation to the marketing and distribution of petroleum products. Yet we still find that Canberra motorists have to pay more for their petrol. It is clearly inconsistent that, for the purpose of Government policy development and commercial marketing and distribution practices, the situation in the Australian Capital Territory is regarded as consistent with that in New South Wales, but that for the purposes of pricing a superficial boundary is drawn which disadvantages Australian Capital Territory consumers. I am glad that the Committee saw the sense of trying to keep the price of petrol in New South Wales in line with that in the Australian Capital Territory. Australian Capital Territory consumers are clearly paying more for petrol than those in other capitals. The submission of the Australian Bureau of Statistics to the Committee on 30 July 1980 indicates a marked price differential which disadvantages Canberra residents. The Department of the Capital Territory, in its submission to the Prices Justification Tribunal inquiry last year into petrol prices, stated:
In the absence of competition demanding significant discounting by oil companies, both oil companies and retailers are earning greater margins from Canberra than other cities.

In my submission to the Minister last December, I estimated that the cost of higher Canberra petrol prices to the person completing an average mileage per year could be as high as $147.50 per year. There has been little change to the pricing differential in Canberra and Queanbeyan petrol sales during this year and Australian Capital Territory consumers continue to subsidise cheaper petrol in the States.

Evidence was given to the Committee that 73 per cent of the energy consumed in the Australian Capital Territory is derived from petroleum products. Higher petrol prices combined with high usage of petroleum fuels-above the national average-indicate that the Australian Capital Territory consumer is paying dearly for this essential commodity. The cost of transporting petrol to the Australian Capital Territory is frequently given as the reason for the higher prices. But that is not supported by the evidence available, as the petroleum products subsidy scheme ensures that consumers in all rural areas of New South Wales do not pay more than 0.4c per litre of the freight cost. The Committee concluded:

No evidence was given to the Committee to substantiate a difference in wholesale price between NSW and the ACT. This situation is affecting the viability of some service stations and disadvantaging consumers in the ACT.

Clearly, Canberra motorists should not have to pay higher prices for petrol than motorists in New South Wales. Last December I asked the Minister for the Capital Territory to remedy this inequitable situation as a matter of urgency. The Minister replied to that submission that he could not give a categorical reply until this Committee had brought down its report. We have that report before the parliament today, and we have a clear recommendation from that Committee that the price of petrol in the Australian Capital Territory should be related to that in New South Wales. I hope the Minister will take note of this Committee's recommendation and act on it immediately to rectify this disadvantage to Australian Capital Territory consumers. I have urged for more than 18 months that this action be taken and the parliamentary Committee has now made exactly the same recommendation.

I turn briefly to the issue of public transport. It is apparent to all of us that in view of the need to conserve energy the long term goal will be to move people from using private vehicles to using public transport. At present, there are few incentives to attract people to use public transport, particularly in the Australian Capital Territory. Intracity transport in Canberra is comprised of an extensive bus network. The Department of the Capital Territory, along with other organisations, has stated that buses are a much more energy efficient mode of transport than private cars. I hope that the Minister for the Capital Territory will take note of the recommendation of the Action for Public Transport group that a special off-peak fare be provided to ensure greater usage of buses in the Australian Capital Territory during that off-peak period, particularly by pensioners and unemployed people.

In relation to intercity travel, it is apparent that Government policies have driven up air fares beyond the reach of ordinary travellers. Since April, Canberra air fares on the most travelled Canberra-Sydney route have risen by 46 per cent. Needless to say, passenger numbers have dropped dramatically. It is apparent that a fast, efficient rail service is the most effective, energy saving alternative. At present the train journey to Sydney takes up to six hours and is not a viable alternative for most families, business or tourist travellers. I was very pleased to see a recommendation of this Committee that the Government give priority to the feasibility study being undertaken on a possible railway link from Canberra to Gunning and a further recommendation that the Government expedite the provision of an XPT rail service between Canberra and Sydney. I hope the Minister takes immediate action on that recommendation. I commend the report to the Government. Before I conclude I, too, give my thanks to the members and also to the staff of the Committee for this very comprehensive report.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr McVeigh, for Mr Viner, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to make a number of changes to the Judges' Pensions Act 1968 to bring the Act more up to date. The Bill makes three basic changes. First, pensions now based on Australian Industrial Court and Federal Court of Bankruptcy salaries are to be based on Federal Court of Australia salaries. Secondly, pensions in respect of children of deceased judges, currently based wholly or in part on fixed annual amounts determined in 1968, are to become a percentage of the pension that would have been payable to the deceased judge. Thirdly, judges who are required to retire before serving the 10 year qualifying period will be entitled to pro rata pensions after seven years' service.

A number of former judges and dependants of former judges are now in receipt of pensions based on the salaries payable to judges of the Australian Industrial Court. The transfer of the jurisdiction of that Court to the Federal Court of Australia has, for all practical purposes, been completed and the plain fact is that the Australian Industrial Court no longer has any real business. Parliament has already provided for the Court to be abolished when there are no judges of the Court holding office. It is not appropriate that pensions should continue to be based on salaries payable to judges of a court that is now virtually obsolete. The Bill provides for pensions based on the salaries payable to judges of the Australian Industrial Court to be based on the salaries payable to judges of the Federal Court of Australia which has taken over the jurisdiction that Court previously exercised. This will also have the effect of restoring, for pension purposes, the relativity that existed until 1977 between judges of the Australian Industrial Court and presidential members of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Provision is similarly made for pensions based on salaries payable to judges of the Federal Court of Bankruptcy to be based on the salaries payable to judges of the Federal Court of Australia which has taken over all new bankruptcy jurisdiction previously exercised by the Federal Court of Bankruptcy.

The pensions payable under the Act in respect of the children of deceased judges are based wholly or in part on fixed annual amounts. The amounts were set in 1968 and have not been increased. They are now clearly inadequate. By way of example, the pension payable in respect of a child who is not an orphan is only $208 per annum. Moreover, fixed annual amounts are no longer an appropriate basis for pension entitlements. Accordingly, the Bill provides for increased pensions in respect of the children of a deceased judge based on a percentage of the pension that would have been payable to the judge.

The Judges' Pension Act provides for a 10 year qualifying period for entitlement to pension. That requirement was introduced at a time when federal judges enjoyed life tenure. As a result of the 1977 Constitution alteration relating to the retirement of judges, a compulsory retiring age now applies to new federal judicial appointments. In the case of the Family Court of Australia, Parliament has fixed 65 years as the retiring age. For the other federal courts the retiring age is 70 years. As the Act now stands, a judge appointed at an age at which he is not able to complete 10 years service is not entitled to any pension at all when he retires on reaching retiring age. It is the Government's view that 10 years should continue to be the normal qualifying period for retirement on full pension but that judges who have served at least seven years and are forced to retire because of the compulsory retiring age requirements should receive a pension entitlement on a pro rata basis. The Bill also updates references to certain former Papua New Guinea judges for whose pensions the Commonwealth is responsible and makes provision for application to be made to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for review of certain decisions of the Attorney-General under the Act. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Willis) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr McVeigh, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is the first of a package of four Bills that I am introducing today for the purpose of authorising the imposition and collection of a tax on various kinds of fishing activities by foreigners. The others are the Fisheries Agreements (Payments) Bill 1981, the Fisheries Amendment Bill 1981 and the Continental Shelf (Living Natural Resources) Amendment Bill 1981.

This Bill imposes a levy on the grant of licences authorising foreign boats to fish in the 200 nautical mile Australian fishing zone or to take sedentary organisms from the Australian continental shelf. since the establishment of the fishing zone on 1 November 1979, the Government has collected amounts in addition to licence fees in accordance with agreements between the Commonwealth and the foreign interests concerned. This Bill does not affect that practice. I shall refer to this in more detail later. The Government's policy is to encourage joint fishing operations between Australian and foreign interests as the preferred method of allowing foreign fishermen to have access to the portion of fish stocks in the AFZ that Australian fishermen do not harvest.

The principal purpose of this Bill is to enable implementation of an aspect of the new guidelines for joint Australian/foreign fishing arrangements, developed by the Australian Fishing Zone Committee comprising representatives of the fishing industry and State, Northern Territory and Commonwealth governments. Following endorsement by the Australian Fisheries Council in September 1980, I announced the Government's acceptance of the new guidelines. The guidelines provide that, in addition to administrative fees prescribed by regulation under the Fisheries Act, joint venture partners during the period when foreign vessels and crews are utilised might be required to pay access fees which may be reviewed during the course of the project. This provision in the guidelines is designed to cover the initial situation where there is little Australian involvement in the joint venture. As the Australian content is increased the levy could be phased out. Alternatively where considerable benefits are offered the levy would be payable if the benefits do not materialise.

This Bill provides for the assessment of a levy payable in respect of the grant of licences for foreign boats operating under the control of joint fishing arrangements and for the liability of licence holders, who may be Australian residents or companies, for payment of the levy. Other Bills in this package provide for the collection of the levy, and how it may be reduced or waived if other suitable benefits are provided to Australia.

The Bill applies not only to licences granted as the result of a joint fishing arrangement. It subjects all licensees of foreign fishing boats to an obligation to pay a tax to be called levy except in two cases. The first case is where the licence is granted under an agreement with a foreign government which specifies that an amount is payable over and above the licence fee. The second case in which levy is not payable under this Bill is where the boats are temporarily imported, and the regulations prescribe them to be exempt. The Government's intention is that the regulations will exempt only those temporarily imported boats that are under the exclusive control of Australians for use in developmental fishing.

The amount of levy that is payable under the Bill will be set out in the regulations. Clause 7 provides that the regulations may set out the amount of levy payable for any boat or class of boats by reference to a wide range of matters relating to the boat or its operations. As I have just mentioned, the amount required to be paid in respect of boats in joint fishing arrangements may be less than the applicable levy as the result of provisions in the Fisheries Amendment Bill or the Continental Shelf (Living Natural Resources) Amendment Bill to which I will refer later. Finally, neither this Bill nor any other Bill in the package, applies to fishing operations with Australian boats. I commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Willis) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr McVeigh, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is the second of the four Bills dealing with payments in respect of foreign boats licensed to fish in waters or areas of the continental shelf under Australian jurisdiction. The purpose of the Bill is to provide the Commonwealth with legislative powers to give effect to fisheries agreements entered into with a foreign government, providing for the payment by nationals of the other country of amounts additional to administrative fees payable for the issue of licences. Boats licensed pursuant to a government-to-government agreement are exempt from levy under the Foreign Fishing Boats Levy Bill and any amount required to be paid under the agreement is payable in lieu of levy.

This Bill has the constitutional character of a taxing Bill and has no other application than in that sense. There are mirror provisions in other Bills to which I will later refer, which have effect if the provisions are held not to deal with the imposition of taxation. This course of legislative action has been taken on legal advice to put the matter beyond doubt. What is not caught by this Bill will be caught by one of the others. The Bill does not of itself provide statutory authority for the Commonwealth to enter into agreements. The Commonwealth does this in the exercise of its executive authority.

Since 1979 when the Australian fishing zone was established, the Commonwealth has collected an access fee in respect of Japanese tuna longline vessels in accordance with the subsidiary agreements with the Japanese Government. The Bill does not replace provisions of that kind in any past or future agreement. It leaves the two governments free to agree that all or some of the amount becomes payable after the licences are granted. This additional flexibility is of benefit to both parties in negotiating the agreement. The Bill supports this flexibility by providing a power to suspend the licences granted under the agreement while amounts agreed to be paid remain outstanding. I commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Willis) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr McVeigh, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This is the third of the four Bills dealing with taxation in relation to foreign fishing boats. The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the collection of levy payable on the grant of licences under the Fisheries Act 1952, which the Bill amends for the purpose. The Bill also contains provisions to facilitate giving effect to fisheries agreements entered into with foreign governments, to the extent that those provisions do not deal with the imposition of taxation. When moving the second reading of the Foreign Fishing Boats Levy Bill, I referred to the Government's policy of licensing foreign fishing boats to fish in the Australian fishing zone only after entering into formal agreements with the foreign fishing interests seeking the licences. These agreements fall into three general categories, each of which this Bill deals with separately.

The first category is agreements for the conduct of joint fishing operations. Where a joint fishing company offers benefits to Australia, in consideration of which the Commonwealth has agreed to release the company from additional impost by way of levy, the Bill empowers the Minister to give effect to that agreement. The Government expects that the use of this power will encourage joint fishing companies to create employment for Australians, to invest in facilities on shore in Australia, or to provide other tangible benefits.

The second category of agreements is where Australia agrees with the government of a foreign country to license fishing vessels flying its flag to fish in the AFZ. The Foreign Fishing Boats Levy Bill exempts boats licensed pursuant to such an arrangement from liability to pay the levy. The Fisheries Agreements (Payments) Bill provides legislative authority to give effect to the agreement insofar as it may be held to deal with the imposition of taxation in relation to the agreed amount. The Fisheries Amendment Bill provides for giving effect to the agreement in cases that do not have taxation implications.

The final category of agreements comprises those which do not fall into either of the previous categories, such as the agreement with the Kaohsiung Commercial Fishing Boat Guild of Taiwan. Foreign boats licensed under agreements in this category will continue to be liable to pay the full amount. The Bill requires the Minister to table agreements of any of these kinds in both Houses of the Parliament within 15 sitting days after entering into them.

The Fisheries Act which this Bill amends, sets out objectives in section 5B, to which the Minister is to have regard when administering the Act. The Minister exercises his discretionary power to grant or refuse a licence under section 9 of that Act in accordance with those statutory objectives. The Bill will require the Minister to disregard those objectives when granting licences pursuant to agreements. The stage at which the Minister considers the conservation and fisheries management objectives of the Act is when the agreement is being negotiated. It is proposed to insert a new section 9C in the principal Act to provide for collection of levy payable in respect of all foreign fishing boats that have not been exempted under the Foreign Fishing Boats Levy Bill.

Proposed sub-section 9C(2) enables the Minister to make arrangements with people or companies liable to pay the levy, concerning the time and manner of payment of the levy. In such a case, proposed sub-section 9C(10) requires payment in accordance with the arrangement or, where there is no such arrangement, within 30 days of the grant of the licence. By proposed sub-section 9C(6), when the Minister has made an agreement approving a joint fishing arrangement and the company has defaulted on the provision of a promised benefit, the amount of levy that had previously been waived becomes payable. The Minister may then suspend some or all of the licences held by the company in respect of foreign fishing boats. Agreements for joint fishing arrangements will normally refer to the benefits to be provided on a year-by-year basis, in conjunction with the issue of licences. If the company subsequently either pays the levy together with any penalty that has accrued or provides the promised benefit, the Minister is then required, by proposed sub-section 9C(7), to reinstate the suspended licences.

In the case of an agreement in the third category, when levy is not paid by the due date, proposed sub-section 9C(8) empowers the Secretary to the Department of Primary Industry to suspend the licences for the foreign fishing boats concerned. Under the next proposed sub-section he must revoke the suspension when the levy and any penalty is received. Proposed sub-section 9C(11) provides a rate of penalty of 10 per cent for each month the levy remains unpaid after the due date. Penalty ceases to accumulate on the date that the licence would have expired.

The combined effect of these provisions is that the licensee would commit an offence against the Fisheries Act 1952 if he used the boat for fishing in the AFZ during the suspension and even if the levy were paid during the period of the licence, it and the penalty would remain as money owing to the Commonwealth, recoverable in a court of competent jurisdiction. The intention of these sanctions is that they should serve as much as an incentive to the provision of promised benefits or prompt payment of levy as a punishment for default. Nevertheless, the sanctions will be applied whenever a default occurs.

It is not appropriate, in the case of an agreement with the government of another country, to make any unpaid amount a debt to the Commonwealth recoverable in a court or to impose any penalty for non-payment. However, the Bill contains provisions for suspension of licences in such a case. To assist in verification of the amount due when levy is assessed in accordance with the size of the boat, clauses 5 and 6 provide a power for an officer to go on board and measure the boat or to obtain the assistance of another person, who would have the powers and rights of an officer while so engaged. It is envisaged that the other person would be a qualified marine surveyor employed by the Commonwealth or a State. Finally, clauses 7 and 8 make a number of formal amendments to the principal Act. I commend the Bill to honourable members.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONTINENTAL SHELF (LIVING NATURAL RESOURCES) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr McVeigh, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Bill is the final Bill in the package concerned with taxing foreign boats. In substance, it is identical with the Fisheries Amendment Bill. For that reason, I will not take the time of the House with a recital of its detailed provisions. However, there are several points about which it is appropriate to inform the House in relation to the Bill. Australia's sovereign rights in relation to living sedentary organisms on the Australian continental shelf differ significantly from Australia's sovereign rights and responsibilities for managing the swimming fishery resources of the Australian fishing zone. In particular, Australia is not obliged to allocate to foreigners, any surplus of the allowable catch of sedentary organisms that Australians do not take.

Since the Continental Shelf (Living Natural Resources) Act 1968 came into force, the Commonwealth policy has consistently been not to license foreign ships. This does not mean that, if Australian fishermen did not harvest the allowable catch of presently known or newly discovered stocks of a sedentary organism, we would not at some future time review the policy to see if there was benefit to be gained for Australia by allowing foreigners to harvest those stocks on terms and conditions determined by the Commonwealth.

The Government considers it appropriate to provide now for collection of the levy in relation to licences that may at some future time be granted for foreign ships to take sedentary organisms. Without the Bill, the Government would be limited in the options available to it in relation to any future proposals it might receive from foreign fishermen seeking permission to harvest sedentary organisms from the continental shelf of Australia or the external Territories on a commercial basis. At present there are no such proposals under consideration. I commend the Bill to honourable members.

Brotherhood of St Laurence

Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs,

Canberra, A.C.T. 2600

An Open Letter on Youth Unemployment
I refer to your letter advising that the Government will not accept the Brotherhood's JOBS Scheme proposal for an experimental community work experience program for unemployed young people.

That 'short, well designed programs that directly create jobs serve to off-set adverse side-effects of labour market constraints and in doing so increase employment of low wage workers, raise economic output and add to total employment, all with little of no inflationary impact. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. I point out that this letter is addressed to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) and is dated 21 August 1981. Of CYSS, it says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Brotherhood sees the decision to abruptly terminate the CYSS Scheme as indicative of a serious lack of concern and understanding on the part of the Government and your Ministry of the feelings and interests of young unemployed people.

In considering the revenue figures in this Budget and looking at matters that have been raised in this House over time, the Government could have been in a better position in relation to revenue. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Mr H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1981-82 Budget, which we are debating, reinforces the consistent approach to economic management that the Fraser Government has pursued over the last 5 1/2 years. Year after year that approach has proven successful through the improvement which is evident in a wide range of economic indicators. In turning to comment about specific aspects of the Budget I say this Budget will ensure the retention and further strengthening of the progress that has been made in the light of a less than favourable international economic environment over the next 12 months.

SPEECH.PARA: Prior to the presentation of this Budget, there were rumours concerning the proposed imposition of a tax on wine. I was very pleased that the strong representations which I was able to make to the Government on this issue were successful and that no wine tax was implemented in the Budget. The continuing exemption of the wine industry from such a tax is fully justified. The wine industry is essentially a primary industry. It is difficult for the industry to make short term adjustment to changes in demand which would be caused by the impact of a tax because of the long lead times required in grape production. I was appalled to hear the Australian Labor Party, through the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), criticise the exemption of wine from sales tax and advocate the implementation of such a tax during the debate on sales tax legislation. At least it is good for the grape growers and wine makers in the Kingston electorate-the Southern Vales area-to know where the Labor Party stands on this issue.

The decision to terminate the Community Youth Support Scheme at the end of October has aroused a measure of controversy in the community. This was referred to by the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) a few moments ago. The decision to terminate CYSS was based on changed circumstances which have transpired since it was initiated by this Government in 1976. These changed circumstances include the significant improvement in the youth employment situation and the large range of more effective training programs that the Government has implemented since that time. That emphasis on alternative training programs is reflected in this Budget by a 67 per cent increase in funding for those programs. However, I was glad of the assurance of the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) that an alternative scheme will be considered if a need is demonstrated following the counselling procedures that have been instituted to attempt to slot CYSS participants into alternative training programs. From my follow-up of those counselling procedures, I believe that thus far, to the limited extent that counselling has taken place, that need has been demonstrated. I believe the Government must have an alternative program in place by the end of October. If that is not possible, I believe the Community Youth Support Scheme should continue until an alternative program can be implemented. In the campaign that has been launched in the community since the Budget to fight for the retention of CYSS there has been the involvement of a large number of people who have not had any previous active involvement in this scheme. I believe the extension of the Community Youth Support Scheme for a further period, if an alternative cannot be placed in operation by the end of October, would give those people the opportunity to place their involvement where their mouths have been over the last few weeks.

I believe South Australia is worthy of special consideration in this matter. In that State there are several regional employment problems which are a result of the combined effect of structural problems in its regional economy and the fact that for nearly 10 years it had an anti-development, anti-private sector Labor Government in office. The Tonkin Government has valiantly strived to reverse that trend since it came to office two years ago. It is achieving success. But I believe the continuing problems that South Australia faces do warrant special consideration by this Government. As I have said, if there is a clear demonstration by the end of the counselling procedures that the participants in CYSS cannot be slotted into alternative training programs, I believe it is essential that an alternative be provided by that date.

It is the proud achievement of this Government that home ownership has gone up from 66 per cent of the population in 1976 to 71.6 per cent in 1980. That means that Australia has the highest level of home ownership in the world. Home ownership is an important aspect of the Australian way of life and I believe that it assists social stability. In this Budget the Federal Government has increased its total expenditure on housing by 17 per cent-from $341.1m in 1980-81 to $399m for the current financial year. Within that, the amount allocated for the Home Savings Grants Scheme has increased from $44.6m to $74m, an increase of 66 per cent. Thus in that way the Government has demonstrated its commitment to support housing.

However, high interest rates remain a major concern for home buyers. The Government has given that problem major priority in this Budget. By budgeting for a large domestic surplus it is reducing the need of the Government to borrow, thereby reducing competition for funds and so reducing pressure on interest rates. This is in marked contrast to what happened when the Labor Party was in office some years ago. On the basis of that past practice and the present economic strategy it advocates, it must be recognised as a party of high spending, high deficits and therefore necessarily high interest rates. In the three years that the Labor Party was in government-from 1972 to 1975-interest rates on bank housing loans increased from 7 3/4 to 11 1/2 per cent. That is in fact a 48 per cent increase in interest rates. In the period of nearly six years that the coalition Government has been in office since then it has effectively restrained the increase in interest rates-so much so that they have increased from 11 1/2 per cent when the Government took office to 12 1/2 per cent currently; that is, an 8.7 per cent increase in the rate of interest compared with a 48 per cent increase when the Labor Party was in government. That is a far superior performance. It ought to be emphasised, of course, that the massive increase in interest rates that occurred when Labor was in office occurred when there was little demand for funds from the business sector because there was no any expansion in business activity due to the way Labor destroyed the economy. The increase in interest rates was due entirely to its profligate spending and the massive deficit that it generated.

TALK.START.PARA: —This will go down well in Kingston; do not worry about that.

—It certainly will go down well in Kingston. By contrast, the revival in business activity that has taken place under the coalition Government over the last 6 years has significantly increased the demand for loan funds. I take the corporate sector as one example. The demand there has gone from $973m in 1976-77 to $4,000m in the last financial year-1980-81. Despite that, interest rates have gone up only from 11 1/2 per cent to 12 1/2 per cent. Of course, the reason for that is the much better financial management of the coalition government. The Government has reduced its need for borrowings by eliminating the deficit that it inherited from the Labor Party. The domestic surplus that has been provided for in this Budget aims to reduce further the pressure on interest rate increases. Of course the best thing that the Federal Government can do for home buyers is reduce its demand for loan funds and so reduce the pressure on interest rates.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government cannot wave a magic wand and instantaneously reduce interest rates because interest rates simply reflect the balance between the supply of and the demand for money. If the Government seeks artificially to depress interest rates, potential lenders will invest their funds elsewhere and so loans for housing will dry up. If it provides some form of interest rate subsidy, either directly or through a tax concession, the subsidy will have to be paid for by the taxpayers through an increase in some other form of taxation. Also, the intended benefit of a subsidy or tax rebate would flow through and be reflected in higher home prices. So in real terms it would not benefit the home buyer. The strategy which this Government has pursued and which is evident in this Budget does provide the best chance of keeping interest rates down. I was very glad that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) was able to indicate only last week that favourable signs are already evident with regard to the future trends for the interest rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has been saying that for the past three years.
—He has done a good job too.
—With interest rates going in the opposite direction.

—I have just contrasted what has happened in six years of Liberal Government with the three years when your mob were in charge. The Budget, of course, highlights the dangers to the economy and also to the much improved employment situation of renewed wages pressure. This is, in part, a product of the expansion of the economy and the shortage of certain skills in the labour market. But in large measure it is due to the institutionalised rigidities in our wage fixation system. It is totally incongruous to have large wage increases at a time of unsatisfactorily high unemployment. Militant unionism, combined with entrenched rigidities, ensure that wages always rise and never fall despite unemployment. If demand slackens for goods and services provided by businessmen, they either have to reduce prices to increase sales or accept reduced profits directly or through those reduced sales. Either way their income falls.

SPEECH.PARA: When there is a slackness in demand for labour it is reasonable for wages to fall to a level which allows many more to be employed. There is no doubt that high wages are a major factor causing unemployment. Of course, the trade unions would not have a bar of such a proposition. This demonstrates that they are concerned only with benefits for their employed members and do not give a damn about those who are unemployed. Far from allowing such an opportunity for job growth to occur, the trade unions continue to seek higher and higher wages. But the improved productivity from more employment at lower wages would soon allow higher wages to eventuate anyway. A much freer operation of market forces with regard to wage levels is desperately required in Australia. It would make a great contribution towards overcoming unemployment. I believe the barriers to its achievement ought to be removed.

The Budget initiates a welcome broadening of the tax base with the application of an increase of 2 1/2 per cent sales tax. This move to a greater reliance on indirect taxation is exactly in accord with the recommendations of the Asprey Taxation Review Committee. Australia has a heavy reliance on income tax as a source of revenue. I am disappointed that the sales tax increases have not been immediately accompanied by income tax reductions. I look forward to them in future budgets. While referring to taxation, let me lay to rest the dishonest claims by the Australian Labor Party that the present Government is the highest taxing, biggest spending government in history.

TALK.START.PARA: —A dishonest lot!

—Of course the Labor Party is dishonest. While it may be true in an absolute sense that total spending and total revenue are at the highest levels, it is superficial in the extreme to use that as justification for a charge of big government to be laid against the coalition. The most important factor in considering such a charge is the rate of growth in spending. In six years the Fraser Government has increased spending by a total of 8.2 per cent in real terms. The Labor Party in half that time, in just the three years when it was in office, increased spending in real terms-that is, after allowing for inflation-by a massive 33 per cent. So the figures of comparison are 33 per cent over a three-year period against about 4 per cent over an equivalent three-year period for the coalition government. Such figures demonstrate the utter hypocrisy of charges of big spending that have been levelled at this Government by the Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: In three years the Labor Party increased revenue from taxation by 24 per cent in real terms. In six years, the Liberals have increased it by 29 per cent. Over twice the time, the figure has increased only a little more than in Labor's shorter era. If one works that on a three-year basis, it is about 15 per cent compared with 24 per cent-a much smaller figure. This is despite the fact that the present Government has needed that extra revenue to make up the gap between spending and revenue that was left in the form of a massive deficit by the previous Labor Government. Despite the massive increases in taxation revenue under Labor, which I referred to a moment ago, its even more massive increases in spending left a massive deficit as a result. That deficit was heading towards--

TALK.START.PARA: —We met the people's needs.

—In 1975 the people showed very clearly that the Government did not meet their needs. It left a deficit approaching $4 billion when it went out of office. With modest increases in revenue, compared with that which transpired during the Labor era, the coalition Government has managed to overcome this massive deficit. It has accompanied that by significant reforms to income tax, such that all are now paying less tax than they would have if the scales of taxation that were in operation under the Labor period had continued. Let there be no doubt that the present Liberal-National Country Party Government is the only one with a legitimate claim to practise small government.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the main factors contributing to increased spending despite the restraint of this Government has been the area of welfare and especially its age pension component. In the last decade the population of Australia has increased by 14.8 per cent, but the aged population-that is men over the age of 65 and women over 60-has increased by 30.2 per cent. This aging population is further evidenced by the expected acceleration which will increase the figure by another two-thirds over the next 20 years. Of course, this means an ever higher proportion of our population is becoming dependent on a smaller proportion of the population which is the active income earners and wealth producers. Even more dramatically, as at 30 June this year, there were 1,376,671 age pension recipients; that is 68.9 per cent more than 10 years ago. So, the percentage increase in age pension recipients is more than twice the increase in the aged population over the last 10 years which, in turn, is twice the increase in the population at large. That is why, in real terms, spending on welfare has doubled in the last 10 years. In money terms it has increased by more than seven times over that period.

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't mind supporting the elderly, do we?

—We do not mind supporting the elderly. We have a very effective policy towards them. Over that period the proportion of the Budget allocated to welfare has increased from 17 1/2 per cent to 27.8 per cent of total Budget expenditure. So there is increasing pressure on government revenue and on the economy to provide these benefits. That raises a serious question as to the nature of pension eligibility. On the one hand people put the argument that the means test should be abolished or significantly eased. This, of course, would result in a large increase in the number of pension recipients and an equally massive increase in spending and, therefore, the need for taxation to pay for it. This argument finds favour with many aged people. The argument against it is the massive tax burden which it would require. On the other hand is the argument in favour of a means test to ensure that pensions are directed to those in real need. The argument raised against this is that it penalises thriftiness and provides a disincentive for people to provide for their future and aged years. There are valid arguments on both sides.

SPEECH.PARA: Given those statistics which I cited a few moments ago with regard to the increase in the proportion of the population of aged people, I believe a continuation of the means test is the only practical option. It is the only way in which we can ensure that the funds that are available are directed in sufficient quantity to those who are in real need. However, I believe that the income test for full pension and fringe benefit eligibility should be eased to take account of inflation over the last decade or so. It is nine years since the $20 limit for a single pensioner and $34 limit for a married pensioner have been increased. I believe the Government should consider one option concerning fringe benefits. Those who are just over the eligibility criteria should be allowed to purchase a fringe benefit card for a fixed amount of money. The arbitrary cut-off point creates certain anomalies in this area.

As I said at the outset, this Budget reinforces the consistent approach the Government has adopted over the last five years. It is a clear demonstration of the Government's concern to ensure that Australia's domestic economic environment will remain well placed to cope with the strains which will be placed on it by international economic circumstances. It maximises the opportunity for prosperity in the continuing difficult economic climate. Nothing which has been proposed by the Labor Opposition in this lengthy Budget debate which is now drawing to a close detracts from the Government's achievement or the prospects which this Budget offers. I am certainly not convinced that I should either oppose the Budget or support the amendment. On that basis I support the Budget.
