Sales tax particularly discriminates against country people as it is levied as a percentage of the price of goods that pass from the wholesaler to the retailer and a freight component, as well as the production cost, is involved. Residents throughout my electorate have an added penalty imposed on them.

I now come to specifics. The Government intends to increase the sales tax levy by 2 1/2 per cent across the board. Items classed as luxury goods, for example, televisions, radios, stereos, records, cameras, jewellery and cosmetics, will now be taxed at a rate of 30 per cent instead of 27 1/2 per cent. Most other articles are classed in the general category. This, of course, includes motor vehicles and caravans. Tax will now be levied on these items at 17 1/2 per cent rather than the previous rate of 15 per cent. All domestic items such as washing machines, stoves, refrigerators, fans and heaters, blinds and mattresses and kitchen utensils will now be taxed at a rate of 5 per cent rather than 2 1/2 per cent. In addition, the Government proposes a whole new tax levy of 2 1/2 per cent on items that were previously exempt. Books, magazines and newspapers now become taxable. There is a tax on knowledge. That does not surprise me. It is obvious that this Government is interested in keeping the public of this country ignorant and ill-informed. The Government also proposes to tax clothes and footwear as well as drapery, blinds, building materials and soft furnishings for the first time. It is, Mr Deputy Speaker, an incongruous government that raises the price of these items by its tariff protection and quota policies and then increases their price by placing an additional tax on them.

Once these items become taxable, the amount of tax that is levied on them will start to creep up. When a person tries to build a house and furnish it in the north-west of Western Australia he finds that prices are astronomical. Yet the only thing the Government can think to do is add an additional tax surcharge in the form of sales tax. The Government proposes to clear up certain anomalies. All of a sudden a 17 1/2 per cent tax surcharge is lumped on pet food. Motor oil which was exempt will have a 17 1/2 per cent tax imposed on it. It is not only the private individual who is affected. Many manufacturers and wholesalers will become tax collectors for the Government. This will appreciably add to their costs.

When we look at the items that are now taxed it becomes apparent that certain industries in my electorate will be very adversely affected. An example is the mining companies. The Treasurer has now decided that all items used in the construction and operation of railways that do not carry public traffic, that is mining company railways, will be taxed at 17 1/2 per cent. This will inhibit the construction of railway lines and the development of mining in the Pilbara. Many items used in railway construction cost almost as much for transport as they do for the item itself. If a 17 1/2 per cent sales tax levy is imposed it will apply not only to the unit cost but also to the freight cost. On many items the cost escalation will be 35 per cent as a result of the Government's new policy. For example, Mount Newman Mining Company Pty Ltd transports its sleepers from Whyalla in South Australia to the Pilbara. It is now faced with a 35 per cent price hike on those items. I certainly believe that the people of Australia in general and Kalgoorlie in particular should not have to bear the new sales taxes outlined in the Budget. I shall oppose them and all added duties. I was hoping that the Government would lighten the existing sales tax burden. We should have before us legislation aimed at removing the freight component from sales tax or a reclassification to exempt more items from sales tax and reclassify some of the so called luxury items as essential items. Instead, I find myself fighting to prevent a massive new sales tax slug.

I now refer to income tax. I see from the Budget Papers that the Treasurer anticipates a rise in income tax of about 19 per cent from $17,543m to $20,860m. The Government has put an end to income tax relief through a scheme of tax indexation. Be that as it may, I believe that some income tax relief should be provided. I have two specific areas in mind. The first is income tax on workers compensation payments. Currently weekly compensation payments made to the victims of industrial caused disease are classed as income and as such are taxable. Lump sum payments are not taxable. Many miners in Kalgoorlie who suffer from pneumoconiosis are penalised by this anomaly. I call on the Government to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act to provide that such payments be exempt from income tax. I ask honourable members how they can justify that if a man breaks an arm and gets a tax free payment it is a tax free recognition of a capital loss; however, if a man breaks his lungs by working in dusty and dangerous conditions and breathing silicon dust he gets a weekly compensation payment, not because he wants it that way but because the Act is written that way and he has no alternative. He must pay tax because he receives a weekly payment. The Treasurer knows the details because I have brought them to his attention. His neglect in this area is testimony to his general indifference to the plight of the needy in this nation.

Great hopes were held out for a significant improvement in the level of zone allowances, particularly by the Western Australian Liberal Government and assorted Liberal politicians. Federal and State inquiries were set up with much fanfare. Committees travelled throughout the length and breadth of the country receiving submissions. The electors have, however, once again been betrayed. The adjustments to the zone allowance contained in the Budget before us are paltry and totally inadequate. The Treasurer has mightily laboured and brought forth a lemon. The current benefits paid to offset the extra costs incurred and disabilities suffered in living in the remote areas could hardly be described as generous. People on low incomes, that is pensioners or those who earn below the taxable limit, receive nothing. Taxpayers in zone A receive a rebate of $216 plus a sum equal to 25 per cent of the dependent rebate. In zone B the taxpayer receives a rebate of $36 plus 4 per cent of the rebate in respect of that area. Thus, a single person living in zone A gets a flat rebate of $216 while a single person in zone B gets $36.

What is needed, therefore, is a significant increase in the basic allowance, an increase in the dependant component, and an easing of the conditions of eligibility. Without this the whole benefit might as well be abolished. At the moment, it is not fulfilling the function for which it was designed. The function of the allowance is to act as an inducement to encourage people to live in isolated areas. It should also provide compensation for the disadvantages of living in remote areas caused by climate, harsh environment and isolation. To some extent, the zone allowance could also be seen as a compensation for taxation paid on district allowances. In many cases it is necessary to encourage people to live in isolated areas in order to develop our resources. Development projects within my electorate may indeed be hampered if more realistic zone allowances are not devised.

For all who favour decentralisation of population and industry away from the State capitals, recent trends are disturbing. Some 5.9 per cent of the nation's population was living in the remote areas of the continent when the zone concession was first provided in 1945-46. This represented 1.6 per cent in zone A and 4.3 per cent in zone B. A substantially smaller percentage is living in those areas today. Common justice requires that we maintain realistic zone allowances. The amount of tax levied on disadvantaged groups should be less than the norm. Clearly, people who live in remote areas are disadvantaged. Their cost of living is significantly higher. Food costs for people who live in my electorate are between 10 per cent and 40 per cent higher than Perth food prices. Housing and insurance is a lot more expensive in remote areas, particularly in the cyclone affected areas of north-west Western Australia. It costs parents who live in remote areas thousands of dollars each year to board their children in Perth or major regional centres for both secondary and post-secondary education. The high cost of freight and petrol imposes an added burden on isolated residents.

Some honourable members have pointed to the fact that significantly higher wages and district allowances are already paid to offset the disabilities suffered by such residents. I concede that the mining industry, in general, offers its employees good conditions. But by far the greatest percentage of workers-72 per cent in zone A and 86 per cent in zone B-are employed in other industries. In most instances the latter are employed under the same award and conditions as workers elsewhere in the State and are paid a district allowance which is taxed and, as such, does not compensate for the increased costs. A number of employees, particularly in the rural industries, are not paid district allowances. There are also a considerable number of self-employed people in these areas. In my electorate 6 per cent of workers in zone A and 22 per cent in zone B are self-employed. They do not have the advantage of receiving district allowances.

How has the Government responded to the challenge to change a token effect into a policy that will have some real impact? It has not. We still have a policy of tokenism. People on low incomes-that is, pensioners and those who earn below the taxable limit-continue to receive no benefit. The single taxpayer receives the same as before. There is some slight improvement in the lot of the person with a family. A taxpayer who lives in zone A now gets a base amount of $216, plus 50 per cent of the rebate in respect of dependants. A taxpayer who lives in zone B now gets a base amount of $36, plus 20 per cent of the rebate in respect of dependants. A special zone allowance will now be paid to taxpayers who reside more than 250 kilometres from a population centre of 2,500 people or more. This new rate of $750, plus the zone A or zone B dependant rebate according to locality, is a step in the right direction. Unfortunately, over 70 per cent of my electors who live in zone A or B will not benefit from the provision at all.

The Government, unfortunately, not only has failed to increase zone allowances but also has introduced some new regressive features. I refer to the proposal that urban areas, with a population in excess of 25,000 in Zone A will drop into zone B, and those in Zone B will be excluded from any benefit. Although this provision will not immediately affect any centre in my electorate, it could well affect Kalgoorlie-Boulder in a few years time. The sword now hangs over our heads. I will not remain silent while the Government just slips this new measure through.

I call on the Government to reconsider its zone allowance policy as outlined in this Budget. I will now outline some recommendations. Firstly, the Government should increase the basic zone rebate to $560 for single taxpayers in zone A and $448 for single taxpayers in zone B. Secondly, it should increase allowances for taxpayers with dependants to a level of $560, plus 75 per cent of the rebate in respect of dependants for zone A residents, and $448, plus 75 per cent of the rebate in respect of dependants, for residents in zone B. Thirdly, it should ensure that those who receive no benefit from the current rebate system because they have an income below the taxable limit are paid a cash benefit after lodging a taxation return. Fourthly, the Government should remove the new clauses that reduce or remove the zone allowance benefits for large rural centres. If this Government adheres to its stated policy it does so in the face of public opinion. It ignores the opinions conveyed to the Government inquiry by 19 shires in my electorate. It ignores the opinion of progress associations, party branches, unions, chambers of commerce and numerous other community groups, not to mention individual citizens. It ignores also rural Australia. Total outlays in 1981-82 are estimated to be in the order of $40,862m.

One small item fails to appear in this year's Budget allocation. Out of a record expenditure of $40,862m there is no allocation for the Community Youth Support Scheme. This Scheme cost us a mere $13.8m last year. The Community Youth Support Scheme has established a line of support between the young unemployed and the rest of the community. Many citizens have taken an active and supportive role in local CYSS communities. Young people who are unemployed have been given basic skills that will at least put them in the race for available jobs. More importantly, they receive moral support and encouragement.

Despite the much touted Government alternatives, there is no alternative for many young people in my electorate. Their geographic isolation will put them beyond the reach of new forms of assistance. Some of the so-called training schemes offered as alternatives to CYSS are next to useless. Many young people who have taken part in a 17 or 34 week subsidised employment scheme have been given menial labouring tasks for the subsidised period and then have been retrenched. I fully support the project officers national campaign to save CYSS. I deplore the cheap sensationalism of the Western Australia Government in trying to make political capital out of the current situation. It announced, in a blaze of publicity, that it would save CYSS in Perth. With its offer to find one small project it misled many people into thinking that it was taking some more substantial action to save the scheme in the metropolitan area. As I understand it, in Perth CYSS will be funded by the Young Men's Christian Association. This is a great effort for this organisation but it offers little in terms of real need.
I will now return to some of the aspects of the sales tax legislation. I must refer to one defect in the current Act. Section 135A of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act states:

Motor vehicles (and parts therefor) for use in the transportation to and from gainful employment of a person in respect of whom the Director-General of Social Services, or an officer appointed by him for the purpose, has certified that he has lost the use of one or both legs to such an extent that he is permanently unable to use public transport, not being goods for sale.

This section is overly restrictive. Only people who have lost the use of one or both legs to the extent that they are unable to use public transport are eligible for benefits. This excludes many handicapped people who justly deserve some concession. The current section also limits sales tax exemptions to vehicles used to transport handicapped people to or from gainful employment. Thus people who have had an accident or are incapacitated in some other way and are attending a hospital for therapy sessions receive no consideration. Many people who are incapacited and on sickness benefit remain isolated in the suburbs with meagre public transport. Making it easier for these people to purchase a car could make all the difference to their lives. Handicapped people need new cars, not worn out second hand cars that will break down.

Many disabled people who are now out of a job could gain employment if they had their own transport. They are in a catch-22 situation. Often they cannot apply for jobs because of a lack of suitable transport. As they are unemployed they cannot afford to purchase a car. Therefore they cannot apply for many jobs. On the other side of the coin, we have the situation of the gent from Dalkeith who regularly purchases a new Mercedes Benz car sales tax free so that he can drive, or be driven, to his bank. He is classified as a self-employed investor.

The Government should make some effort to aid the disabled in this the International Year of Disabled Persons. It has done precious little so far. I suggest that the exemption provided under item 135A should read:

For motor vehicles (and parts therefor) for use as personal transportation and not for sale by persons in respect of whom the Director-General of Social Services, or an officer appointed by him for that purpose, has certified those persons so permanently physically or mentally handicapped as to require the use of private transport.

In the 30 seconds I have left, I point out to the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Chapman) that, in line with current Liberal Party practice, it was my belief that there should be a tax on wine. I am outraged at the very high tax on beer. I think it is only equitable that wine should bear some of that tax. It obviously was not the view of the Labor Party and, in this instance, I feel that the Government and the Labor Party was wrong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without spending a lot of time on any one aspect, I make brief mention of the speech by the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) and the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) and, in particular, their references to the Community Youth Support Scheme. The worst thing that the Government has done in recent times was to take advice from Labor politicians. I shall quote Mr Mick Young, the previous Labor spokesman on Employment and Youth Affairs. In his book, I want to Work, in relation to the CYSS he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The scheme is no more than tokenism, confined to creating drop-in centres, providing 'cuddle-therapy'; rather than the jobs young people really need.
He went on to state:
The guidelines even limit training, preventing formal educational classes or instruction in job skills as normally provided by educational or training institutions.
He goes on to state:
The $12.26 million would be better spent on genuine job creation and training programmes.

Day after day since the Budget Speech was delivered, members of the Australian Labor Party have led marches and banged the drums on the CYSS program saying: 'It must be saved'. Yet prior to the Budget debate it was the Labor politicians who were actively undermining CYSS. I speak as the founding president of the program in my former electorate of Griffith and the patron of the CYSS program called Woodridge Ways in my electorate of Fadden. I know what CYSS is all about. I say this to the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) at the table, the former Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs-and I hope the Minister can believe and understand exactly what I am saying: my view is that whilst many CYSS programs throughout Australia were a flop-I know of one in Sydney that consisted of a dark room, a coffee machine and two pin ball machines-across the country there have been many worthwhile CYSS programs. I realise that the Government is a very responsive government, but on the other hand--

TALK.START.PARA: —Responsive to what?

—Responsive to me. In regard to this point, in view of this decision having been made, it is a good time for the Government to go through the processes recently outlined by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) to evaluate all the existing programs properly. But it is my plea-I do not care what it is called or what name it is given-that once we remove the warts and wrinkles some program should be continued or developed to allow the type of young people who do not fit into the existing programs to be given an opportunity for training and assistance. I already know that the Government by this Budget-the previous speaker did not mention this; perhaps he did not read the figures-is allocating $203m simply for manpower training in this country. Of that $203m, 70 per cent is going to youth training. That is approximately $154m out of a total of $203m.
—What about country areas where there are no facilities?
—Nobody, including the previous speaker, the noisy member for Kalgoorlie, can say that the Government is not doing anything. The Government is doing a lot. I direct my plea to the Minister--
—You want to tell people that in Carnarvon and Geraldton.

—The honourable member sounds like an empty gold mine in his own electorate. I present my plea that something be developed whereby these young people who cannot fit into these numerous existing programs can be assisted. I know from personal observation, experience and talking with people that CYSS programs or schemes such as WAYS have a lot to offer a certain category of people, and those people can be uplifted and directed into a useful and worthwhile future life.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard a lot about the subject of sales tax. I suppose no one would have received any more letters than I on the subject. John Citizen is exercising his democratic right to complain and to express an opposite view. Since the Budget was introduced on 18 August, one has had at least a month to consider seriously the ramifications of what is being done. It is very easy to stand up in this Parliament, kick the Budget and say: 'No, it is not on. We would be better without it'. I would rather have no tax at all. I receive $30,000-odd in salary, but by the time I get it home it is less than $20,000. I wonder where the other $10,000 has gone. I am representative of every member of Parliament and every working man and woman in this country. I could be the most popular man in the world by saying: 'Abolish all tax'. Now let us see what we have achieved as a nation. We have almost reached a stage at which we have killed or are killing incentive in the work force by the growing plundering raids that we make on the working man's pay packet. Our growing reliance--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right. This is the highest taxing government ever.

—Opposition members cannot talk. If ever there was a party that kicked up government involvement and government expenditure it was the Whitlam Government, and it went out in a screaming heap for that. This Government will not follow the path which the previous Government followed. Our reliance on the pay packet as a source of income for government expenditure is growing and growing. The Labor Party even appointed the Asprey Taxation Review Committee, which later stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the weight of taxation should be shifted towards the taxation of goods and services, and away from the taxation of income.

When we look at Australia's position compared with the countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development we see that in 1978, the last year for which all necessary information is available for comparative purposes, total tax revenue as a percentage of gross domestic product averaged 35.8 per cent for the 22 countries. The Australian figure at that time was 29 per cent. The averages in 16 of the 22 countries were higher than in Australia. Although Australian personal income taxes are lower than in other OECD countries, Australia collects more of its total revenue from personal income taxes than other OECD countries. In announcing--

TALK.START.PARA: —Does it kill incentives in other countries or just in Australia?

—Listen to this, the honourable member from Bob Dyer's Pick-a-Box; you might learn something that you did not know. Balancing this, Australia ranked ninth out of 22 in terms of reliance on all types of consumption tax but, in the area of sales tax and excise, 20 of the 22 member countries derived more expenditure from those sources than did Australia. Besides that, the number of items to which sales tax is applied has been limited. Over the last quarter century the nation's reliance upon the worker's pay packet has grown appreciably. I referred before to what the Whitlam Government-appointed Asprey Committee later suggested. I used that prized quote. I believe that expenditure in this country never really will go down and, whilst there remains a continuing upward trend, the Government still has to raise revenue. If honourable members look at this Budget they will see that almost half of the $40.7m--
—The figure is $40,000m.

—Yes, $40,700m. I stand corrected. I thank the honourable member. I am glad he is listening. I notice that $20,000m of that comes from personal income tax. The Government has pledged-I hope it realises the depth of its pledge-that, when economic conditions permit, it will reduce income tax levels. I believe that before that can be done the ground work has to be laid. The Government is in the process of realigning, rearranging, the commitments that will be made by all Australians. That is not to say that I do not recognise that in some areas there will be an extra imposition. Food is an exempt item, but my electorate of Fadden would have more children per thousand head of population than any other electorate in Australia.
—No. It is No. 2.
—We will decide that later. The honourable member for Lalor is claiming--
—The census figures say that.
—I am talking about children per thousand head of population.
—So am I. Lalor is No. 1.

—The honourable member for Lalor says that my electorate has the second greatest number. I claim that it has the greatest number. We will examine that later. However, Fadden is right at the top. I wonder whether that compromise pleases the honourable member for Lalor. I am glad that he is smiling. There are many small children in my electorate and the parents of those small children have to throw away their children's shoes not because they are beyond repair but for the simple reason that the feet of those children are growing and the shoes become too small and too tight. I respectfully suggest to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and to the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner), who is at the table, that consideration be given to compensating these people who simply cannot avoid the extra costs which will be incurred under the sales tax legislation. Perhaps it could be done through an increase in the family allowance for all children as a compensatory measure.

SPEECH.PARA: I single out another area-that of home building. We all know that, depending on the style of the home young people plan to build or buy, the increase in cost brought about by the sales tax legislation will be anything from $300 to $400 upwards. There is a limitation, in the Homes Savings Grant Scheme, on the value of the home that attracts the full grant. I respectfully suggest that, to offset the cost increases in the building industry which this tax will bring about, those first home owners become entitled to a larger payment. On the other hand, I have no regret for those people who are gathering homes like chestnuts; the very wealthy who through tax avoidance schemes-I am not saying that this applies to all people who own a number of homes-are avoiding their obligations. I am talking about the smart-Alicks who are advocating tax avoidance and avoiding their obligations. I cannot see why we should have a system in this country whereby those people can go right through from A to Z scot-free and even at the end, if they use their heads properly, pick up a tidy sum because a capital gains tax is not applied if a property is owned for X years and it can be shown somehow that it was not bought simply for quick profit purposes.

Unfortunately, it is true that a lot of people are getting away with not meeting their obligations in terms of tax. However, I think any Labor politician in this House who is fair-minded would acknowledge that our worthy Treasurer (Mr Howard) almost has the nickname of 'the ferret' because of his actions in this regard. There has been no man in this nation's history who has been more determined to crack down on those smarmy, slimey people who make a living simply out of trying to teach people how to get out of their tax obligations than our John Howard. In my time in this Parliament-it goes back 15 years-there has never been a Treasurer who has been more dedicated to this cause. There has never been a Treasurer who has brought in more legislation on this matter. There has never been a Treasurer who has been more determined to shut the door on these smart-Alicks. Let us leave the matter at that. One of the problems with this chamber is that every time someone makes a constructive comment or observation, Opposition members say: 'If you were to collect the tax avoidance money we would not need to take these measures'. That is a very hollow and unfair observation because in their own hearts they know that John Howard, the ferret, is doing a full job in this area.

I notice that I have a maximum of only six minutes left to me in which to speak so I turn now to another aspect of the plundering of the public purse. Out of this Budget of $40,000m, I notice an amount in excess of $11,000m allocated to social security. I personally subscribe to supporting those in this lucky nation of ours who are in need of care, supporting the aged and supporting those who are not as fortunate as the majority of the population. But I am rather deeply concerned about a trend that is sweeping this nation, a trend which I believe was started by the Labor Party, a trend which has not been stopped by my party, which has been in government for the last six years. I do not wish to moralise because what a person does with his or her body is not my business. However, it becomes my business when the working men and working women of my electorate, of my State and of this nation have to pick up the bill.

I will relate a story to the House of an experience I was confronted with during the recent recess. It perhaps exemplifies the paralysis of the nation in a particular area and explains and accounts for some of the growth of expenditure in the area of social security. Last week a young lady-for the sake of the story I will call her Marjorie-came to me and complained about the level of social security paid to a mother with two children. She explained, and properly so, that her pension payment represented about $199 per fortnight. Nobody in this House would find it easy to live on that amount of money. I said to Marjorie: 'Do you mind if I am personal?' She said: 'No, not at all'. I said: 'I only want to ask questions'. I said: 'You have two children. One is five and the other is one. Are you married?' She said: 'No, I have not married'. I said: 'Have you had any support from the fathers of the children or is it the father?' She said: 'One father'. I said: 'No support?' She said: 'Never a cent'. I said: 'You told me that one of your children is five and the other is one. Please tell me, having gone through that experience, how you could have fallen for the two-card trick?' She said: 'I thought of that, but I always wanted two children, so I thought it was best to go out and have them by the same man rather than different men'. That is fair enough. That is her decision. But the point is that she was in my office complaining about the level of support for her. She was in a Housing Commission home which would be worth $54.50 a week in rent if it were put on the market and utilised by a normal income earning family and she is paying only $19.50 a week. So there we have a $35 subsidy from the Government. On top of that, she has her benefits of about $99.50 a week, say. So we are up to about $135. On top of that, she has her entitlements to health care, which are worth about another $10 a week.

So Marjorie and her two children are receiving support from the Government to the extent of $145 a week. Some people may say: 'That is not much. You should give her more'. The point I am making is that, whilst I acknowledge Marjorie's right to do with her body what she wants, I also believe she has an obligation not only to those children but also to the working men and women of this country. I checked with the Taxation Office and found that to support Marjorie we would need the total income tax from one single man earning $225 a week gross, one married man earning about $260 a week gross and a sole parent with one child earning about $250 a week gross. The entire income tax contribution that those three people will pay will go to supporting Marjorie and her two children. I am not knocking motherhood. I am knocking an attitude in this country that we can do anything, we can do what we like, and then knock on a door and say: 'I want to be supported'.

In the remaining moments available to me I express my personal view that if anything is likely to destroy Australia it is the continued, unfettered growth of this attitude. I really believe that there is just so much that this country can carry. The country is already carrying a fair share. We have an aging population. We have to face up to the fact that there will be fewer people to work to provide for a greater pecentage of older people. If we simply keep going like this, oh how the lucky country will crumble.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free Mr R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Budget richly deserves to be condemned on any number of grounds but principally for its inhumanity and its dishonesty. The Australian people should never forget that this is the Government and this is the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) who came in six years ago on a promise of honesty. This is what the present Prime Minister had to say on the subject of honesty on 15 November 1975:

SPEECH.PARA: I can promise you honesty and integrity in government. I'd like to have a government which people can trust.

Less than a year after its return to office this Government has demonstrated its dishonesty and its lack of integrity with brutal clarity. It is a government that cannot be trusted. Its deceit and inhumanity are there for all to see, not just in this Budget, not just in the decisions of the razor gang, not just in the latest-the fifth-health scheme, but also in a whole range of sins of omission and commission and, as events this week have shown, in day to day administration. This is a government that trades on deceit. Where, in the Government's policy speech last year, did it tell the people of Australia that interest rates would go up yet again, that the Community Youth Support Scheme would go, that public health would be butchered and that the sales tax slug was on the way? When did the Government tell the people? Where is its mandate for these measures? The answer is that the Government did not tell the people at all and consequently it has no mandate for those measures.

This is a government that skates from one election to the next. It skates on the short term currency of rubbery promises that bounce well and truly once the election is out of the way. This is a Budget which is particularly silent on the important matter of assistance to home seekers and to home buyers. The silence of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Prime Minister on this matter is deafening. Of course, it was not always so. In fact, the Prime Minister and others in this Government are always most vocal on the question of interest rates before an election. This is what the Prime Minister had to say about interest rates on 21 November 1977:
Interest rates have begun to fall and they will keep on falling.
On 6 December 1977 the Prime Minister, again on interest rates, said:
Once the election is over, we will start to move to the consummation of a two per cent reduction in interest rates-and that means about $500 a year for someone on an average home loan.
The present Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) went one better in that election campaign. Speaking in Orange in the electorate of Calare just before the election in December 1977 he said:
If interest rates don't fall by two per cent I'll eat my hat.

At that time those were the promises on interest rates. What was the post-election reality? The reality is that since that time we have had six rises in interest rates. The impact on families buying or seeking to buy homes has been catastrophic. We all know of instances of people battling on with less and less, trying to pay off homes that they cannot afford to furnish, depending more and more on overtime, looking for a second family income, chasing part time work to make ends meet and to pay off a home. Many people are giving up and selling out in their struggle to pursue the great Australian dream of owning the family home.

Is it any wonder that under these circumstances, these rises in interest rates under this Government, foreclosures on home loans have increased so much? In 1973 one in 950 mortgages was foreclosed. In 1979 the rate was up to one in 70, an increase of over 13 times in foreclosures. Is it any wonder that under this Government it is becoming harder and harder for home seekers to get a loan? In fact, it has become so hard that sterilisation has actually become an advantage for home seekers. I refer to the National Times of 9 August to an article on page 3 headed 'The Unkindest Cut of All'. The first paragraph reads:
The Australian housing market has now reached the stage where sterilisation is an advantage in getting a loan.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some authorities even suggested it.
—That is true. The article continued:

SPEECH.PARA: A National Times survey has found that finance companies are favouring married couples where the woman is prepared to be sterilised.

What a situation we have reached when finance companies insist on a guarantee of that second income through means such as this in order to enhance people's chances of getting a loan. The Treasurer's line now on interest rates is two-pronged. The first defence of the Treasurer has been to deny responsibility in this matter and to point to market forces determining interest rates. In fact, he has adopted the defence that perhaps there is some virtue in higher interest rates because they mean more money invested and, therefore, more money for lending. Well, there are two obvious replies to the Treasurer's line on interest rates. The first one, which is utterly obvious, of course, is that really, if the Government has no intention of controlling interest rates even up to the point of denying that it can control them, then why, before an election, does it pretend that it can? Why does the Government raise expectations in this way? I respond to the Treasurer's second line of defence that higher interest rates mean more money for lending. If we have moved from a position where there is only enough money for one in four applicants to a new position where money is so expensive that only one in four applicants can afford it anyway, then where is the advantage in that situation?

Many people are still waiting for the Deputy Prime Minister to eat his hat. What a gastronomic spectacular that would be. I guess that under the present circumstances a hat might be less suspect fare than some of the dead horses that have been flogged around this country recently. Perhaps a hamburger might in these circumstances be preferable to a horseburger. As entertaining as that spectacle might be, the people of Australia would prefer, rather than see the Deputy Prime Minister eat his hat, to see action on the housing front. They would rather see cheaper money for housing. They would rather see tax assistance on interest repayments. Under this Government they will be waiting forever.

There is no doubt that average families are far worse off after this Budget and those measures which preceded it, in relation to not only housing costs but also health charges. We have certainly come a long way since 27 November 1975 when the Prime Minister told the people of this country: 'We will maintain Medibank'. There was no fine print in that statement, just four words: 'We will maintain Medibank'. This year, instead, we have seen the final destruction of Medibank, another Liberal promise dishonoured, another pre-election cheque that bounced. The Government's latest medi-muddle has spread confusion throughout the community. It has spread insecurity. It has meant that people are paying more and more for less and less. This downhill trend in family living standards will be accelerated by the taxation measures contained in this Budget. Income from pay-as-you-earn taxation will go up over 22 per cent this year. Tax indexation has gone. Of course, a host of new sales taxes have been introduced without the promised offsetting cuts in income tax.

Let us look at what some of the spokesmen for this Government have said in the past on questions of taxation. We find that this Government on taxation, as in so many other areas, is a government that cannot be trusted. The Prime Minister on 27 November 1975 on the subject of taxation said:
We will fully index personal income tax for inflation over three years. We will reduce the tax burden.
In his 1977 policy speech two years later, again on the taxation question, the present Prime Minister said:
We have ended the big tax rip-off.
Again in that election campaign, on 1 November 1977, the Prime Minister said:
From 1 February 1978 further tax cuts will come in for every Australian wage and salary earner . . . the Government will bring taxes down further-not increase them.

That was the fistful of dollars election. On that promise the Government ran full page newspaper advertisements in the metropolitan Press featuring that fistful of dollars. The message was quite brutal and quite clear: 'You give us votes, we will give you money'. How long did the promise last? That was the pre-election rhetoric. What was the reality? Full indexation was never introduced. For a time we had part indexation, but then even that was whipped away. Instead of a lower tax rate we have had a massive increase in the tax take. As I mentioned earlier, pay-as-you-earn tax collections are up by over 22 per cent this year, more than double the expected inflation rate. Finally-surprise, surprise-after the earlier promise of this Government, we have had a host of new sales tax measures, a further blow to family incomes and family living standards.

I have listened with interest to the Treasurer twisting and turning under questioning about the extent of the impact of the new sales tax measures on families. Really it seems to me to be quite a simple matter to calculate the effect of the new sales tax measures on family living standards. If we look at the Budget Papers we will find that the income from the new sales tax measures contained in this Budget is quite easy to add up. First of all, by increasing the existing rates the Government will raise an extra $420m a year. From the new 2 1/2 per cent rate it will raise an additional $330m a year. From the correction of anomalies provision it will raise an additional $142m a year. The total take from the new measures will add up to $892m a year. The estimated working population in 1981 is 4.72 million people. When one divides the first figure by the second figure, using an electronic calculator, which, of course, is more expensive under these sales tax provisions now, we find that the additional sales tax to be paid by each person each year amounts to $60.60, or $1.17 a week. The average family of three people will be paying an additional $3.50 a week because of the new sales tax measures. However, a young family of, say, two children and their parents will pay an additional $4.68 a week. That is without taking into account the fact that young families will be spending more on major household goods and in looking after the needs of the children. As the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Donald Cameron) said a short time ago, in attending to the needs of children going to school by buying expensive school shoes and so on, it is obvious that the young growing families will be bearing the brunt of the sales tax burden.

The most objectionable feature of these sales tax measures is that they hit not luxury items but necessities. There is a doubling of sales tax on furniture, white goods and floor coverings. Shoes and clothing have been hit. Books and newspapers have been taxed-a tax on knowledge and a tax on the free exchange of information. As the executive director of the Library Association of Australia said earlier this month, a tax on books is not the act of a civilised, developed country. It is a tax also on safety. We note from the Budget Papers that sales tax on seat belts will go up from nothing to 17 1/2 per cent. There are few items untouched. They include food, medicine and wine, but not packaging. I note with some amusement down towards the bottom of one of the Schedules that also untouched are certain parts of toilet pans. I have some sympathy with the newspaper correspondent who wondered whether this last item reflected the Government's own assessment of its Budget or an anticipation of public reaction to it.

I should also mention, as has almost every speaker in this debate, the destruction of the Community Youth Support Scheme in this Budget. This is a scheme which has assisted some 200,000 young people. It has operated some 276 projects and has harnessed the skills and dedication of some 2,000 instructors, tutors and project officers. It is a low cost scheme and a very successful scheme. The success of the scheme was admitted in the annual report of the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs for the year 1979-80. In that report the Department said:

CYSS has expanded rapidly since its inception and a review and rationalisation of the scheme during the 1979-80 financial year consolidated its progress and provided a sound base on which future community based projects can be developed.

The report said that the progress had been consolidated and that the scheme provided a sound base. Yet this is the scheme that is to end on 31 October. The 117,000 teenagers currently unemployed, the school leavers, the staff of the scheme and the local communities are all entitled to ask why the scheme has been axed and where the Government expects them to go from here.

This is a Budget which is also largely silent on the needs of the underprivileged. There is no doubt that under this Government the ranks of the poor have continued to swell. In fact in the last six years there has been a massive redistribution of income away from families, away from the needy and away from the desperately poor. As Graham Williams pointed out in a series of excellent articles in the Sydney Morning Herald last month, the Government was saved some $800m by failing to index a whole range of welfare benefits. About $180m has been saved by not indexing the $36 unemployment benefit for those aged under 18. Some $210m has been saved by not indexing the unemployment benefit for single adults. The new increased rate this year will be $11.60 a week behind the base rate for all pensioners. About $145m has been saved by not indexing the weekly allowance for each dependent child of a pensioner. If these allowances had been indexed, they would be worth $14.40 a week instead of $10. The family allowance was increased for third and subsequent children in this Budget, but if it had been indexed for the children of the 25 per cent of poorest families, the Government would have paid out $170m more than it has. The result of these cuts in real income to large groups of the poor, as well as rising rentals, has led to a phenomenal demand for emergency aid. Graham Williams quotes in his article one welfare worker. She said:
No one is able to cope with the huge growth in poverty. The poor are at their wits end trying to get clothes and a little cash to tide them over. It's really frightening to see how bad things are.

Welfare agencies, including State agencies, now give an estimated $60m a year in emergency aid to the poor, but the Federal Government in six years has given the private agencies only $500,000 to assist. There is a whole range of other indicators showing that poverty in this country under this Government is intensifying. Rents for the poor are rising. There is a huge increase in the number of people seeking public housing and, of course, there have been major cut-backs in Federal programs. These cuts all show, as Graham Williams said in his article and as Professor Ronald Henderson told the Sydney Morning Herald, that those in need are suffering the most under the Fraser Government. That is the situation with the poor and needy in this country this year. But what was the promise? This is what the Prime Minister had to say on 12 December 1975:
We will protect those in need of help. Medibank, pensions, education and social welfare will all be strengthened by honest responsible government.

This Budget is part of the deceitful cycle of action of this Liberal Government. Stage one in the cycle is before the election when the people are promised anything-honesty, lower taxes, prosperity, a fistful of dollars-lead them on. That was the last slogan-'Lead on, Liberal'. I point out to honourable members opposite that the dictionary definition of 'lead on' is to entice into going further than was intended, as in 'lead up the garden path'. That is exactly what stage one of the Liberal action cycle is-to lead people on, to promise anything before an election.

Stage two after the elections is the bitter reality. This is when the promises are dishonoured. This is when the pre-election promises bounce. The result is a confused and a disillusioned community, a community that does not know where it stands on a whole range of matters. It does not know where it stands on social welfare. It does not know where it stands on interest rates, health care or taxation. But the one thing that people do know is where they stand in respect of promises and performances of this Government. They reject this Budget because they can see it for what it is. It is a recipe for higher inflation, for higher unemployment, for falling living standards and for more misery. Equally they will reject the Government responsible for it at the first opportunity.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Sinclair)-by leave-agreed to:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Prime Minister speaking for a period not exceeding 35 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Central to every Budget brought down by this Government, to every action with significant economic implications, has been our recognition of the critical role of economic policy in creating a favourable environment, for individual initiative and a growing private sector, for effective humanitarian concern and greater assistance for the needy, for balanced economic development throughout Australia and sustained confidence in Australia's future. This Budget highlights the gulf between the Australian economy as it was in 1975 and the Australian economy as it is today, with our international reputation restored, with well-founded projections for growth, higher employment and better wages, and with the enhanced potential for personal income tax reductions which even the Opposition has not failed to perceive within this Budget. When this Government came to office in 1975 inflation was high; it was above world levels; and it was uncontrolled: Unemployment was growing and private sector employment actually shrinking; and confidence was shot to pieces. How different is the picture today, with inflation below world levels, with nearly 300,000 new private sector jobs created in the two years to May, and with very great confidence indeed in this country, as evidenced particularly by the widespread investment in the manufacturing and mining industries that is now taking place. All of this comes from the steady application of responsible economic policies by this Government. It comes particularly, as it will continue to come, from the successive Budgets of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I want, first, to say something about this particular Budget's strategy in the context of the Government's overall economic objectives. I shall put it to the House that the virtual elimination of the deficit in this Budget will be seen in years ahead as a landmark in Australia's development, that any claim that this Government is a high spending or a high taxing Government does not stand up, and that expenditure restraint must continue to be a matter of fundamental priority. Secondly, I want to explain to the House the success of the Government's commitment to combining expenditure restraint and economic responsibility, with effective care and concern for the legitimate expectations, the real needs, and the authentic aspirations of the Australian community. I will put it to the House that our programs are effective and progressive, that they identify priorities and balance the total range of human concerns, and that any suggestion that the Government does not care and does not understand, simply flies in the face of the record.

The strategy of this year's Budget is unmistakable in the virtual elimination of the deficit which has been achieved. The $3.5 billion Budget deficit which the Government inherited from the Labour Government, which would have been even higher without the expenditure reductions immediately made by this Government when it came to office, would now be almost $7.5 billion if we had persisted with deficit financing at the Labor rate of almost five per cent of gross domestic product. The Government has consistently rejected deficit financing as totally inappropriate for Australia's circumstances through the 1970s and into the 19801s, for these circumstances are quite different from those which existed in the 1930's when deficit financing became respectable and, as Keynes himself would unquestionably have recognised. Australia is still paying the price for Labor's irresponsible deficits, for those deficits are still distorting Australia's capital market, and still contributing to excessive interest rates as the loans that had to be raised at the time to fund the deficit are still having to be rolled over and renewed. The Labor deficit was nothing more than a way of making the future pay for the spending schemes of the past, either through inflation, or through higher taxes, or both. Deficit financing encourages expectations that are unreal and it means dishonesty about the real level of taxation.

With the virtual elimination of the deficit in this Budget, we can plan next year's Budget no longer hostage to this element of the Labor Government's mismanagement and with the enhanced potential for tax cuts which I have already referred to. The Government has got rid of the massive Labor deficit partly by an honest approach to taxation and partly by rigorous restraint on its spending. We have worked at the problem from both ends. Our more honest approach to taxation, which has involved lifting Commonwealth revenue by 2.4 percentage points as a proportion of gross domestic product has gone into getting rid of the deficit. The Government's view has been that our children should not have to pay the costs of the Government programs of today. The Opposition calls this a high tax approach which only shows again that the Opposition simply does not care about the long term development or future of this country. The claim that this Government is a high tax Government simply does not stand up. And if we look at the sales tax increases and the Government's objectives in connection with them, objectives of deficit elimination, of reduced pressure on interest rates, of a better balance in the tax mix, and of enhanced potential for personal income tax reductions, the Government's overriding concern with reducing the burden on the community of taxation and of the high costs of Government is again apparent.

Expenditure restraint has been the major ingredient of this Government's approach to getting rid of the deficit and to making room for the private sector growth on which the future prosperity of Australia so fundamentally depends. In the Labor years the average annual real growth of Budget outlays was just over 10 per cent. Between 1975-76 and 1980-81, under the present Government, that figure is just over 1 per cent. The restraint of this Government is highlighted further if we look at what has happened in some major overseas countries, countries which are themselves concerned to achieve expenditure restraint. While Britain has matched Australia's achievement, the Australian figure of 1.2 per cent stands in stark contrast to the comparable figures of nearly 3 per cent for West Germany, about 5 per cent for the United States of America, and over 10 per cent for Japan. The most important index of Government spending is the number of cents which it takes out of every dollar of gross domestic product. The proportion of gross domestic product which the Government spends is not only vital to the number of dollars in actual pay packets; it determines whether there is enough room for expansion and growth in the private sector.

In 1975-76, the Commonwealth Government spent 30.1 cents of every dollar that Australia produced. In 1981-82, the Commonwealth Government will be spending 2 1/2 cents less than in 1975-76 of every dollar produced in Australia. This reduction, which would be nearly 3 cents but for the extra payday which comes at twelve year intervals, means that the Government will be spending $3.7 billion less than if the 1975-76 proportion had, in fact, continued.

This Government's reduction in Budget outlays as a proportion of gross domestic product stands in stark contrast to the increase under labor from less than 24 per cent to more than 30 per cent. Everybody knows how much easier it is to spend more, rather than less. The steady progress which this Government has sustained in reducing its expenditure requirements has come about only as a result of the Government's resolute commitment to the cause of expenditure restraint and more limited Government. This Government will continue to maintain expenditure restraint and will continue the task of bringing down its outlays as a proportion of GDP towards the more moderate levels which prevailed before the Whitlam years.

Let me turn from the Government's expenditure restraint to its borrowing restraint because, in the end, borrowing is a form of expenditure. This year's Budget makes a substantial contribution over and above the reductions already achieved in the Loan Council towards reducing Government borrowing requirements and a central objective of this is to ease the pressure on interest rates. The interest rates which currently prevail are produced by three main factors; inflation, the pressure of demand within Australia, and the impact of overseas factors. A prospering Australia, where business investment and business borrowing are surging ahead, cannot hope to cut itself off entirely from overseas trends in interest rates, and overseas trends have been upwards in recent years.

This overseas pressure, together with the demand that is arising out of growth in the Australian economy, explains why it is imperative that all governments should pull back their borrowing demands. Between 1975-76 and 1980-81, the Commonwealth Government has achieved a reduction of over $2 billion in its own and its authorities' borrowing requirements, and there will be a further reduction of about $1 billion this year. While substantial public sector borrowing is needed to provide infrastructure for the private sector economic developments now taking place, that borrowing must not be so high that it squeezes out these developments, for all loans are ultimately drawn from the same pool of funds, and larger borrowing by governments reduce the availability of funds, not only for large investment projects, but also for home owners, farmers and small businesses and tend to push up interest rates at the same time.

All governments need to be aware that the dollars which they borrow could be used for other purposes, that the money which goes into a $10m government loan might have been used to provide 300 or 400 housing loans. While interest rates are obviously too high at their present levels, it must also be recognised that the people who provide the funds for borrowing will need an adequate return if they are to continue to invest their capital in this way, and the fact that the present housing interest rates are little different from the average rates through the 1960s when infiation is taken into account serves again to demonstrate the insidious nature of inflation and the continuing need to get it down in the cause of lower interest rates.

Bringing down inflation has of course been a vital target in the Government's expenditure restraint and the continued containment of inflation obviously remains a primary economic objective of the Government. The restraint of this Government, both in terms of spending and borrowing, has been remarkable by any standards, as other countries recognise. It is even more remarkable in view of the fact that the priority areas of social security, welfare and defence, which have required real increases over the period in question, encompass such a high proportion of Budget outlays-more than 37 per cent this year.

I have been speaking of what this Government has achieved over almost six years through its consistently applied Budget strategy. But while the Budget is the major economic vehicle through which the Government's philosophy and priorities are given concrete expression, many other activities of Government have a significant impact indeed in their own right on the well-being of Australians and the prospects for increasing prosperity. The Review of Commonwealth Functions provides a particular example. The results of the Review contributed significantly to restraining expenditure this year but to assess the RCF exercise only in this perspective is to miss its main point, for out of that Review have come decisions which will strengthen the role of the private sector, reduce government interference in private sector decision-making and restore the State governments responsibility and ultimate control over areas of activity which are rightly theirs. The impact of these outcomes is not to be measured merely in dollars and cents. Indeed, in some cases their monetary value would be virtually impossible to estimate, but they will offer huge long-term benefits in increasing the strength of Australian federalism and the vitality of the Australian economy.

Another area of Commonwealth Government decision-making which has significant implications for long term prosperity is that of tariffs and protection. This is an area of decision-making fraught with difficulties, for we are well aware that the long term benefits of a more competitive and efficient Australian economy need to be balanced against the costs to those whose employment prospects may be put at risk and the consequences for those who have made substantial investments under existing protection policies. On many occasions the Government has stated its view that Australia should move progressively towards lower levels of protection in order to promote the development of a manufacturing industry which will be more internationally competitive. In the last three years in particular, as the Industries Assistance Commission has moved through its progressive series of reviews of assistance to all sectors, we have taken many decisions which over a period will phase down protection in a wide range of industries including iron and steel, rubber products, chemicals, sporting equipment and, starting in 1982, textiles, clothing and footwear.

We have also recently acted to eliminate, except in the case of certain defence-strategic high technology industries, an additional element of protection to Australian industry afforded through a margin of preference in Commonwealth Government purchasing. Now that the IAC has almost completed its series of tariff reviews, we have asked the Commission to report by early 1982 on what options are available to achieve further reductions in protection. I want to emphasise that gradualism and the avoidance of disruption are indispensable elements in the Government's approach and policies in this area. In these and other ways, the Government has sought to promote the necessary conditions for a dynamic economy and a prosperous society. In doing so, however, we have not forgotten that change and progress, even prosperity itself, inevitably confront people with pressures and problems, that sound and responsible economic management must be integrated with care and concern for the needs of people.

Let me turn to this wider issue, bearing in mind that a Budget does not demonstrate genuine concern about people or their well-being unless it faces up to economic reality with firmness, with conviction, with balance, and with that proper caution which does not place hard won gains at risk. It also needs to be understood that Budgetary policy is not just a matter of cutting up this year's national cake, which is what the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) boils it down to in the end, and that while Budget allocations have an immediate and critical bearing on the well-being of a significant proportion indeed of Australians, Australians overall should obviously be looking to a healthy economy rather than a few dollars and cents in the Budget for their economic well-being. What better illustration of this could there be than the increase of $2.7 billion, after tax, in real household disposable income that was achieved last year as a result of the economic growth and activity which this Government's policies have generated.

In considering this Government's policies on the great issues of human concern and the real needs of people the starting point must be our concern and the real needs of people, the starting point must be our programs for young people because it is this Government which has concentrated on equipping those who are not academically inclined with useful work skills, and this Government which has based its policies on the premise that young people who are not at work ought where possible to be in education or training. The Government has sustained its original commitment to the development of a skilled work force, with particular emphasis on youth, and prominent among our major initiatives are the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training scheme, the Special Youth Employment Training Program and the School to Work Transition Program. Under these initiatives, a record 95,000 apprentices will receive assistance this year compared with only 21,000 assisted in 1975-76 by the old apprenticeship scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about CYSS?

—The honourable member should wait. Some 90,000 young people will be able to obtain work experience including longer term experience for 12,000 of those who have had the greatest difficulty in finding jobs, and 23,000 young people will receive training under the transition programs in technical and further education institutions alone. The Government has also introduced a variety of smaller scale schemes because the Government's initiatives cater for the real problems in this area. The programs implemented by the Government are appreciated throughout the community and nobody in the community would want to deny the importance of the Government's concern in relation to this matter. The total allocation in the 1981-82 Budget, directed towards training schemes and transitional programs is more than $24m, almost 40 per cent up on last year's allocation, and upwards of 225,000 young people will be receiving assistance. The fact that unemployment has come down by over 20,000 in the year to August for young people seeking full time work and by over 25,000 for those seeking part time work shows the effectiveness of our policies.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the Government's initiatives and support for disabled and handicapped persons where assistance is being provided this year involving an overall expenditure of $1.1 billion. This figure might be doubled or trebled without the real needs that exist being fully met, by the real increase of 39 per cent on the Labor figure of 1975-76 shows the very considerable and sympathetic commitment of this Government to the well-being of handicapped and disabled persons.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about in real terms?

—That is in real terms. The Government's view is that a wide range of programs and forms of assistance are required to meet the needs that exist. About 280 projects have been approved to date for the 1980-83 triennium in the handicapped persons welfare program. A new progam of aids for disabled people who were not covered by existing programs was established last June and the national employment strategy for the handicapped is improving services and increasing assistance under the training programs at a cost of $4m this year. Three new initiatives in the Budget, which will have a significant impact on the lifestyles of handicapped and disabled people, are: A new permanent scheme for assistance in the production of audio books in addition to Braille books; a new scheme of support for the establishment of radio services to supply spoken word services; and the new Australian caption centre, which will provide access to television programs for people with impaired hearing. The Government is acutely aware of the difficulty of allocating priorities in relation to the needs of disabled persons. A fundamental principle of government policy is to assist disabled persons to live normal lives wherever and so far as this is possible. Our commitment to making real gains in meeting the needs of disabled persons in our community will be maintained.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to Aboriginal affairs where health care, employment opportunities and self-management initiatives are among the most central concerns and objectives of government policy. In this Budget health grants to Aboriginal medical services, at almost $5 1/2m, have more than doubled in real terms since 1975-76, and are up 22 per cent on last year's allocation; $50m is to be provided over 5 years for the Aboriginal public health improvement program, $8m of it this year; $47m will be provided this year for Aboriginal education and training; and a further $25m has been allocated specifically for employment and related programs for Aboriginals. Some $78m will be provided through various programs for Aboriginal housing. Grants to Aboriginal legal services will increase by almost 20 per cent over last year; to Aboriginal cultural and recreational organisations by 18 per cent; and funds for social support schemes will increase by 24 per cent. The well-being of the Aboriginal people concerns the Government as it concerns the vast majority of Australians and while a great many of the initiatives which need to be developed require a financial commitment, initiatives of a different order are equally required. In relation to the profoundly important objective of self-management, the Aboriginal Development Commission is an exciting initiative which is attracting overseas interest. It was established only after detailed consultations with Aboriginal organisations and communities, including the National Aboriginal Conference. It already has over 60 per cent of its positions occupied by Aboriginals. In this year it has available over $50m for spending on Aboriginal advancement programs. This Government also promoted the establishment of the National Aboriginal Conference-a body elected by Aboriginals to give independent advice to the government on matters affecting the Aboriginal people and with which successive Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs have developed strong ties. The Government continues to seek co-operative progress in meeting the special claims and particular needs of Aboriginals. While there is much that may be said about the treatment of Aboriginal people in earlier times, I believe that the record of achievement over the last decade or two-a record to which both sides of this House have made significant and impressive contributions-provides a basis for confidence that progress will continue as a matter of urgency and of the highest priority.

I turn to the Budget allocation for assistance to aged persons. This is an area which raises issues and dilemmas of profound significance for the community, especially in the situation in which there is not only an increase in the aged population but also in which the legitimacy of established expectations and the policy of directing government assistance to the needy cannot be reconciled completely in practice. Assistance for the aged is directed to three major areas of need: Pensions and other income support; services which enable aged persons to remain in their own homes; and assistance for people who require either sheltered accomodation or nursing care. This year's allocations illustrate the degree of this Government's commitment to its policy of protecting basic pensions against inflation-a policy which we regard as crucial in ensuring social justice especially for those whose only source of income support is their pension. The Government has, through indexation, maintained the real value of pensions with the cost of the 1981-82 increases amounting to about $430m in a full year for aged pensions alone. The upper income limit at which an aged couple can receive some pension payment will be $266 per week after November this year, compared with $163 per week when this Government came to office. The Government continued to provide assistance for home care, meals-on-wheels, and senior citizens centres at a cost of over $23m this year. Support is also being provided towards the capital costs of nursing homes, hostels and self-contained accommodation and personal care subsidy. In all, at $4.6 billion for this year, assistance for the aged has more than doubled since this Government came to office-a real increase of 20 per cent since 1975-76.

I turn to multicultural affairs and services to migrants where this Government's achievements are again meeting the needs, the concerns and the aspirations of so many members of the Australian community. The Galbally report, which was designed as a review of services to migrants, has become a symbol of a transforming vision of Australian society. It recommended that $50m will be spent on new or expanded programs over three years. We have more than met our commitment to this expenditure through expanded settlement and migrant education programs, establishment of migrant resource courses, the development of multicultural television and ethnic radio, establishment of the Institute of Multicultural Affairs, the funding of ethnic schools, and the ongoing teaching of ethnic languages and culture. The Galbally vision is increasingly becoming a reality. There has obviously been major expenditure on a very large number of programs and services for immigrants and for ethnic communities. But the truly significant aspect of all this is not so much the financial commitment involved, but rather that multicultural Australia has been made a reality under the auspices of this Government, and to a significant extent as a result of its initiatives and encouragement.

The 1981-82 Budget combines responsible economic management with effective care for people and their concerns. The list of initiatives and achievements which I have presented is by no means exhaustive. The same picture of effective achievement of progressive Liberal objectives would emerge in an examination of grants for local government, of grants for overseas aid, of increases in family allowances and in attention to veterans' affairs. Any suggestion that this Government has concentrated on economic management to the exclusion of broader concerns and issues is wholly groundless. Any suggestion that the Government has lost sight of its own Liberal objectives, or its commitment to the way of life which Australians want, is wholly groundless. Of course, the Government recognises the importance of a strong economy as a pre-condition for the realisation of wider social and cultural objectives. That recognition has been written large in the balance which has been maintained in our pursuit of social and humanitarian objectives and in the rigorous way that we have always given first place to the highest priorities. It is this concentration on priorities which has allowed the Government to make significant increases in allocations to areas of need while maintaining expenditure restraint and building up the Australian economy.

Above all, the Government's policies reflect its fundamental philosophy that individual Australians and Australian families have the right and must have the freedom to decide for themselves their own needs, their own way of life. Our policies-unlike the Opposition's-are designed to give a constructive, positive and properly limited role to government to make room for private enterprise: to make Australia strong by moving in a responsible and balanced way to a more competitive economy; to give people greater control over their own incomes by firmly setting this country on the only course leading to lower taxation; to develop opportunity, choice and power over their own lives for all Australians by appropriate government programs for Aborigines, migrants, the elderly and the young; to make government strong to protect the weak and open doors for the disadvantaged; and to make individuals strong to defend their rights and build the kind of life they want for themselves. In six years, Australia has been brought from the chaos of the Labor disaster to a condition of strength and prosperity with unrivalled prospects and a magnificent future.
Sitting suspended from 6.1 to 8 p.m.
