TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment moved by my colleague, the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis). The amendment moved to the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1981-82 substantially spells out the direct opposition that I have to this Budget in clear and unmistakable detail. The Budget strategy of the Government is yet another onslaught on that section of the Australian community least able to defend itself. During the years of the Whitlam Government a series of initiatives were taken. Whilst they did not solve the difficulties of the community or the capitalist society in general, at least they set in train a basis for a concensus in regard to decent living standards, social welfare, education, housing for the underprivileged, the socially and economically deprived including pensioners, Aborigines and other groups at risk. Yet even this meagre attack on the evils of our society was regarded as a development that had to be reversed.

SPEECH.PARA: According to the warped minds of the landed gentry and the blue bloods who control the Liberal National Country Party-the coalition-we were heading into a form of socialism that had to be destroyed at all costs. That is not just fundamental to Australian society. In general it is found in a world wide pattern. We have the Reagan Administration and the Thatcher Administration and we now have our Prime Minister (Mr Malcom Fraser) who does not have enough guts to reverse one decision that was spelt out in the Budget Speech. That is the matter of the Community Youth Support Scheme. The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) had to go on television this evening to announce the reversal of the position in regard to the funding of CYSS and a new campaign. The Prime Minister of this country did not have the courage to say that in a half hour speech to the House this evening. What sort of courage is that? This reversal in the face of at least a consensus that I referred to in the initial stages was indicative of the thuggery led by the Prime Minister of this country and his cohorts on the front bench. He had the audacity last night to try to defend an indefensible position. The Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair), caught yet again in another scandal, was defended by the Prime Minister in such a way that he would not have to worry about his enemies if he has friends such as the Prime Minister. He did not defend the matter at all; he just toughed it out. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) again was challenged by the Opposition. What happened again? The Prime Minister could muster exactly seven minutes to defend him. He did not utter one word to defend him but went on with a lot of garble that we on this side of the House have learnt to expect. It means absolutely nothing.

A lot of posturing will go on in the next couple of weeks. The three people I mentioned-Reagan, Thatcher, and Fraser, the Prime Minister of this country-have something in common. He will go off to America and will speak to Reagan after he has done his posturing at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in the next two weeks. What a paragon of virtue! What a wolf in sheep's clothing! What a great defender of democracy and of the underprivileged of this country! What a great defender of the Aborigines of this country! Honourable members should go and have a look in the back blocks of the Northern Territory, Queensland and Western Australia. He should bring the people he will talk to in America over here and show them exactly how Aborigines are treated in this country and then see how he stands up to the test. Once again, this gutless wonder who stood up here for half an hour this evening--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. He knows very well, because he has been a member of this House for some little time, that he may not impugn another member of this House, from the Prime Minister to the lowest member of parliament, in those terms. I ask him to withdraw.
—That probably gives him a wrap, so I will withdraw it.
—The honourable member will resume his seat.
—I withdraw unequivocally.
—I call the honourable member for Melbourne.

—The Budget strategy is indicative of that arrogance which knows no bounds. After six years of Budgets and obnoxious attacks on the livelihood of the people to whom I have referred, what do we have under the banner of fighting inflation, increasing employment availability and increasing socio-economic opportunities for the poor; people who find themselves on the lowest spokes of fortune's wheel? We have a Budget strategy that is indicative of the areas I pointed out.

SPEECH.PARA: Education spending has fallen by 2 per cent; health spending is down by 22 per cent; transport and communications spending is down by 53 per cent; water supply, electricity and gas spending is down by 50 per cent; and the general housing construction is down by 59 per cent. If, for instance, we look at the alternatives, where is the redistribution of wealth? The wealth has gone to the people who run the Liberal and National Country Parties. Those who invested their fortunes in Australia will reap the results. The redistribution of wealth in this country is in that direction. Once again the needy and those who depend on social welfare will pay the price. Will there be a relief in taxation? Will there be relief in unemployment, the rate of inflation, interest rates and, as I mentioned before, taxes? Certainly not!

In the time available to me, I will refer to three or four specific matters that are relevant to the strategy I pointed out. One other aspect of the strategy of the Government is to hand over the whole running of this community-not only running it behind the scene but also directly by supplying the wherewithal-to private enterprise which results in million of dollars being poured into the pockets of private enterprise. In regard to housing, the people who have been relegated to the status of second class citizens are those who are unfortunate enough-and young people predominantly are-to need to try to find themselves a home. Once they are married they have to place themselves in hock for the rest of their lives. It was indeed bad enough 12 months to two years ago, but where do they find themselves at present? They are in a worse situation because of the availability of housing loans not purely on the basis of the money that is available but in regard to the wherewithal to service their loans.

During the last session of the Parliament, I raised a number of questions about the operation of permanent building societies. I expressed concern at the numbers of homes being repossessed by those societies. Since then, the monetary policies of the Government have ensured that even more Australian families will find themselves on the street. The interest rate increases, encouraged by the Treasurer (Mr Howard), have placed an unbearable burden on many families who will find their monthly repayments beyond their means. The Government claims it has increased emergency housing funding in this Budget by 22 per cent. Many people at both State and local government levels must wonder what happens to this increased funding. The Government claims it has increased its emergency funding all right, but I suggest that every cent of the welfare housing finance will be required to meet the needs of hundreds of families who will be left homeless because of the Government's policies. At the same time as these families are faced with crippling increases in home repayment costs, they also have to face increased medical and hospital costs, new or increased sales taxes on many essential items and, in my State, increases in energy prices. The impact of these added costs will be devastating for many families. The effect will compound when the unscrupulous among the building societies get their tentacles in.

Therefore, I will suggest several steps which the Government could and ought to take to assist these families in their dealings with building societies. Further, I argue that any people over many years who have been charged penalties by building societies under certain contracts ought to have their money refunded, depending on the time the societies--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is for State governments.

—My friend the honourable member for Phillip, who has just woken up, talks about this being a State government problem. That is what the Minister said. Of course the organisation which repossesses the houses is the direct responsibility of the Federal Minister. I do not know how much the honourable member knows about it. He is a barrister. For God's sake, how would honourable members like him defend them? He does not even know that the responsibility for repossessing houses rests with the Federal Minister for Housing and Construction.

SPEECH.PARA: In making these comments, I do not want to include societies which may fully inform borrowers of their rights. There was a case in England which proved conclusively, beyond doubt, that if these societies do not advise those who borrow from them the amounts that they are required to repay there is no obligation on the individuals concerned. I put it to the Federal Minister that, unless his obligation in that regard is so superficial, he ought to do something about the people in Australia who are robbed of their possessions by societies such as the Statewide Building Society in Victoria and the shonky lawyers who represent that society.

Another area we ought to look at is the situation in education institutions. The educational needs of the multicultural and socially disadvantaged communities in Melbourne require attention. It is not good enough simply to say that this is another State matter. In 1976, the Victorian Department of Education imposed staff ceilings on all State schools. These ceilings were set at below the actual number of teachers already employed. The ceilings were clearly not related to any educationally based decision but rather to an economic and political one. Decisions about staffing are ultimately made by the Federal and State Treasuries through the respective Ministers for education. The decline in staffing has been coupled with a decline in teaching conditions as well as a decline in the students' learning conditions. For instance, the ad hoc cutbacks in recent years have had a devastating effect on curriculums.

Cutbacks have not affected the private school sector to the same degree. In fact, money is being diverted from the state sector to the private school sector. Non-government schools receive 56 per cent of Federal Government recurrent funds while catering for only 20 per cent of the students. This squeeze on the state education system has led to centralised decision-making which leaves little, if any, room for input from teachers, students and parents. Because the special needs component can be ascertained only by the school community involved, the centralised decision-making system has had a disastrous effect on schools with acute needs resulting from economic and/or ethnic disadvantage. Rigid staffing formulas have led to the dismantling of previously existing school programs.

I wish to bring to the attention of the House the effect that the funding priorities of the Fraser Government has had on the education available to young people in my electorate. I do not have the time to go through all the examples that could be put forward in that regard. However, I point out that I was a member of a committee on specific learning difficulties during my period in this Parliament. One has only to read that committee's report to find out precisely how students in both areas-public and secular-have suffered at the hands of this Government.

Let me take the matter further and go into the area of unemployment and the Community Youth Support Scheme. In Melbourne, for example, young boys and girls are prostituting themselves on the streets to keep a roof over their heads. If anyone wants to deny or question that, I suggest that he asks the Salvation Army and other religious agencies in my electorate about it. These young boys and girls are prey to perverts and other individuals who oppress them and place them in all sorts of mitigating situations. Some of these young people are too ashamed to go back to their families because they cannot get a job. What is the result? We have the pressures applied by this Government and, adding insult to injury, the Government then takes away the funding of at least some of the counselling agencies where these young people could go day after day for the purpose of getting some relief and to talk to people who are in the same situation.

But what has happened insofar as this Government's policy is concerned? This Government has shown the same disregard for the position of these young people as it has for the pensioners, the homeless and others. The Government purely applies an economic formula to what these young people are all about. The Government says, out of hand: 'We will stop that system without even making a close examination of it'. When asked by church people and people involved in counselling agencies to reconsider, the Government refused point blank. The Minister came into this chamber and said that the Government would not change its Budget strategy.

TALK.START.PARA: —He wouldn't talk to them.
—The Minister would not talk to the people involved. He moved around my electorate like a professional bedsniffer, going to the various CYSS projects, popping in, trying to find something wrong.
—Creeping.

—The honourable member for Holt is right; 'creeping' is the right expression. Having done that, trying to build up a case for abandoning CYSS, and having come into this chamber and defended the policy of this Government, the Minister suddenly finds that the Prime Minister has ratted on him. The Minister has been the front man. He has done what he could. He does not do much, but he has shown what he could do in the area I have just mentioned. He has indicated to this House that the Government would not do anything about retaining CYSS. But the Prime Minister stood here for half an hour tonight and, with all due respect to you Mr Deputy Speaker, once again did not have the intestinal fortitude to make that announcement himself. He had his puppet go out this afternoon and make that announcement in the media.
—Shameful.

—It was an absolutely shameful performance, but that is par for the course. In the time left to me I would like to speak about the handing over of private enterprise and how successful private enterprises, such as Telecom Australia, are being starved to death of funds. Government policies applied to Telecom are not in accord with the best interests of Telecom. The government has taken interest rates out of the loans which were afforded to Telecom during the time of its commission, thereby increasing the rates to people in the communications area. What I am saying is this: The capital program applied by the Government is forcing Telecom into a series of situations which is forcing up the rates of communication. The Australian Postal Commission is in a similar situation. The common letter traffic has been making a profit over the last four or five years. What is happening now? Junk mail, such as the Reader's Digest and all the journals of various organisations, are being subsidised by pensioners and others who have no other means of communication than the 24c letter. In my view, the amendment should be supported If anybody on the other side of the House had the courage of his convictions, he would support the amendment. What I have said this evening justifies support of the amendment. I hope it is carried
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —As my friend and colleague the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Innes) said, the presentation of the Federal Budget is an event of national significance. Over the past weeks, political commentators, members of parliament and the community have had time to analyse this Budget. It is understandable that we have had many complaints from sectional interests. The mining industry has seen its tax deductions halved and all exports of black coal not presently subject to duty will now become dutiable at the rate of $1 per tonne. Surely these small charges are acceptable to an industry which has been given substantial government and taxpayer encouragement in the developmental stage, and which knows it will continue to receive this encouragement.

SPEECH.PARA: None of us like the impact of a more general sales tax. However, the reasons for its introduction are valid. Australians pay higher personal income taxes to government revenue than most other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. This has been a major disincentive to the average worker to work, to save and to invest in his own future and in the future of Australia. It is estimated that income tax receipts on individuals and companies in 1981-82 will be $26,000m or 64 per cent of total government receipts. On the other hand, excise, customs duties and sales taxes will account for only 27.7 per cent of Government receipts. It is, therefore, of significance that the opportunity has been taken to broaden the tax mix by raising extra revenue through a 2 1/2 per cent increase in sales tax and the rectification of taxation anomalies. The credibility of the Government is dependent on these changes being reflected in substantial-I repeat, substantial-personal income tax cuts in the near future.

I make some criticisms of these changes. One is where some measures by their effect are, in my view, retrospective. I believe the Treasurer (Mr Howard) has to ensure by clear direction to the Australian Taxation Office that new sales taxes must not apply in any area where documented evidence can be produced or where contracts or orders were entered into before the Budget night. In some individual cases I am aware of, and of which I have provided full documentation to the Treasurer, major purchasing decisions made months ago under existing tax rates could well threaten the viability of business if forced now to pay sales tax increases. I express also my opposition to the sales tax on books, magazines and newspapers. Whilst most countries have taxes-some as high as 22 per cent on these items-Australia does not need to follow suit. I see this as a disincentive to the free flow of information. The Government should reconsider this unnecessary impost.

We should not, however, lose sight of the real purpose of a Federal Budget and the economic responsibility of a national government. That purpose is to manage effectively the economy in a way that will ensure growth, ensure that we are competitive on world markets and improve the living standards of our people. If this can be achieved all other government responsibilities in welfare, health and education and our commitment to foreign aid can be both met and increased. As a result of the prudent management during the past six years our economic position is now one of growth and productivity-what a different position from 1975-76 when this nation was showing negative growth and had a deficit of $4,000m.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is after Labor.

—I agree with my colleague. We are indeed in a fortunate position compared with other industrialised countries that are troubled with slow or no growth, higher inflation and higher unemployment. Production, employment, investment and consumer demand are not only stronger than a year ago but also greater than thought likely at the time of the last Budget. It is important to note that business investment grew by more than 20 per cent in real terms during the year, which is the largest growth in this country for 30 years. It is essential that the Government, therefore, keep a tight reign on its own expenditure if this position is to be maintained, if inflation is to be contained and if we are to reduce the pressure on interest rates. What a contrast we have with the Opposition's policies. The outlook for next year under our policies indicates prices will rise by 10.75 per cent, employment by 2 per cent, gross domestic product by 3.5 per cent and wages by 13.5 per cent. Labor calls again for increased Government expenditure. These are the same policies followed by the last Labor Government when we saw inflation rise from 5 per cent to 17 1/2 per cent. The spending of taxpayers' money in that time was at a record rate. Personal income tax increased by 125 per cent in three years and investment in development collapsed completely.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to discussing some of the specific measures in the Budget and areas of change that must be undertaken in the year ahead if we are to continue our enviable position. It has been said that the primary welfare of the Australian people does not rely on our social welfare system but on the strength of our economy. The Government's concern for the care of the elderly and needy will be further expanded this year. Indexation of pensions based on consumer price index increases in November and May will add an additional $7.6m to the Budget. In November the single rate of social service pension will be $69.70 a week and the combined married rate will increase to $116.20 a week. The Government has decided also to increase and redirect a program of rental assistance to pensioners and long term sickness beneficiaries in order to provide more support to those paying higher rents. Other major initiatives in the social welfare area include increases in family allowances by some 50 per cent for third and subsequent children and new assistance measures for the handicapped. It should be emphasised that it was this Government that introduced the family allowance scheme and it was this Government that has increased assistance to the disabled by 140 per cent since 1975-76.

The Australian social security system is in place to protect people from economic hardship caused by loss of earnings through age, sickness, invalidity, unemployment or the loss of a supporting spouse following death or desertion. It is also intended to assist parents with the cost of raising children. When we look at the total outlays on social welfare at Commonwealth level, always remembering that State governments also supplement these outlays, we find that in 1981-82, 27.8 per cent of the Commonwealth Budget or $11,357m has been appropriated. As this is a 14.5 per cent increase over the previous year and well in excess of the inflation rate we should expect our programs to meet all those factors mentioned earlier. But do they?

We are, of course, aware of significant areas of poverty and a wide disparity of living conditions in our community. Whilst no Government programs can be expected or should be expected to assume responsibility for every individual's well-being it is becoming increasingly obvious that our social security system is far from satisfactory. I believe that two questions have to be asked. The first question is: Can our economy continue to support the massive annual increases in welfare spending? In 1968, for every 1,000 workers in our community 178 persons were being supported on welfare benefits. Today, this has increased to 287 persons being supported by every 1,000 workers. The burden of this upon each taxpayer is exces- sive and the inflexibility it imposes upon a government in establishing priorities for increased growth is immense. If such a trend is allowed to continue the social security system will collapse either through economic or political pressures.

The second question to be asked is: Are the people in real need in our community being supported adequately or is our assistance being spread too thinly across a broad spectrum of programs? We are all aware that many payments in the social security area are being paid to people who are not in need of income maintenance. It is time to bite the bullet on this issue. The two advantages to be gained are that, on the one hand, those in real need could be supported at benefit levels above the poverty line and, on the other hand, government programs for economic and employment growth could receive higher priority stabilising the ever increasing welfare budget.

The emphasis in the Budget of devoting increased resources and introducing new manpower and training programs is indicative of a positive commitment and totally against those remarks made by the honourable member for Melbourne tonight. Of course, we are all aware of the many reasons for the high levels of unemployment. We are aware of the social effects of unemployment in our community. Most of us have reasons for why this occurs. I guess that we can all cite many of them. Perhaps the economic recession that has gone through most of the industrial world in the last few years can be blamed. Perhaps the inappropriateness of our education curriculum can be blamed. Perhaps a higher junior wage and penalty rates which have been accompanied by a loss of traditional youth jobs can be blamed. Of course, we all know that the replacement of labour by technology is another one of those reasons. All these factors combine to contribute to some of the high unemployment rates that we have at the present time.

But Australia is not in the position that the honourable member for Melbourne likes to paint us. Australia is in the fortunate position in that in the last two years 300,000 new jobs have been created. We know, by Budget estimates, that we can look forward to a further 2 per cent growth in employment this year. Our positive programs are practical ways of helping young people improve their education, training and work experience opportunities. An amount of $72m will be expended on training and an increased number of 95,000 apprentices will be assisted. The Special Youth Employment Training Program will assist 90,000 young people. An assessment has shown that up to 60 per cent of young unemployed people commencing this Scheme have obtained long term employment or have obtained satisfactory work shortly after their training is complete. I was disappointed, after a considerable effort had been made by me in my electorate and, I know, by most other members of this House, that the decision was taken to terminate the Community Youth Support Scheme. The Scheme was particularly appropriate and successful in country regions. I pay tribute to the project officers and their supporting community committees for adapting the scheme to bring positive benefits to many young people with acute social and employment difficulties.

I am very pleased that the Government has been able to reassess its decision. I am pleased that it has been able to announce that, as its assessment has proceeded far enough to show that not every CYSS participant would be able to benefit from the new range of programs we have established, it has been prepared to change its mind. It has been prepared to accept that some young unemployed people would not have access to the programs we have designed and that these programs would not meet their needs. Therefore, it has been decided that in the interests of the young people concerned, current CYSS projects will receive their present level of funds until February 1982. New and improved guidelines for the operation of the scheme will be prepared. Those guidelines will have particular regard to the best means of providing assistance and support for young people who live in areas where training and educational opportunities are limited or who may not qualify for or be able to benefit from existing employment programs. As I said, CYSS is to continue, and it will continue after 28 February 1982 under new guidelines. Special attention will be needed in many rural and remote communities as many disadvantaged young people will not have access to transition programs, training positions and, in turn, apprenticeship opportunities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you have a hand in that, Peter?

—I did have a hand in it. I am very pleased to say that I did. In the context of the Budget debate, it is appropriate to pay some regard to the effect of our exchange rate and the impact of protection upon our economy. Our rate of exchange is important because it determines the international competitiveness of our exporting and importing industry. The Government has quite correctly been successful in restoring and maintaining this country's exporting advantage. While I recognise that the real effective exchange rate has no meaning unless it is taken over a period, I must express concern at the trend that is occurring. We all know that most rural industry prices are determined in the countries and currencies of major consumers. The conversion of these into revenue for primary producers depends solely on the existing exchange with the Australian dollar. The real effective exchange rate appreciation during 1980-81 was about 7 per cent. The dollar appreciated by some 18 per cent, however, for wool against the Australian Wool Corporation's wool trade weight basket. This is a major disadvantage to wool producers and is of more significance to the wool industry compared with other rural industries because of the impact of European countries on the world wool trade.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other hand, beef suffered only a 6 per cent appreciation in the dollar because of the importance of the United States trade to that industry. Adverse exchange rate movements reduced the price of wheat over the last 12 months by $13 a tonne. The combined effects of these movements have reduced rural income by $400m in 1980-81, which is approximately 10 per cent of net rural income. If we add other exporting competing industries to this, the net loss is close to $700m. As I said earlier, exchange rate movement must be looked at over a period and not just at any given point in time. But it is important to note that the farm rate of inflation over the last 12 months rose by 15 per cent, whereas the consumer price index rose by less than 10 per cent. We must expect further revaluations in 1981-82 due to the estimated capital inflow of up to $8 billion. There are several solutions to this problem, foremost being a restriction of capital inflow and an enccouragement of capital outflow. We can endeavour to restrict government borrowings further and to repay earlier borrowings. We could abolish the 2 per cent revenue duty and relax by-law entry.

The other solution to the exchange rate difficulty is, of course, to reduce tariffs. It is on this matter that I wish to conclude my remarks. There is probably no area of greater misunderstanding or misconception than in the 'free trade' versus 'protectionism' debate. Firstly, it should be pointed out that there are valid arguments for granting protection. There are the arguments that tariffs are necessary to support infant industries or that tariffs on manufactures are justified in a labour scarce economy. Levels of protection, however, cannot be justified on these arguments today. The main arguments we hear today in favour of high levels of protection have been that they are necessary to expand the size of the manufacturing sector in order to provide employment for a growing labour force, as Australian manufacturers have also argued, that industries in which there are economies of scale should be protected from import competition, so allowing the domestic producers to increase their output and to lower unit costs. Most people would not necessarily agree with this, as often such protective industries operate at less than the minimum efficient scale. Primarily this happens because firms are aware of their interdependence and avoid price cutting, which may jeopardise all their profits.

Of course, governments must also consider the levels of tariff, subsidy or other forms of protection that are necessary to preserve the viability of industries established by government decisions. An example of this is that many of our horticultural industries have been developed following closer settlement schemes. It may be necessary, therefore, to afford some protection against low cost imports if these industries have to operate in a high cost structure. The social and decentralised importance of these industries adds another dimension to the protection debate. But even this assistance must not be such that it becomes a burden on society. We have seen in the primary industry sector many examples of restructuring over the years, the dairy industry offering a most recent example. Such restructuring has resulted in more efficient and profitable industry, but not, I emphasise, without personal trauma and hardship. The difficulty with tariff protection is that society usually does not know the cost of the protection it is bearing and some industries become fat and lacking in initiative.

This leads me to the current discussion on protection for the motor vehicle industry. Any assessment of the Australian motor vehicle industry, despite the unfair and emotional outcry from the industry in recent weeks, will show that it is out of step with the Government's objectives and that it is a massive burden on the Australian community. We know that protection for the indsutry amounts to over $1,000m annually, the equivalent of $3,000 for each car produced in Australia, or a massive $15,000 for each employee in the industry. Australia also has five manufacturers making 19 basic models for an insulated domestic market. As a result, the industry is fragmented and costly in its total manufacturing process. We also know that, despite protection, employment in the industry continues to fall. Presently 65,000 workers are involved. This is a drop of over 20,000 during the past five years. Therefore, the Government has to make decisions in the overall national interest. However, its intentions in the short and long term must be clearly stated. The industry must be restructured gradually, in my view, with the intention of retaining a strong and efficient industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Listening to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) speaking in this debate before the dinner suspension, one could have been excused for thinking that he was talking about another country. But then I suppose the perspectives are somewhat different from Nareen compared with Coburg. The 1981-82 Budget presents us with a clear statement of the bankrupt economic thinking and regressive social attitudes which have characterised the Fraser Government's handling of the Australian economy and society since 1975. It provides yet another stark reminder of this Government's blinkered commitment to a misguided conservative ideology, the practical application of which has imposed immense economic and social costs on all but the most wealthy and powerful sections of the Australian community. The average wage earner, the unemployed job seeker and the young person have all been treated with contempt under the social and economic policy regime administered by the Fraser Government since 1975.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1981-82 Budget confronts us with the latest regurgitation of an economic strategy which aims at suppressing inflation, reducing real wages and pruning the size of the public sector as the necessary prerequisites for generating economic growth in the private sector. Such a strategy has been pursued consistently since 1975 and its main policy ingredients have been, and continue to be cutbacks in government spending, reductions in the Budget deficit, and tight control over the growth in the money supply-in other words, a monetarist strategy aimed at squeezing the economic life out of the economy for the sake of some vague assurance of longer term recovery. This strategy has had five years to produce the much-heralded regeneration of output and jobs. It has proved to be an abysmal and unequivocal failure.

There has been minimal gain on the inflation front. The inflation rate of 13 per cent in 1975-76 was reduced to under 9 per cent by 1978-79, but the trend has subsequently worsened and the consumer price index is anticipated by the Government to rise by almost 11 per cent during 1981-82. In other words, little headway has been made after half a decade of tight policies. Economic growth has stagnated. Average annual growth of less than 2 1/2 per cent in non-farm output since 1975-76 compares dismally with the experience of the first half of the 1970s and with the growth experience of other major Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. Growth in the first half of 1981 collapsed to the lowest level for four years. Job opportunities have increased at a snail's pace as a consequence of this poor growth performance. Employment has grown by a mere 384,000 over the 5 years to 1980-81, or at an average annual rate of little over 1 per cent. Over one-third of this increase has consisted of part time jobs. Amongst teenagers, an extra 55,000 jobs have been made available since 1975-76, and only 12,000 in that period-or less than a quarter-have been in full time employment.

The unemployment situation has deteriorated significantly and generated a social problem of massive proportions. An average of almost 390,000 people, or 5.8 per cent of the Australian labour force, were recorded by the Australian Bureau of Statistics as being out of work during 1980-81-that is, an increase of almost 90,000 over the level in 1975-76, when the unemployment rate was less than 4 1/2 per cent. Unemployment over the six years to August amongst teenagers has risen by almost 20,000 to stand now at 106,000 or 14 per cent of the teenage labour force. Unemployed people are now out of work for much longer periods-35 weeks on average compared with about 13 weeks in 1975-76, with over 80,000 unemployed people now out of work for over a year. The inadequate growth in job opportunities over the past 5 years has also contributed to the emergence of substantial 'hidden' unemployment currently totalling at least 300,000 people-that is, people who want jobs but have decided not to participate actively in the labour force because of limited job prospects or who have taken part time jobs even though preferring to work full time. The true unemployment figure is thus probably closer to three-quarters of a million Australians.

The Fraser Government must bear the prime responsibility for this economic mess. The eminent Australian economist, Professor John Nevile, in the Economic Record of December 1980, reached the unqualified conclusion that tight fiscal policy was a major reason why unemployment had risen in the last three to four years, and would rise again in the near future. Professor J. O. N. Perkins from Melbourne University, in a recent discussion paper circulated by the Parliamentary Library, has provided an even more comprehensive indictment. He says:

Policy in the recent past has held activity well below potential in the hope of thereby restraining inflation. If such a policy was intended to make possible a restoration of full employment without serious inflation, it has clearly failed.

The Fraser Government's record in the specific area of labour market policy is particularly susceptible to criticism. Total Government expenditure on manpower, training and support schemes has been reduced by almost 50 per cent in real terms between 1975-76 and 1980-81. In terms of real spending per unemployed person, the fall has been more like 80 per cent. The real value of unemployment benefits has fallen dramatically over this period, especially for unemployed young people under the age of 18 who have been required to exist on a paltry $36 a week since 1975. The Government has not developed a coherent manpower policy. Rather, it has been content to rely almost entirely on inadequate programs of subsidisation of a range of training and work experience schemes administered by employers in the private sector.

I ask honourable members to consider the major examples: Firstly subsidisation of apprenticeships under the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training scheme introduced early in 1977 has failed to generate an adequate increase in apprenticeship training. Government assistance under this scheme has more than doubled in real terms over the three years to 1980-81. Despite this, the number of new indentures only regained the 1973-74 level during 1979-80. The number of apprentices in training and the rate of apprenticship completions have hardly risen at all since 1976. Hardly what one would call an effective trade training performance!

Secondly the Special Youth Employment Training Program, aimed at temporary subsidisation of the employment and training of young unemployed people, has been dogged by a history of ineffectiveness and abuse by some employers. Many trainees have received little, if any training, and according to the Government's own evaluations in 1979, 20 per cent of SYETP positions at most were created specificaly for trainees, half the trainees not being kept on after subsidisation was terminated, with almost 30 per cent becoming unemployed again. Our unemployed youth deserve better employment schemes than this. The Government has resolutely refused to implement any programs aimed specifically at creating jobs, continually referring to the Australian Labor Party's Regional Employment Development scheme of 1974-75 as the definitive example of the inherent costliness and ineffectiveness of a public sector job creation program. The Government has apparently chosen to ignore the 1977 evaluation of the RED scheme by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations which concluded that the scheme's benefits outweighed its costs. It has also conveniently overlooked-or is probably unaware of-the 1978 report of the United States National Commission for Manpower Policy which pointed to the widespread use of job creation schemes by most European countries as a major means of reducing unemployment, and concluded that, if well designed, such programs were worth their cost.

All in all, what a dismal record after 5 years of supposed economic responsibility! It is a catalogue of unmitigated failure in the area of economic and labour market strategy. What a price the Australian community has had to pay for the implementation of such a bankrupt strategy: The costs inherent in the potential goods and services which have been foregone as a result of production levels being consistently depressed below capacity; the economic, social and psychological costs of persistent and massive unemployment; the emergence of shortages of skilled labour and the need to rely increasingly on immigrant skills; and the erosion of the living standards of the average wage earner. In relation to this last point, it is worth highlighting the fact that, as a result of an increased tax burden, higher health costs, rising interest rates, and continued high inflation, the typical family on average earnings is at present $8 a week worse off in terms of spending power compared with the situation in 1975-76. It is only the top 30 per cent of wage earners who have experienced gains in real incomes over the past 5 years.

Perhaps the clearest practical indictment of this Government's economic strategy is the fact that the only experience of accelerated economic growth in recent years occurred as a direct result of the Government's failure to implement its repressive policy regime of fiscal and monetary restraint. This brief revival took place during 1980, which, predictably enough, was an election year. During the latter half of 1980, output increased at an extraordinary annual rate of 6.1 per cent, and annual employment growth was close to 3.5 per cent. What were the underlying causes of this burst of growth? First, accelerated growth in Government expenditure during 1980 which created expansion in the public sector; secondly, growth in the money supply at rates well above the 11 per cent policy ceiling, and accelerated growth in real wages and disposable incomes, both of which underpinned an upsurge in business investment and consumer spending-in other words, the very economic magnitudes which the Fraser Government has sought to repress as part of its basic long-term strategy!

What does the 1981-82 Budget offer us specifically on the economic front? After six years of waiting for less inflation and sustained recovery, the Government now presents us with a set of policies which deliberately add to inflation, diminish economic growth, increase unemployment, and worsen the economic situation of the average working family. An overriding obsession with reducing the size of the Budget deficit is to be the basis for policies which will intensify the economic and social problems of this country.

Increased sales taxes, together with increases in health costs arising out of recent Government decisions, will add at least 1 1/2 percentage points to the rate of inflation during 1981-82. Reductions in the real level of funding to the State governments will force State charges to rise and put further upward pressure on the cost of living. What an incredible scenario from a Government committed to fighting inflation! Of course, it is the average wage earner who will continue to bear the brunt of such regressive fiscal measures. On top of recent interest rate increases, the typical family unit receiving average weekly earnings which I referred to earlier will find itself a further $4 out of pocket each week during 1981-82 as a result of the Government's fiscal decisions.

In addition, the economy is to be subject to the deflationary impacts of further cutbacks in overall government expenditure and a continued commitment to curbing growth in the money supply. Growth in government outlays is to be reduced to 12.6 per cent, compared with a 14.6 per cent increase in 1981-82. Direct government expenditure on goods and services is expected to rise in real terms by less than 1 per cent, considerably less than the 2.6 per cent growth recorded in 1980-81. The domestic surplus is budgeted to rise by $1.1 billion, which will constitute a 12 per cent increase in the rate of withdrawal of spending power from the domestic economy over what was achieved by the previous Budget. The 1981-82 Budget will thus have a strong contractionary effect on the economy. Indeed, the Budget documents contain the Government's own prediction that output will increase at a slower rate-3 to 3 1/2 per cent compared with 4 per cent in 1980-that employment growth will fall from 2.6 per cent to 2 per cent and that the level of unemployment will rise during 1981-82.

The reality is that the economic outcome for 1981-82 is likely to be far more draconian than even the Government's own miserable predictions would have us believe, for what we have is a set of contractionary policies being imposed on a private sector economy which is already on the downturn. Consider the recent behaviour of some key economic indicators:
Growth in non-farm gross domestic product fell dramatically from 6.1 per cent in the first half of 1980-81 to a mere 1 1/2 per cent in the latter half of the year.
Annual employment growth has plummeted from a high point of 212,000 in July 1980 to a rate of 109,000 by July 1981.
The level of unemployment has deteriorated noticeably over the past two months, after some improvement earlier in the year.
Consumer confidence, as measured by ABS surveys, has been declining continuously during 1981 and growth in consumption expenditure during the latter half of 1980-81 fell noticeably.
The number of building and construction commencements slumped sharply during the recent June quarter.

An unexpected slowdown in manufacturing growth in recent months has been associated with a decline in business confidence in this area, according to the latest joint survey by the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Bank of New South Wales.

The effect of the Budget strategy will be to intensify this economic downswing. In particular, a severe reduction in the growth of consumer purchasing power will be the inevitable outcome of the slower growth in real wages and the increased burden of pay-as-you-earn taxation associated with the 1981-82 Budget. This in turn will ensure that a further brake is applied to consumer spending during 1981-82, and there can be little basis for the Budget assumption that consumers will maintain the rate of expansion in their spending levels during the coming year. Moreover, further increases in interest rates are inevitable if the Government is successful in reining in the growth of the money supply from around 13 per cent to the targeted range of 10 to 11 per cent for 1981-82 or if the anticipated boom in capital inflow is not forthcoming. As a result, additional adverse effects on business investment decisions and consumer spending can be expected during 1981-82.

What we are facing, then, is the prospect, if not the certainty, of a substantial deterioration in the growth of job opportunities, the level of unemployment and the standard of living of most Australians during 1981-82. As has been the case over the past 5 years, it is the application of a misguided and inappropriate budgetary strategy which will be largely to blame. The increase of 10 1/2 per cent in the rural level of funding for manpower, training and support programs appears to be a notable departure from the general restraint in government spending. It is, on the contrary, a grossly inadequate gesture when viewed in the context of labour market realities.

Firstly, this increased funding will only provide support for an additional 23,000 people in training and work experience positions over the number subsidised during 1980-81. Unemployment is likely to rise by at least this much during 1981-82. Secondly, these positions are essentially subsidised on a temporary basis, with permanent employment still depending on an expansion of job oppportunities in the private sector, which, as we have seen, will be decidedly sluggish during 1981-82.

It is quite clear that the Fraser Government has discarded the policy goal of full employment and is content to pursue instead the goals of smaller government and reduced inflation, no matter what the impact on wage earners and the unemployed and no matter what the damage to the social fabric of this nation. The Australian Labor Party, on the other hand, believes that the achievement of full employment is still of paramount importance. Availability of satisfactory jobs for all those who want to work and sustained and equitable improvements in general living standards must be rekindled and restored as the dominant guiding philosophies for economic and social policy.

Fiscal strategy, for a start, must be more expansionary, involving a more direct role for the public sector in job creation and more appropriate mix of taxation and expenditure policies which will tackle the problems of inflation and unemployment simultaneously. But traditional fiscal and monetary policies are, by themselves, insufficient to cope with our contemporary economic problems. An incomes policy which seeks to achieve consensus between government, labour and employers concerning maintenance of the real incomes of all sections of the community is an essential ingredient of a policy strategy aimed at fighting stagflation and protecting living standards.

Elimination of large scale unemployment and the achievement of sustained improvements in living standards require progressive and imaginative policies and, most importantly, a government with the humanity, vision and strength to devise and implement such policies. The Fraser Government has shown itself singularly incapable of meeting such a challenge.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I start my speech by apologising for not having made this statement in the House before it was released to the news media. The reason for that-I hope it will be accepted in the spirit in which it is given-is that the Government and the Opposition, I freely concede, have been concerned about the problems of youth unemployment. The Government has also been concerned with many young people and adults in the community who have, themselves, been concerned about the Community Youth Support Scheme and its future. Accordingly, when a decision was made by the Government about this matter it was decided that it was appropriate to make the statement publicly and as quickly and as widely as possible. I emphasise that there was certainly no intention to cast any aspersions on the standing, significance and importance of this House or of the importance of making significant statements in this House. If any such disrespect to the House was interpreted by my actions, I certainly apologise.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the Community Youth Support Scheme. Since the Budget decision to terminate CYSS on 31 October, the Government has been looking closely at its skills, training, work experience and education programs for young people. It has also been looking closely at the availability of those programs for young unemployed people under the Community Youth Support Scheme. The Budget provided a total of $197m for manpower and training programs, an increase of almost $50m on the previous financial year. Within that expenditure there is greatly increased provision for practical and positive assistance to young unemployed people through work experience and educational opportunities. Indeed, expenditure on youth training programs in 1981-82 is to be increased from $47.5m to $79.4m, a 67 per cent increase over the last financial year. Opportunities through the School to Work Transition Program have also been substantially increased. The Government has consistently stated that skills, training, work experience and education opportunities are the best means of helping young people to find a job and keep it. The School to Work Transition Program and a greater range of training programs are designed to achieve that objective. The reduction in the number of young Australians who are unemployed indicates that those policies are working.

As announced, the Government has taken special steps to ensure that as many CYSS participants as possible are helped into our programs with the enhanced employment, training and education opportunities that are needed so much by the young unemployed. That assessment has not been completed, but it has proceeded far enough to show that not all CYSS participants will be able to benefit from other programs. The Government is not prepared to have a situation where some young unemployed people do not have access to a program suited to their needs. The Government has considered the alternatives of maintaining CYSS or establishing another scheme.

It has decided, in the interests of the young people concerned, that: Firstly, the current CYSS projects will receive their current level of funds until 28 February 1982; secondly, new and improved guidelines for the operation of the scheme will be prepared; and, thirdly, those guidelines will have particular regard to the best means of providing assistance and support for young people who live in areas where training and education opportunities are limited or who may not be qualified or able to benefit from existing programs. It has also been decided that CYSS will continue after 28 February 1982 under the new guidelines.

The Government will continue to encourage young unemployed people to take full advantage of skills, training, work experience and education programs. The Government firmly believes that it is in the best interests of the young unemployed to take part in those programs. They have been carefully designed to help young people prepare themselves in every way for employment. For those young unemployed who may not be able to take part in these programs, the new and, we believe, better Community Youth Support Scheme will provide a practical way of improving their position to a level where they can take advantage of existing employment, education and training opportunities. In drawing the new guidelines, my Department will consult with community interests, including the National Youth Advisory Group, the Youth Affairs Council of Australia, church bodies, State governments, local government associations, State CYSS committees, and associations of CYSS committees and project officers.

The Government has always said that youth unemployment is a major concern. It is not only an economic problem but also a matter of great personal and social concern. It believes that by the procedure now announced it can draw on wide community resources to help solve a difficult human problem. The funds to enable the Scheme to function until 28 February 1982 will come from resources within the present Budget of the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the new program be introduced after that?

—Yes. I will repeat one part of the statement. The final point I made with respect to the specific decisions of the Government is that the Community Youth Support Scheme will continue after 28 February 1982 under the new guidelines. We are confident that the new guidelines will produce a new and better scheme. It remains only for me to thank those people both outside this House and within the House who have made constructive suggestions to the Government. I would like to place on record that the Government has considered very carefully all of those suggestions from honourable members and senators and community representatives and organisations outside the House. Those representations, particularly from houourable members, have been of considerable assistance to the Government in reaching these decisions. I present the following paper:

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-What the Opposition has to say on this matter falls into two parts. I will briefly dispose of the first part. We believe that the Government has laid itself open to criticism in respect of the timing and making of the announcement. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) was speaking to the House in the Budget debate in the half hour leading up to 6 p.m. this evening. Clearly, the decision had been made by that time. We believe it obviously appropriate that, the decision having been made by then, the Prime Minister should not have treated this House with contempt by not making the statement to the House. Clearly, if he wanted some extension of time to his prepared speech to make such an announcement that extension of time would readily have been granted.
—He stopped five minutes early.

—I am reminded that he stopped five minutes early. I make the point that, at a time when this Parliament is saying that it is taking the question of the standard of the Parliament seriously and that someone is being dealt with in respect of prima facie contempt, it would have been much better if the Prime Minister had done the House the courtesy of making the announcement to the House. I could understand the desire of the Government then to make the broader announcement as the Minister did on PM. I think the House would have been better served if it had been done in the other way. In that respect the Acting Leader of the Opposition, Mr Lionel Bowen, has made a statement which has the support of the Opposition in that regard.

SPEECH.PARA: Having made that statement in a responsibile manner, I come with much more happiness to the second part of what I wish to say. I have said publicly and, as the Minister knows, I have said privately, that in regard to this matter we do not seek to make political capital. It is quite clear that if the decision had stood we would probably have been able to do better out of it in political terms. But we do not approach the matter in that way. On behalf of the opposition and with its full support I congratulate the Government on having changed this decision. As one who this week has been very much concerned in attacking the Government, it gives me very much pleasure on behalf of the Opposition to say to the Government that we congratulate it on its change of heart and decision. It is a change of heart and decision which will be applauded by every member of this House and, I believe, the other place as well.

I have not completed all that I have to say at this stage by extending congratulations to the Government for this change of decision. We should extend congratulations to members on both sides of the House, the young people themselves who have been involved in CYSS projects, the CYSS officers, the churches and the other community organisations in this country who have properly used the processes of democracy in this matter. They have been faced with a political decision of which they did not approve and they have used the processes of democracy peaceably to make their opposition known. To the Government's credit it has responded to the use of the democratic processes and it is to be congratulated.

The final thing that has to be said-I appreciate the sense in which the Minister to some extent picked up this point-is that we should all conclude on the note of acknowledging that we are talking about a problem which transcends partisan considerations. It is not just an economic problem we are dealing with. It has tragic dimensions for this community. The Government has recognised that and it will keep the CYSS projects going. I congratulate it. I hope that the organisations to which the Minister has referred will be able to take part in the review and will throw their full resources positively and constructively into assisting the Government so that at the end of that process a better Community Youth Support Scheme will emerge. It will provide to young people some hope and feeling that the community has not abandoned them and the great resource involved in those young people will, at the earliest possible time, be made available to play a constructive part in the community. I conclude by unequivocally congratulating the Government, in the terms I have mentioned, for the decision it has made.
