TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker. I take a point of order. I understood the Leader of the House to have informed us that there would be only one speaker from each side of the House. If the Government is to open up a wider debate, other speakers on this side of the House will have to be found to match those from the Government side.
—The honourable member's remarks would be more appropriately directed to the Leader of the House. The matter is not within the province of the Chair. I call the honourable member for Cook.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the spirit of the night, I will be brief. I merely say that as chairman of the Community Youth Support Scheme committee in my electorate since the Scheme was started, the decision taken tonight by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) is very much appreciated, not on policital grounds, not for reasons of recrimination or who was responsible for what. The unemployed youth in my area will be greatly benefited by the decision taken tonight. Honourable members might recall that I commented yesterday in another area that I admired the Government's decision to switch its emphasis towards the training aspect for unemployed youth. I commend the Government for its decision tonight. Its decision with respect to unemployed youth is still to move to training but to keep a community, non-governmental department involvement in the problem of those people who, in most cases, are incapable of finding work for themselves. Under the same circumstances, those people will be incapable of finding training programs.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the decision taken tonight is a very good one. In February 1982 the new guidelines are created. In my area we have called the Scheme SPEC-the special pre-employment centres scheme. We have never called it the CYSS. Perhaps the name of the Scheme could be changed to something like that. But the title is irrelevant. The functions are the most important thing.

I congratulate the Minister for his decision. I am sorry to hear groans from honourable members opposite in this regard. I congratulate the Minister for the sensitivity he has shown towards the problems affecting unemployed people. One of the great things that have been achieved through CYSS--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the greatest conversion since the Damascus Road.

—I was never on that road. Perhaps the honourable member for Lalor could tell me something of it. He has an historic approach. As far as I and the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) are concerned, this matter is beyond politics and it is beyond our scene. The decision is to be welcomed and the Minister is to be congratulated for his sensitivity. I hope that after February 1982 we will see a revamped progressive scheme that combines both the work search aspect of CYSS and the training program that was brought in by the Budget. I am confident that with the Minister's administration of his portfolio we will see a happy marriage of both those things and community backed committees which will help the officials around the country. I am sure that this will have the total support not only of the churches, the volunatry organisations or the people who have worked on these schemes so far but also of organisations such as employers and the trade union movement which has been most forthcoming where CYSS has been successful. I am sure that will continue. I congratulate the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with my colleagues on this side of the House in saying that we are pleased that the Government has reversed its decision. Frankly, we are grateful for any crumbs that fall from the table of this Government. The young unemployed of this country have been served a very harsh blow by this Government. The ruthlessness of the Budget in cutting back in this area was inhuman in the first place, so much so that there was a great deal of protest across the nation. The young people joined together and created public demonstrations to make sure that the Community Youth Support Scheme was not done away with. In a sense, it really brought something to those young people. Even though we in the Opposition were critical of the Scheme in the first place, it is remarkable how it brought some compassion and unity to people. It was a kind of a bringing together of many unemployed people who needed some compassion.

SPEECH.PARA: The sad thing about young unemployed people is the hopelessness of their positions. CYSS was successful in its own way in bringing those young people together. Many honourable members on this side of the House have said: 'That Scheme is good in itself, but what we really need to do is to build on to it'. All honourable members in this Parliament need to search for broad programs to do away with unemployment in this country. That is the major problem which we have to solve in the long term. At present young people under the age of 18 years are getting $36 a week. That figure has not changed since 1975. They are now $37 a week under the poverty line. As a result of pegging the unemployment benefit at $36 a week for people under the age of 18 years the cumulative savings of this Fraser Government in all of its Budgets since November 1975 have amounted to $53m. This Government has stolen $53m out of the pockets of the young unemployed of this country.

We are pleased that this Government has given a few crumbs to those people. But it is about time. The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) and back bench members started to put pressure on the Government to raise living standards. What is the equivalent value now of that 1975 $36 payment? That amount would have more than doubled and would be in the vicinity of $72 to $73 a week if allowances were made for the normal cost of living increases in this country.

What I was most pleased about was the self-help and, as the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) said, the agitation. The young people organised themselves throughout this country and held protest meetings. I actually spoke to a meeting of between 500 and 1,000 people in the Town Hall Square in Sydney recently. It was a public rally held according to democratic principles to express concern at the Government's drastic action in abolishing the CYSS scheme. Also I must commend the role of the churches of all denominations across this country. Their representatives conferred and spoke out against the actions of the Government. Delegations came here and expressed their criticism and their protest to the Government and to Government Ministers. For instance, tonight I actually spoke with young people who really were pleased with the success of their campaign to save this scheme.

I think that what we have to do if democracy is to function in this country, if we cannot convince the Government by debate in the Parliament, is to see that action is taken in a democratic and peaceful way throughout our society. This is one example of how the people have said that the Government decision was wrong and inhumane and that they wanted that decision reversed. If we are to congratulate anybody for changing that decision we should congratulate the people because this is a victory for the people over the Government. The Government has said that it was wrong, that this was an inhumane decision, that public opinion was against it, and it submitted to that view. The Government certainly has been under pressure, particularly the Cabinet, in this last week. It has been under the pressure of criticism from the Government side. We have seen Ministers misleading the House. We have seen charges of collusion on the part of Ministers and the Prime Minister. We on this side of the House have seen charges of collusion on the part of senior Cabinet Ministers.

We are pleased that the Government has seen the light. It has seen the light because it knows that public criticism is running against it. If it cannot lift its sights, if it cannot show a bit more compassion for those people affected, if it cannot build economic policies that will overcome the unemployment problem in this country, it at least can raise the level of the unemployment benefit paid to people under the age of 18 years. Honourable members know that $36 a week is now $37 a week under the poverty line. So far as I am concerned, it is about time some of those smug complacent people on the Government back benches started to criticise and put pressure on the Government to give a more compassionate living to those people whom it has forced into unemployment.

I hope the CYSS scheme will develop into a scheme which will give greater confidence and greater comradeship to young unemployed people. That is an important aspect because these young unemployed people are lonely; they need compassion, comradeship and support. At least the Minister is starting to recognise that this Scheme in fact gives them that. The Scheme will exist until February, and I hope the scheme that comes forward after February will be even much more progressive. I hope it will be a much more generous scheme. I hope in the long term, and in the not too far distant future, that the Minister will advocate and, ultimately, will get from Cabinet an increased payment for the unemployed until such time as he can convince the Government to reverse its policies and start to bring in more compassionate policies so that more young people can be fully employed in this society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Mr R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this decision by the Government. Although I wish to speak in support of it, I have been told that the debate is to be adjourned. So, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the debate be now adjourned.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (Budget Debate)
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak to the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1981-82 as a Government supporter. I congratulate the Government on re-implementing the Community Youth Support Scheme, although I must say that indecision in regard to change is probably better than a change of the type under consideration. All the training in the world is no good to anybody unless jobs are available. That is what our Government is about. I rebuff the comments made by the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke). He said that the Government is not progressive and imaginative. I believe that it is. He said that we were not seeking to create job opportunities. But I point out that business confidence has actually increased to a greater extent in the last 12 months than it has at any time in the previous 20 years. I also remind the honourable member that the inflation rate, although it is still too high, has been kept at a reasonable level and is nothing like the 17 per cent that we experienced under the Whitlam Government.
—For one quarter.

—That was enough; I can assure the honourable member. One quarter was one quarter too much. I assure the honourable member for Wills that, if he had been in government under Whitlam, he probably would not be here today. I guess we are all treasurers at heart, as most honourable members on this side of the House own and run businesses of some kind or another. It is a basic fact that we handle the Australian financial system better than the Opposition. I would like to do better than John Howard, and that is good for the challenge keeps him and his department working at their task. No one can deny that the honourable member for Bennelong is a hard working Treasurer and manages the economy well with what he has to work with. Total receipts are up to $40 billion, which is an increase of $5.5 billion or a rise of 15.8 per cent. Total tax revenue is up $5.3 billion to $37.7 billion, an increase of 16.3 per cent. Expenditure is $40.8 billion. In real terms, with an adjustment for the extra pay day, there is a real increase in expenditure of one per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: It disappoints me that government spending continues to grow, even marginally. Although a cut of $500m was made by the revenue review committee and a staff ceiling reduction of 9,000 was imposed on the Public Service, we still see that overall tax collection and expenditure are growing. Somehow or other we have to find the means to stop that because we cannot continue to pay higher and higher taxes forever. I believe more emphasis should be placed on the processing of our resources. I applaud the Government for encouraging the iron and steel industry by allowing it a greater write-off in depreciation. I believe this should be extended to other resource industries in order to help ease unemployment. I think we have reached the stage in our development at which we should be looking at processing much more of our raw resources here in Australia. Surely there is no better way to increase employment than to do that.

I oppose the shifting of the tax base to indirect taxation. I have expressed my opinion on this matter before. I believe that it militates against employment in that it does not encourage small businesses to employ people because they are paying tax before they show a profit. I do not believe that that is good for employment. No one can employ unless he has a profit and the balance that is over enables him to employ more people. The Government is using the Asprey Taxation Review Committee to project this theory. I put it to the Government that it was set up under the Whitlam Government. Surely it must have been in the interests--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not still blaming Gough, are you?

—Yes, I am, because the Asprey Committee was set up under the Whitlam Government and we are still using it as a reason for shifting the base of taxation. If we are to argue that, we should have an inquiry of our own. We should not be obliged to have anything whatever to do with the Whitlam Government. It really depends on the line we push as to how we encourage people to think about what sort of taxation they should be paying.

SPEECH.PARA: I only hope that Cabinet is as generous in looking at the anomalies in sales tax as it has been with the Community Youth Support Scheme. I believe it has been generous in continuing the scheme. Let us hope that Cabinet will give them due consideration when the sales tax Bills came back to this House. Surely some of the anomalies must be looked at, particularly the severe rate of 17 1/2 per cent that has been applied to some goods. In some cases, it has gone from nothing to 17 1/2 per cent-an enormous increase in tax. This is particularly so in the case of people in my electorate purchasing grain trucks. The tourist industry is another industry which has been very hard hit. I believe we have to look again at this tax. I think that there should be only a 2 1/2 per cent increase for these anomalies and it should apply as from 1 January when the other 2 1/2 per cent sales tax increases come into operation. I believe that is the only fair and just way to apply the new increase. Those people who are being asked to pay the 2 1/2 per cent increase from 1 January are being given a breathing space to adjust their businesses to the new tax. I believe that should also apply to those expected to pay the enormous increase of 17 1/2 per cent.

Air navigation charges have been increased to 20 per cent. This is slightly higher than we expected. We were hoping that it would only be in line with the consumer price index increase. The Government and the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) need to be congratulated for rejecting the general aviation report whereby we were going to see enormous increases in charges. Trans Australia Airlines has announced that it intends to withdraw from the F27 routes in Queensland. These basically are the routes up the coast and inland. We will have to look at maintaining those essential services and at seeking a subsidy from the Government to do so. I think that is fair and equitable. The report of the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares recommended that this happen. Tasmania has received $5m to do exactly that. I do not particularly like playing one State off against another but perhaps Tasmania is a good example to use. I hope that Cabinet will be feeling generous when we put the proposition to it that an extra $3m will be needed to continue operations in that part of the world. That money will have to go either to Bush Pilots Airways Ltd or to TAA.

Interest rates are far too high, and this is an enormous burden on rural Australia. Those of us who have businesses or farms have to borrow large sums of money to continue operating throughout the year. Usually all our income comes in at once, whether one is shearing sheep, selling cattle or growing wheat. Normally, after a period, one has to borrow large amounts of money to carry on until one's next income arrives. I believe this has a disproportionate effect on people in rural Australia as against people in business who have a continuing income. Let us hope that interest rates will come down. The fact that we have budgeted for a surplus suggests that we are pointing in the right direction. In the past few weeks we have seen a decrease of about one per cent in the United States interest rate. I am hopeful that overall we will see a steady decline in interest rates. The overall tax collection is now 28.8 per cent of the gross domestic product. This is a rise of 2.8 per cent on that of last year. Unfortunately, it is continuing to go up.

I believe it is not good economics to rely on capital inflow to balance our Budget. I believe we should be encouraging business to produce and to export more and to look for more overseas markets as this is the only safe and sound way to run our business. We cannot rely on the income of overseas speculators and on other income coming into the country. It is projected that in the next 12 months we will have an increase in the capital inflow of $2 billion-roughly from 6.8 per cent to 8.8 per cent. I thing we would have to have pure luck on our side to maintain that sort of inflow. I do not think it is a good idea to put ourselves in the position of having to rely on so much money to balance the trade portion of our Budget.

The Government must be congratulated for reviewing zone allowances. These allowances affect a great area of my electorate. I only hope that when the final decision is made-as yet, it has not been made-we will see substantial increases in those allowances. Surely anybody living and working in that part of the world deserves some consideration for putting up with the environment. Today, we see unionists getting site allowances and things such as that when they live within a stone's throw of Brisbane, for instance. If it is good enough for them to get something, those people who live permanently in the western part of Queensland and other parts of rural Australia ought to be compensated to some extent. The Industries Assistance Commission has been asked to look at protection to all of industry. Let us hope that its report is taken up by Cabinet and that we will see a gradual reduction in tariffs because surely that is long overdue. We can no longer afford the luxury of heavily protecting inefficient industries to the detriment of efficient industries. Most of the industries in rural Australia are highly efficient because they are operating on a world market without any protection whatsoever. Defence spending is up by 16.3 per cent or 5.3 per cent in real terms. I think that is important.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about pork?

—We have been fortunate in being able to get a voluntary quota on imports of pork. That is to the betterment of the pork industry because pork has never been selling at a higher price than it is today. We can thank the National Country Party for that piece of pork-barrelling, if you like. As I said, defence spending is up by 16.3 per cent or 5.3 per cent in real terms. That is one of the main reasons why the Budget income has had to be increased. Surely defence spending is worthwhile because we must have good defence in Australia if we are to survive in the long term. Education expenditure is up by 11.1 per cent to $3.255 billion. The freight equalisation subsidy on petroleum products is now worth $129m.

SPEECH.PARA: The levy on raw oil is worth $3.44 billion or an increase of 10.7 per cent. I have always opposed the crude oil pricing policy and I will continue to do so because I believe it militates against those who have to live away from the points of refining. The further away one gets the more of the product one uses and the greater the tax one pays. I believe that is unjust. At present, over 50 per cent of all we spend on petroleum products goes to the Government by way of indirect taxation. So when someone accuses me of not paying enough tax I politely tell that person that when I start up my tractor I use an awful lot of fuel and half of it goes up the chimney stack as taxation to the Government. I believe it is important that in the long term we look at alleviating this problem. We have to find some way in which to subsidise the people who live further out, in inland Australia. At present the equalisation scheme applies to the wholesale price only. We find with price cutting obviously that the more people in capital cities there are, the more price cutting goes on and the cheaper the fuel becomes. The further out one moves the dearer the retail price becomes. In actual fact, the whole system is militating against those people who live inland from the coast.

TALK.START.PARA: —Private enterprise does that.

—Yes. Allowances to primary producers will continue. Depreciation on plant is worth $24m. A soil conservation measure which was a once only measure and which has been done away with by the razor gang was worth $2m. The mains electricity connection proposal is worth $6m. The fuel storage facilities proposal is worth $4m.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Koongamia Post Office-Community Youth Support Scheme-Aids for Disabled People-Tasmania-Aircraft Accident at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport-Water Resources-Sydney Rugby League Grand Final

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bring to the attention of the Parliament and the Government the poor logic involved in plans by Australia Post to close the Koongamia post office in my electorate. I am aware that Australia Post must operate as efficiently as possible and that at times this will mean that some post offices will have to be discontinued because the expense of providing them cannot be justified by the marginally greater convenience they offer when compared with other offices. However, it appears to me that this argument is currently being applied in a very simplistic manner. Australia Post is closing the Koongamia post office on the grounds that usage, measured in the numbers of telegrams, articles posted, money orders and so on, has dropped to a level where the cost can no longer be justified. It also claims that other services, in this case at the post office in Midland, are quite accessible. If this arguement were used in relation to a post office of the usual type in its own building, occupying land, having a permanent staff, this might make sense, though the access to alternatives would be debatable. I will return to that question presently.

SPEECH.PARA: The main point, however, is that the Koongamia post office is an agency. It is located in a general store occupying about one square metre of floor space behind a wooden frame built by the shop owner. There is no permanent staff. The shop owner gets paid according to the numbers of each type of post office transaction he conducts. In this situation it is hard to see how Australia Post could save money by closing it down. Australia Post has no capital invested there and it pays no rent. No matter how low the volume of business gets it is still paying the same proportion of income for labour. An Australia Post van will still have to visit the location because the post box outside the shop is to be retained. On the other hand, Midland is already a busy post office. Constituents have complained of waiting lengthy periods in queues, particularly at peak times such as lunch hours. If Koongamia and two similar post offices outside my electorate, but in the same general area, close down then Australia Post will need to put on more full time staff in Midland to handle the extra work. The cost benefit of closing the small agency type offices becomes even harder to understand.

I return to the question of convenience of access to the alternative Midland post office. The buses run approximately at the rate of one an hour during the week between Midland and Koongamia. It has been argued by Australia Post that most people in the area go to Midland to shop and can use the post office at the same time. Apart from the fact that this limits access to once a week it should be pointed out that this is a solid, working class suburb and many of the people would shop on Saturday morning or on Thursday late night shopping when the post office is not open. I hope the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) will review the process by which decisions to close post offices are made. I would particularly like to know how the agency type of post office would be losing money. The Koongamia post office should not be closed and a full review of this sitaution should be made.

I go on tonight to congratulate the project officers of the Swan, Belmont and Victoria Park Community Youth Support Scheme projects for the very successful campaign that they and their committees under the chairmenship of Lyla Elliot, Fred McKenzie and John Hudson waged to retain the very vital service that they perform for many young people in the Swan area. That service is irreplaceable. I am pleased to say that that service will now not have to be replaced because of the reversal of the Government decision that the pressure of these individual committees has successfully brought about. I want to thank, too, the many service organisations which have supported them over the years and which will now have an opportunity to go on supporting them. I am glad that they will now see that their money has not been wasted, that the projects that they have pursued over some years now will be properly accorded the financial assistance that their success deserves.

I am pleased too, particularly in the Midland area because there we have had, at least until the Swan CYSS project opened, a very considerable problem with the activity of youth gangs. These substantially diminished during the time of the operation of the CYSS project and many people in Midland feared that there would be a resurrection of that type of antisocial behavior. There will not be. Many young people will continue to be given hope by the operations of these projects. I hope that none of the reviews of the guidelines close down any of the very important activities that those organisations have undertaken. We will, along with those committees, be watching that very closely. I assure those committees that I shall be watching the changes to guidelines very closely in this House to make absolutely certain that for some very considerable time into the future, until the problem of youth unemployment is solved, their very real contribution to the solution of that problem will be maintained.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Mr R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I congratulate the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) and the Government for their decision to continue the funding of the Community Youth Support Scheme. I will not speak tonight on the decision as announced by the Minister. Since the Budget decision was made to terminate the scheme on 31 October this year I had constantly expressed my concern to the Minister that a number of CYSS participants would not be adequately catered for in the newly expanded and funded job training, work experience and education programs which the Government announced in the Budget. I expressed this concern to the Minister personally. I spoke in this Parliament on the same subject on 27 August. I spoke within my Party on this subject and in the Estimates Committee which dealt with the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs on 15 September. The point was made that because of the particular problems of CYSS participants-many of them have been unemployed for a long while-they lacked confidence. They do not necessarily fit into institutionally based and broadly based bureaucratically administered programs. Because of these characteristics pertaining to CYSS participants I was most concerned that they might not be taken up in the new programs of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: During the Estimates Committee debate I think the most interesting thing to come out was that, in answer to one of my questons, it was stated by one of the officers of the Department:
No statistics are kept on the characteristics of the participants in CYSS . . .

To me this obviously indicated that there was no guarantee that the CYSS participants with their particular problems would be embraced by the new schemes announced by the Government in the Budget. So, for that reason I am very pleased that the Government has decided to continue funding the CYSS program. I think that there has to be a reassessment of the guidelines under which CYSS programs operate. I believe that the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs needs to monitor the CYSS projects more closely than it has done in the past because if it does not there is a real danger that the particular projects which do not work will, in fact, prejudice the good schemes which exist throughout Australia.

I think CYSS needs more secure funding arrangements than it has had in the past where it really lived on a six-monthly basis not knowing what its future was. I believe also that there needs to be less of an administrative burden placed on the project officers of these schemes who, instead of being able to get on with their job of looking after unemployed youths, have to spend so much time carrying out a very heavy administrative load. I do not think that is satisfactory. I believe also that the CYSS projects have to be given official sanction to carry out a greater orientation towards job placements. In the past and certainly initially job placement was not considered to be a role of the CYSS program. I think this was utterly ridiculous. Certainly, in my electorate I know of projects which had a great deal more success than, say, the Commonwealth Employment Service in putting young unemployed youths into appropriate jobs in a very short time. I believe that is something which the Government must consider when these guidelines are being reviewed.

Finally, I just make the point that I think that the democratic process has been well served by the decision of the Government. There was a great deal of agitation for the retention of CYSS. I believe that the Government was quite right in its decision. I support that decision and wish again to congratulate the Minister and the Government for deciding to continue the funding of the CYSS program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw attention tonight to the appalling inadequacies in the Government's highly publicised program of aids for disabled people. This program has finally been implemented, after a 10 month delay. The State of Victoria is to receive the sum of $600,000 this financial year, to be divided between 28 hospitals in the State. The program has been advertised as assistance for disabled people to receive aids such as wheelchairs, walking aids and home modifications, and has been given considerable publicity by the Government Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar), in this International Year of Disabled Persons. However, I suggest that the experience of several of my constituents with this scheme has shown that it is little more than a publicity stunt at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to describe the case of a young disabled girl in my electorate. This girl was born on 26 January 1963. It was discovered that she had a partial cleft palate and a defect in her nasal passage. She subsequently had three operations on her mouth and throat before she was three years old at a cost ot approximately $3,000. Her health gradually deteriorated and at the age of 6 1/2 she contracted rheumatoid arthritis. Her parents spent the next four years taking her to one of Melbourne's best arthritic specialists. By the time she was 11 she was confined to a wheelchair and had reacted adversely to the drugs prescribed for her condition. She was unable to attend a normal school, so her parent moved to a suburb close to Balwyn so that they could have their daughter attended Yooralla special school.

In 1980 this girl spent nine months in the Austin Hospital and underwent five operations. In the last operation, her hip joints were removed as the surgeons were hoping to replace these joints with plastic hips. However, due to the severe deterioration of her bones they were unable to replace these joints. She is now without hips and her legs project at right angles from her body. Her knee joints calcified while in plaster and they cannot be bent. Before he hips were removed, she was able to roll onto her side when lying down, but this is now impossible for her. She is in constant pain from her physical condition, which make transportation by car a nightmare, as well as an extremely awkward operation due to the angle of her legs. This is only a brief outline of this young girl's condition. She is bright and intelligent, interested in art and craft activities and particularly interest in the possibility of showing Chinchilla cats at cat shows, if she could be suitably transported to venues.

Unfortunately such transportation at present is impossible. Even attendance at day centre is impossible as the staff are unable to cope with her physical condition. She is virtually stranded in her home, an has in fact only left this home twice this year, to attend the Austin Hospital. I point out that the parents of this girl have, over the past 18 years, been involved in considerable personal expense in order to alleviate the severe physical disabilities and pain which their daughter has suffered. They have built a new home with suitable modifications to allow her some mobility within this environment. This cost them $50,000. Other expenses incurred have included two wheelchairs for $800, a bath chair for $450, a lifting machine for $1,200, a special heating light for $130, a special bed for $900, and a slide table for $20, as well as the continual expenses of sheepskins, medication and other on-going requirements.

The girl's father brings home $214.05 per week. Her mother works at night and on Saturday afternoon to supplement this income, as their daughter cannot be left alone. There are three other children in the family. Inevitably this couple has found the expense of providing for their daughter a considerable drain on their finances and their need for support has now become desperate. They were advised to apply for help under the program of aids for disabled people and prepared a submission for such help. They wish to be able to purchase a van to enable their daughter to leave her home without pain, and require financial help with a battery operated wheelchair and a hoist for the chair. I supported this submission from her parents and assumed that such a deserving case would have little trouble in gaining help.

However, when the parents approached the hospital they were virtually laughed at, and told that their daughter's requirements would take up the whole of the hospital's allocation. They have received no help at all from this program. It seems extraordinary to me that such a case of extreme hardship and tragedy, where a family has worked so hard and for so long to help their daughter, and devoted enormous sums of money to this, can get no relief from a program supposedly designed to help such cases.

The primary objective of the International Year of Disabled Persons, as proclaimed by the United Nations, is to promote 'full participation and equality' for disabled people in everyday community life. I therefore call on the Minister to extend this scheme until it becomes a genuine vehicle for enabling disabled people to have some real access to the community. Realistic funding must be provided for the numbers of people desperately in need of this help.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased with the Government's decision with regard to the Community Youth Support Scheme, and I know that there are in the House tonight many honourable members who were very supportive of its continuation. But I would like to issue a note of warning, not only to Government members. I think members of the Opposition should heed the warning too. They have done a fair bit of talking about CYSS since it has been in a state of flux, but they did not say very much about it when we originated it. They did not say so much about it during the difficult times, and there have been difficult times with CYSS. I think we are now all charged with the responsibility of making absolutely certain that the right project officers handle CYSS. We were critical of a few who were not the right types to be looking after young people. That is a fact of life.
—A minority.

—It is a minority group, admittedly. If there is one bad apple in the case, it will send the case bad. I did not mean to mention apples, but that is true. Therefore, we have that responbility to make absolutely certain that we have the right people looking after CYSS. Then if we extend CYSS we will have good programs throughout Australia and we can do something positive for the young people. This will need the co-operation of the Opposition and, of course, the co-operation of the Government. If in the future we have a bad scheme then we, as parliamentary representatives, should curtail it. We should have that responsibility and we should not leave it to the Commonwealth Employment Service or to some public servants who would not have a clue about what makes a good CYSS program tick. We need to get involved. So, therefore--
—I don't agree.
—You do not agree? Why?
—Order! The honourable member will address the Chair.

—I am sorry. My parliamentary colleague is sort of creating an argument, which is quite unusual. I am sure that CYSS will continue. I come to another little problem in Tasmania at the moment. Procrastination is the thief of time. I said the other night that we have a fairly good Premier in Tasmania but that he procrastinates and will not make postive decisions. Surely that is what has created most of the problems in Tasmania at the moment-our poor Premier cannot make a decision. He has made another disastrous decision. He has left out of the referendum the critical question about whether there should be no dams at all. A lot of people seem to be very interested in Tasmania now. They were not interested before. They are not interested when we have a strike, but they all seem to want to come to Tasmania with their haversacks on their backs looking at the stars and saying they are going to make it survive for the future. They are getting involved now in Tasmania. They were not involved before.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —We have a division in our friends in the Labor Party. Mr Hayden comes to Tasmania and tells the hydro-electric workers that the State should make the decision. We have the Opposition spokesman on the environment, Mr West, saying no, there should be intervention by the--
—Order! The honourable member for Franklin will refer to honourable members by their positions or their electorates, not by name.
—I beg your pardon, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am sorry. I thought I did. I thought I said: 'the Opposition spokesman on the environment'.
—No. What is his seat?

—Newcastle, yes. There is plenty of coal in Newcastle. That is probably the reason he wants an alternative fuel in Tasmania. He probably wants Newcastle coal to go down there. But that is just one reason. Another point I would like to make concerns the Huon highway in Tasmania. That is where all the apples are grown in Tasmania. I see I have only a second left. We have had a lot of trouble in the last couple of weeks and this week in particular. I would like to see a coup within the Labor Party to decide once and for all who is going to be its leader, Mr Hawke or Mr Hayden, because they are mucking us all up.
—Order! The honourable member offends the Standing Orders again. I ask him to be more particular in observance of the parliamentary forms.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon C.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter not in any sense in an attempt to score off anyone but just to put a point of view, in an endeavour to get some assurances from the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) who I hope either will be listening or will be on his way to the chamber, on the recent aircraft accident in Sydney, the findings that the Minister tabled in this place on Tuesday and some of the information that is now starting to float out with regard to air operations. Whilst I realise that a commission of inquiry has been appointed to investigate the aircraft accident investigation report, I still believe we should get some assurances from the Minister that the Department is moving to ensure that the things that possibly brought about this tragic accident are not going to happen again. I draw the attention of the House to conclusion 5 on page 42 which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The aircraft operating weight used by the company did not make allowance for all the equipment carried on the aicraft.
The last sentence in conclusion 6 states:
The Weight Sheet incorrectly indicated that the aircraft was loaded within the maximum permitted limit.
In actual fact it was not. On page 43, conclusion 7 states:
The fuel load figure used by the pilot was in error by some 40 kg. The reason for this error could not be established.
Conclusion 13 states:

A take-off at the company limit of 700 degree centigrade reduced the power available by approximately 23 per cent and, under the ambient conditions, reduced the single-engine performance to a critical level.
This was done, obviously, with the approval, knowledge and direction of the company. On page 44, conclusion 14 states:

Officers of the Department of Transport were aware of the unapproved practices in respect of standard passenger weights and reduced power take-offs but action had not been taken to regularise the company's operations.
Conclusion 15 reads:
Although the aircraft was equipped with an auto-feather system, it was company policy, in the interests of fleet standardisation, not to use the system.

Was it for the safety of the passengers who were flying in that aeroplane that that was done or was it a case of the company stretching to the limit the operations of the aircraft to give maximum profit? I am trying to get the Minister for Transport's assurance that the Department is acting to ensure that all of these matters will be rectified. Conclusions 16 states:
The take-off was probably made with power set at the company limit of 700 degree centigrade ITT.

All the way through the report there are issues that indicate a laxity that has crept into the industry. The commuter industry is now a very substantial means of transport for thousands of people. Over a hundred thousand people fly from Newcastle to Sydney every year on commuters. It was clearly established in this report that the aircraft was 128 kilograms overweight. That is an unacceptable weight in the size of that aeroplane.

I am pleased to see the honourable member for Barton (Mr Bradfield) here. A Press report in today's Sydney Morning Herald which has obviously been checking on these matters states that the big jets are cutting back on power so as to reduce the level of noise to the people living under flight paths. That noise is just too bad for the people living there. The Department should ensure those aircraft are taking off and landing in conformity with the rules laid down in the manuals for take-off, weight, speed and all aspects that are necessary to ensure safety of operation. It is also claimed that aircraft are now using the full length of runways so they can take off with reduced power and so save wear and tear on the engine. I hope that the Minister will come into the House and give us an answer to some of these questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr F.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's national water resources program was recently announced. It provides for expenditure this year on capital items of $34.9m. This is an increase of approximately 20 per cent over last year's allocation. It provides limited scope for some new initiatives. We feel that the allocation for water resources in this country should be far in excess of $34.9m. This is the driest continent in the world. Unless we make provision for the storage of water we will face some very serious problems. Indeed these problems are with us today. These schemes have been put forward and are now under consideration. An announcement about them will be made at a later date.

SPEECH.PARA: It is pleasing to see that an allocation of $1.5m has been made for the Split Rock Dam project on the Manilla River, approximately 10 kilometres upstream from the town of Manilla. This dam is designed to store 370,000 megalitres. It will increase the flow in the Namoi River by about 30 per cent. This then flows into the great Keepit Dam, of course, which provides water for 200 or 300 miles down the Namoi River and particularly to the great cotton industry at Wee Waa. It is very important that the building of this dam be continued. It is to be hoped that the New South Wales Government, which has not given the Commonwealth its priorities to date, provides more funds this year for the building of the Split Rock Dam.

The situation is very serious in the Hunter River area. The capacity of the great Glenbawn Dam is down to 20 per cent. It was at 8 per cent but rain filled it up to 20 per cent. Very dry conditions exist in the Hunter Valley and in the north- west of New South Wales at present. Indeed, a very serious drought condition exists. It is very important that more water storages be built on the Hunter River.

The Bayswater Power Station, which is a very big power station, is being built. It and the Liddell Power Station, which is the biggest in the southern hemisphere, will draw their water from the Glenbawn Dam; so it can be seen that great problems exist. The dairy farmers down the Hunter River depend on this dam for irrigation water. The towns of Muswellbrook, Singleton and Scone depend on water as well from the Hunter River for the town supply. I note the State Government has commenced building a dam at Glennies Creek which is between Singleton and Muswellbrook and runs into the Hunter River. When this dam is completed, it will assist in providing further water supplies. But the Federal Government should be co-operating with the New South Wales Government in this area to see that more storages and dams are built. If more are not built, a calamitous situation will develop in that area.

The coal industry is developing at a great pace at Singleton, Muswellbrook and, indeed, up to Scone. These mines will require great quantities of water; we all know that. It is hoped that the Commonwealth water resources authority has close liaison with the New South Wales Water Resources Commission and takes note of the serious situation that exists in this area.

Major industrial development expected in the Hunter Valley over the next 25 years could mean that water needs will increase by at least three times the present need. If these needs are to be fully met, it is necessary that investigations be carried out immediately and water storage facilities implemented. Glennies Creek dam is now being constructed near Singleton. Proposals are in hand to enlarge the Glenbawn Dam. The Kerrabee Dam on the Goulburn River is also mentioned for the New South Wales program. The Goulburn River eventually flows into the Hunter at Denman. It is very important that every effort be made to increase our water storage, to provide more funds and to co-operate with the State Government to see that they are provided so that a calamitous situation will be avoided.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his Press release of 5 June 1981 on Airbus A300 curfew dispensation, can he indicate (a) how he intends to take the views of communities into account before any decision on the matter is taken and (b) in particular how will he assess the views of Adelaide residents living near the airport.

(2) As A300 aircraft are not scheduled to operate from Adelaide Airport until late in 1982, does his statement mean that any proposed change to the curfew at Adelaide Airport will not be considered at least until after that date; if not, what is the position.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) and (b) My Department has established noise abatement committees at the major capital city airports to facilitate, inter alia, public participation in finding the best possible answers to the aircraft noise problem. ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: French Nuclear Testing at Mururoa Atoll

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 September 1981 the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Lionel Bowen) asked me a question, without notice, concerning the French nuclear testing at Mururoa Atoll.

ANSWER.PARA: The following is in answer to the honourable member's question:

The Government is aware that on 12 August 1981 the French authorities in French Polynesia issued a communique declaring the temporary closure of the beach in the eastern part of Mururoa Atoll against the possibility that ''residues of the atmospheric tests conducted prior to 1975'' might have been deposited there following a period of bad weather. The French communique stated that ''the temporary situation that has been created is a result of atmospheric testing and had no link with the underground testing that has been carried out since 1975''.

The Government has no information concerning any serious leaks of radioactivity in the waters of Mururoa Atoll. Nor does it have information which supports the suggestion that, due to venting, a large gap has been opened in the atoll below sea level. However, in in the light of the information provided by the Honourable Member, the Government is making urgent enquiries into this matter. In the absence of any further information it would of course be premature to canvass courses of action which might be open to it to take.

As will be known, Australia's continued opposition to the French nuclear testing program is firmly on record with the Government of France. Our position has been frequently conveyed to France, most recently during discussions in Paris in June between Mr Street and the French Foreign Minister, M. Cheysson.

Australia also supported the resolution adopted by the recent Twelfth Meeting of the South Pacific Forum in Vanuatu which, among other things, reaffirmed the Forum's strong condemnation of nuclear weapons testing and urged France immediately to cease its nuclear weapons testing program and provide full details of the effects of its past testing activities on Pacific people and the environment.
